In this he is quite right. We have fearful thunderstorms on the mountains, and the large trees, acting as conductors, have nearly all disappeared. Now the question is, will not such a large quantity of iron attract the electric fluid, and act as a conductor to the destruction of the building? Will lightning rods do their work sufficiently to keep the building safe? Will not, if a thunderstorm come during a service, the danger increase that people might be struck? To decide these questions we should have something like statistics, which perhaps those could furnish who are constructing such buildings. Military engineers could, perhaps, give explanation. What we wish to know would be condensed into four questions for every building in a hot climate: 1. Where is the building? 2. When was it erected? 3. Has it ever been struck with lightning? 4. Has it lightning rods?

Would you do us the favour to make inquiries?—Yours, &c.,

---

**EGBA, YORUBA, ETC.**

**OBOMOSHO.**—The account recently given of a civil war having occurred there was substantially correct; the leading rebels were killed.'}, {'id': 1033, 'article_title': 'Valuable Kindness on the Part of a French Naval Officer', 'full_section_title': 'Valuable Kindness on the Part of a French Naval Officer', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1867#article-1', 'issue_date': '23_02_1867', 'content': 'A British merchant at the Gambia returning to Bathurst from England by way of Bordeaux, found himself in great difficulty lately on arriving at Goree; as in consequence of the prevalence of yellow fever there the French packet-boat quarantined the shore, so that there seemed no other course open to him than to go to the Brazils! But fortunately the French Admiral came alongside, and seeing how serious the difficulty was, gave the British merchant shelter on board his own ship, and afterward sent him down to the Gambia in a French vessel of war. We are glad to have to record this act of a French naval officer, and endeavor to believe that a British Admiral would under similar circumstances have shown the like courtesy to a merchant of France. It is an act certainly worthy of imitation.'}, {'id': 1149, 'article_title': 'Parliamentary Papers: Sierra Leone, Etc.', 'full_section_title': 'Parliamentary Papers: Sierra Leone, Etc.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_07_1867#article-12', 'issue_date': '23_07_1867', 'content': 'The second case referred to is that of Mr. Pike. In this case, the complainant was employed as a watchman, and one evening Mr. Pike had seen him arriving on duty at eight p.m.; but on returning at eleven p.m., not only was the man absent, but the gate of the premises was locked, and Mr. Pike could not get into his own house. At that time Mr. Pike, as Marshal of the Mixed Commission Court, had a considerable sum of public money in his house; and he was rather alarmed lest there should be some foul play; and the man coming up soon after, and not giving a satisfactory reply as to his reasons for leaving his post, and locking Mr. Pike out of his own premises, he did strike the man with his fist, and gave him a blow across the back with his stick. This man remained at his duty until the following day, when Mr. Rainy got hold of him; but Mr. Pike compromised the matter himself with the man for the sum of 10l.

In Mr. Marston's case, a man had entered his premises, the doorsteps being within an inclosure, to seek payment of a debt due to him by one of Mr. Marston's servants. The servant was out, but the man persisted in sitting down on the doorsteps, and making so much noise that Mr. Marston could not proceed with his business; the man was asked several times to go away, but refused; and eventually Mr. Marston forced him to the gate, and as he went out assisted his exit with his foot. An action was immediately taken by Mr. Rainy, and the jury gave 50l. damages. Mr. Marston was urged by his friends to move for a new trial, but he refused, as a new trial would only have been to a jury, imbued with the same prejudices and subject to the same influences as the first, and entailed upon him further expense.

I hope your Lordship will not imagine that I am an apologist for public officers forgetting themselves, as on the three occasions quoted; but I deny altogether that there was any "brutality" evinced; and certainly great provocation was given, and, as Colonel Ord observed before the committee, they were cases which in England would have been settled in a police-court; but I must say that this reign of terror, for I can call it nothing less, demoralized a large amount of the population. I have myself witnessed every kind of irritating insult offered to Europeans by natives, to endeavour to provoke a blow and a consequent civil action. This has been remarked on in every publication by authors who have visited this coast, and I may more particularly allude to Captain Burton's, Mr. Winword Reade's, and Captain Hewett's works.—I have, &c.,

**SAMUEL BLACKALL, Governor-in-Chief.**

---

**Letter from John Carr, Esq., Chief Justice of Sierra Leone, to Sir Frederic Rogers, Bart.**

7, Bennett Park, Blackheath, February 16, 1867.'}, {'id': 1382, 'article_title': 'West Africa Mails', 'full_section_title': 'West Africa Mails', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-0', 'issue_date': '23_09_1868', 'content': "The African R.M.S.S. Company's vessel Mandingo arrived at Liverpool on Monday morning, the 31st of August, with the regular mails, a large amount of specie, and thirty-three passengers, among whom were Mr. Usher from Cape Coast, Assistant-Surgeon Skues from Accra, and Admiral Patey from the Gambia.

At Sierra Leone writs were served on Mr. Usher and Mr. Skues for damages for alleged illegal proceedings towards Mr. Finlayson; who was released from his barbarous imprisonment at Accra on the 10th of July, by order of his Excellency Sir Arthur Kennedy, C.B., Governor-in-Chief of the West Coast Settlements.

The bi-monthly mail steamer arrived in due course at Liverpool on the 18th inst."}, {'id': 1412, 'article_title': 'GABOON RIVER', 'full_section_title': 'GABOON RIVER', 'last_edit_date': '07-22-1868', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-30', 'issue_date': '23_09_1868', 'content': 'The French authorities at this place will strangely persist in suspecting the English merchants (of all people in the world!) of dealing in slaves. A small steamer belonging to a firm extensively engaged in the African trade from Bonny to the Congo, whose business necessitates the employment of such a vessel, is most jealously watched in all her movements by the French naval officers and colonial officials, who have by some means succeeded in inoculating the English commodore with their absurd and unfounded suspicions; so that lately an English cruiser and a French gunboat were despatched to Cape Lopez to endeavour to catch the little steamer *in flagrante delicto*, and, as a matter of course, failed in their bootless errand, as there is not the remotest ground for believing either the firm in question, or any other, or the *employés* of any of them, to be in any way connected with the slave trade; but the French, whose own trade here is chiefly confined to a petty retail dealing in what is refused by the English houses, cannot by any means comprehend the possibility of the business of any of the latter being so large as to render necessary the employment of a steamer.'}, {'id': 1732, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '01-25-1870', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1870#article-9', 'issue_date': '23_02_1870', 'content': "Sir,—The authorities seem to be opening their eyes at last to the necessities you have so long been urging upon them. I am told that Mr. Ussher has asked to have a civil engineer sent out to this place. Who can tell but that there may be soon a beginning of those roads you have year after year cried aloud for. If it should be so, and the thing be well done and maintained, there will be great results, depend upon it, and all you have said will be justified by them.

Mr. Simpson, who was Acting Administrator here while Mr. Ussher was in England, is to be Collector of Customs at the Gambia, and Mr. Fowler, who has been Acting Collector at the Gambia since Kueller was removed, is to come as Collector here, Dr. Jones acting once more till he arrives. Our painstaking Chief Magistrate, Mr. Chalmers, has asked for leave of absence. He will get it, of course, and when he does, it is said Dr. Hinckes, Staff Surgeon, will be Acting Chief Magistrate. Let us hope he will be a just and good one.

The Fantee and Elmina-Ashantee trouble is not at all settled yet. Ashantee messengers—the late King's brother is one—have reached Elmina. On their way they committed great atrocities, destroying every Fantee residence in their path, and killing a great many poor people in cold blood. It is said the Dutch Governor is not over proud of his visitors who have done such deeds.—Yours truly,"}, {'id': 2079, 'article_title': "Geraldo's Statement of the Rise and Progress of the Awoonah War", 'full_section_title': "Geraldo's Statement of the Rise and Progress of the Awoonah War", 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1871#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_09_1871', 'content': "Sir,—The object of this is to inform you briefly of the war of which I have been supposed to have been the author and cause, and of which I am in the belief you possess more information than anybody else.

From 1856 to 1864 I was residing at Addah as a trader. Bristol captains who frequented that port were in the habit of supplying me with goods on credit, and as the credit system is general in our place, so I trusted also some of such supplies to people belonging to this town. These people became dilatory and afterwards unwilling to pay me for what I had given them on credit. As I must pay these captains, of course, I tried all means to come at payments, but it was fruitless. Being so pressed, I applied to the king of the place to enforce from the several debtors payments for me, which application the king readily complied with, but he was unsuccessful in obtaining any payments from the debtors for me. The king afterwards gave me permission to seize any oil which those debtors of mine might bring on the sea-coast for sale, till full payments were effected to me. On the strength of this I seized one of my debtor's, by name Ovorcoyrats, oil, which he had transported to the coast for sale. The oil amounted to eighty pots, about $160, which seizure was to be applied as part payment of what he owes me. Ovorcoyrats, therefore, was incited and instigated by all the educated traders, influential persons in that town, and those who cherished hatred against me, to do me harm; even the townspeople desired to kill me or to drive me out from the said place, but the king permitted them not to perform their evil intentions against me.

A time after the seizure above-named, Ovorcoyrats took two women and three men belonging to my family captive and carried them away, and afterwards attempted at night to kill me in my own house, having collected in my yard upwards of 200 men, at the head of which he and his brother were. I caught him and his brother, and therefore the 200 men ran away and escaped.

The next morning all the educated traders from Accra, Addah, and one white man in particular, Ungar, of the Bremen factory, gave the men forty kegs of gunpowder, and the educated men armed their labourers, slaves, &c., to come in the night-time to attack me whilst I was peaceably at home asleep, and have me killed. Accordingly, one house of mine was set on fire by a certain Nar (trader) by name, and all the things I had in that house were plundered. During this plunder I escaped from my house, about which armed men were encircled, and reached the borders of the Volta, and was brought over on that side the river by a man by name Povoroo. An influential man from Jellicoffee, by name John Tay, sent messengers to me, desiring me to stop and remain on the Volta till he comes up to settle the palaver between me and the Addahs amicably. Well, he came, and his interference was ineffectual, as also that of thirty-six Awoonah towns."}, {'id': 2807, 'article_title': 'ANOTHER CRY FROM CALABAR RIVER, WITH NOTES OF EVIDENCE BEFORE THE COURT OF EQUITY.', 'full_section_title': 'ANOTHER CRY FROM CALABAR RIVER, WITH NOTES OF EVIDENCE BEFORE THE COURT OF EQUITY.', 'last_edit_date': '08-31-1874', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_10_1874#article-12', 'issue_date': '30_10_1874', 'content': 'Sir,—Having heard the statement of the Sierra Leone men, and of the two white men connected with the mail steamer Bonny; and having heard and perused notes of evidence given at sundry meetings of what is called the Court of Equity—one set of said notes having been taken by the Sierra Leone men, and the other by a European, a member of the Court—I consider myself to be in a position to give an impartial account of a sad occurrence which took place in the Old Calabar River, on Saturday August 15, 1874. I shall in the meantime avoid mentioning names; and should I feel constrained in the course of my narrative to indicate any opinion of my own, I shall place such indication between brackets, so that if the reader chooses, he can pass over the opinions and confine his attention to the facts. On the day above named, about 11 a.m., a gig on the way to the mail steamer Bonny came into collision with a canoe which was also on its way to the steamer which had just arrived. These white gentlemen were in the gig, which was manned with the usual complement of Kroomen. There were four men in the canoe, and they had only one paddler, who was also the steerer of the canoe. The occupants of the canoe were Sierra Leone men. On seeing the gig coming dangerously near, one of them cried out, "Mind your helm! mind your helm!" In a second or two one of the Sierra Leone men received a stroke on the breast from one of the gig's oars, which knocked him over into the canoe on one of his neighbours; another oar struck the paddler and steerer, and at the same instant the collision occurred. From the stroke of the oar or the jerk of the canoe when struck, or perhaps from both causes, the paddler was pitched into the water. The gig party went on to the steamer, without waiting for a moment to ascertain the result of the collision. The canoe party and other spectators declare that the gig party went on their way, laughing at what had occurred. The man thrown into the water kept himself afloat for, apparently, from eight to ten minutes, crying "Help! help! help!" His own party were unable to aid him, being left without a paddle, and so much water being in their canoe that they were afraid to remain in it; and in spite of the opposition of the Kroomen, they clambered into one of the boats. They implored the Kroomen to save their countryman, and offered a reward for doing so, but not one of them would move.'}, {'id': 3002, 'article_title': 'Further Horrors at Lagos', 'full_section_title': 'Further Horrors at Lagos', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1875#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_12_1875', 'content': 'A Frenchman named Bonaud, agent at Leckie for Cyprien Fabre and Co., was brought before Captain Graves, acting stipendiary magistrate, and Messrs. J. P. L. Davies, A. H. Porter, C. D. Turton, and H. F. Wadeson, Justices of the Peace, charged with having committed an aggravated and brutal assault. It appeared in evidence that the Frenchman ordered three Accra men (Canoemen), at Leckie to be tied to a post, and himself flogged them with a horsewhip until blood gushed out of their persons. This was done by him because their canoe capsized on the Bar, and they lost their paddles. On going to get other paddles, the agent immediately he saw them ordered them to be tied up. Seeing the blood gushing from these men, the head canoeman ran to the Commandant, Cecil Dudley, Esq., but he would not listen to them. The Frenchman went to the Commandant, and got the headman and second headman locked up; so the boys seeing no redress ran to Lagos, and reported the matter to the Governor. The Bench fined the Frenchman 25l. and costs, and cautioned him that on any future occasion he would be imprisoned without fine. The Frenchman admitted the truth of the charge.

It remains for the Governor to deal with Mr. Commandant Dudley. The chief magistrate is said to have reported the whole thing to the Governor in Chief.'}, {'id': 3016, 'article_title': 'MONSIEUR BONNAT.', 'full_section_title': 'MONSIEUR BONNAT.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1875#article-20', 'issue_date': '01_12_1875', 'content': 'The following appeared in a Paris paper on the 23rd November: "It is stated that M. Bonnat, the French traveller, whose captivity was alluded to in the last sitting of the French Geographical Society, has escaped from the hands of the Djuabins, a black tribe on the Gold Coast, and has furthermore succeeded in contracting with the King of Ashanti 'a treaty of commerce, which assures to French traders a monopoly of the commerce of the country for ten years.'" We hope this absurd paragraph was not inspired by Mons. Bonnat through the agency of some Paris friend. It is quite certain that Mons. Bonnat had been detained by the Djuabins, and afterward allowed to return to Kumasi. But if he has been so ill advised by a foolish vanity as to make such an arrangement with the King of Ashanti, he must well know it is not worth the paper on which it is written. Since our little army was at Kumasi, the King of that country, whoever he may be, has no power to make a commercial treaty without the consent of the Governor of the Gold Coast, who is not likely to give over the whole trade of the interior, which has necessarily to pass through Ashanti, into French hands. We are sorry to see so foolish a paragraph with Mons. Bonnat's name mixed up in it.'}, {'id': 3065, 'article_title': "THE KING OF ASHANTI'S INDEMNITY", 'full_section_title': "THE KING OF ASHANTI'S INDEMNITY", 'last_edit_date': '02-07-1876', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1876#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_04_1876', 'content': "## THE KING OF ASHANTI'S INDEMNITY.

**CAPE COAST, February 7.**—The King of Ashanti paid another instalment of 500 ounces of gold, on account of the indemnity, on the 24th of January, to Dr. Gouldsbury, at Coomassie. The gold was sent, under escort of Captain Baker, to Cape Coast, but the money not being paid at the promised date, a fine was imposed of ten ounces, and paid at once. The gold paid by Ashanti has proved to be adulterated, and orders have been sent by the Governor that it be replaced in five days by good gold. Dr. Gouldsbury is still at Coomassie. The King of Djuabin arrived here on the 1st inst., having been summoned by the Governor for a reprimand for the late outbreak. He is now arranging to settle in the Protectorate, near Prahouse. Interior very quiet; roads all open. Trade dull. Commodore Hewett is expected here about the 14th. Lieutenant-Governor Lees arrived here on the 5th. The Daubin and his followers having been defeated by the Ashantees, sought protection from the Governor of the Gold Coast Colony, and were promised so much of the Protectorate for their habitation and cultivation on the same terms as the Protected tribes. Captain Baker's rapid march of four days to Coomassie has made a deep impression on the Ashantees at Coomassie. Human sacrifice has been put a stop to. It is stated that Captain Baker will proceed to the Windward districts immediately, but for what cause did not transpire. All is quiet in Ashanti. The King of Djuabin is nearly ready to start for the new site for his town. Trade is improving, owing to the interior disturbances being settled. The Whydah authorities have committed an outrage on a European agent of an English house. They stripped and flogged him, and imprisoned him in a filthy store, on account of the agent protesting against forcible appropriation of some property by the King's people.

A fire broke out at Little Popo on the 1st of February, which totally destroyed one-half of the Beachtown. In almost all the houses gunpowder is kept, and explosion after explosion took place, the natives not attempting to prevent the spreading of the flames. In one house 2,000 kegs exploded, causing a shock like that of an earthquake. Some of the natives, while plundering, were blown up, and it was reported that about fifty were killed. The loss is stated to be very considerable, two factories alone having lost about 4,000l."}, {'id': 3067, 'article_title': 'OUTRAGES UPON BRITISH SUBJECTS', 'full_section_title': 'OUTRAGES UPON BRITISH SUBJECTS', 'last_edit_date': '03-05-1876', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1876#article-4', 'issue_date': '01_04_1876', 'content': "## OUTRAGES UPON BRITISH SUBJECTS.

**CAPE COAST CASTLE, March 5.**—Her Majesty's corvette Active, Commodore Sir William Hewett, with the other vessels of the squadron, assembled at Whydah on February 23. A Court of Inquiry was then held, at which it was resolved that the King of Dahomey should be heavily fined for the outrages lately committed by his subjects against Englishmen. Three months are allowed to the King in which to pay the fine, and a blockade is threatened if it be not paid at the proper date. Notice of this has been served upon all the merchants. A British gunboat remains off Whydah. The action taken by Commodore Hewett in this matter has rendered him very popular among the European community."}, {'id': 3371, 'article_title': 'WRECK OF THE STEAMER SULTAN OF SOCKATOO, AND LOSS OF TEN MEN, ON THE RIVER NIGER.', 'full_section_title': 'WRECK OF THE STEAMER SULTAN OF SOCKATOO, AND LOSS OF TEN MEN, ON THE RIVER NIGER.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1877#article-24', 'issue_date': '01_08_1877', 'content': 'Sir,—The following is nearly, I believe, a verbatim copy of a report given to the senior officer whilst at Lagos by the Chief Engineer of one of Messrs. Miller Bros'. steamers plying on that river, and who is now on his way to England in the last steamer. He says, relating to the accident to the Sultan of Sockatoo, which caused her total loss, and unfortunately ten men also, "We left Andony, one of the stations near to Ebo, about the 24th of May, in company with the Sultan on our downward passage for Brass River, the Sultan leading. On the afternoon of the 25th, the Sultan grounded off Egberi and remained all night. On the 26th got off, and proceeded on our downward passage. In the afternoon, the Sultan grounded again near to Emblama, one of seven hostile villages, and the King Omoru also grounded about a quarter of a mile ahead of her and about one hundred yards off the West African Company's S.S. Victoria, which was also aground. The next day the Sultan got off and anchored near us, but as we could not get off, she proceeded for Brass, intending to return and lighten us. However, we managed to get off early next morning, when Captain Wallace, the nominal master of the Sultan, made his appearance in a boat, and informed us of the Sultan having struck a snag near to the village of the Kéama, a hostile village on Sterling Island, and that they were obliged to beach her, as casks in the fore-hold were all afloat in seven feet of water. We proceeded at once and took what cargo out of her we could. She had a deck load of puncheons of palm oil. She was laying on the starboard bilge and heading up the river, and nearly parallel with the bank. The natives rendered us assistance in getting some twenty odd puncheons of oil landed on the shore, and the chief of the place, whose name, I believe, is Kiama, voluntarily came on board the King Omoru with two of his head men, and offered them as hostages as an earnest that no harm should be done to the Sultan or her men; but one of them taking alarm backed out, and the chief most generously stepped forward and took his place, and the three of them proceeded in the Omoru to Brass, leaving Capt. Wallace and the Sultan's crew to look after the sunken vessel. The King Omoru returned to the Sultan as soon as possible, when it was found that to keep the vessel from heeling over too far, Captain Wallace had, with the assistance of the natives, landed several puncheons of palm oil. In the meantime, the natives of Emblama—far more numerous than those of Kiama—had collected in great numbers, which could overpower those of Kiama and Ogberi, and sent a hostile message the evening before the arrival of the Omoru, threatening to come down to the Sultan, and anyone interfering with them should be killed. Mr. Hunter, it appears, instead of making any attempt to pacify those who were already come down—and which he might easily have done with a few trifling presents—immediately put the three hostages into irons, the chief amongst the rest, and ordered the Krooboys to go on shore with the two boats to take the oil off the beach by force, when, seeing the natives made some resistance, he (Hunter) fired at and killed one or two of the natives, which caused them immediately to open fire and rush out, cutting down all they encountered. The Kroomen took to the water, and some of them managed to reach the steamers; but I am sorry to say that there are seven of them missing, no doubt killed, besides Abouke, an Accra cook, and our Accra cooper. It was found that the rifles were of no use, there being no ammunition for the brass gun or Gatlin gun, so that I presume, under the circumstances, it was found best to retire. I have since heard that the Sultan was completely stripped of every thing valuable. The hostages were (my informant says) to be taken to Fernando Po, to be dealt with by the British Consul, Mr. Hunter going with them to prosecute, and Captain Wallace and Mr. Dunn, chief engineer of the Sultan, as prosecuting witnesses; but whilst lying off the Mission-house in the S.S. Whydah, two of the hostages managed to slip their irons during the night and jumped overboard, but whether they reached the shore or not it is impossible to say. However, the chief only was left, and was taken to Fernando Po, where there is no doubt Mr. Hunter will tell his own tale before the Consul, and his witnesses will scarcely be able to contradict any of his assertions; at least out here, being in his power, he is able to do them any amount of injury, holding such sway as he does. The poor chief who so generously gave himself as an hostage, and who has been grossly ill-treated on board since being made prisoner, will have all against him, for there will be none that understands his language to interpret for him, and even if there were, the poor fellow will be so frightened and confused that he will not know what to say or what is being said against him. It must be remarked that none of the vessels of the other firms get molested, either going up or down the Niger, even the little steam launches, only Captain Croft's ship, the Sultan of Sockatoo, ever since Croft and Stout fired upon the villages to test the range, I suppose, of their Gatlin guns. Trusting that you may be able to find room for this in your valuable paper, I am, Sir, yours, &c.,'}, {'id': 3878, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA', 'last_edit_date': '10-01-1879', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1879#article-0', 'issue_date': '01_11_1879', 'content': "The news from Cantora is serious. It seems that Barcarry Sardow, King of Bondoo, who is a feudatory of the French in Senegal, marched a large force of men to the forks of the Gambia, and was there joined by the King of Fouta Foulah with his army. The combined forces then marched west, sixty miles, to Songkoonda, the capital of Cantora, attacked it, carried it by storm, killed King Collie and all the old people, and made slaves of the rest. They then attacked Farintoomba, destroyed it, killed King Nalling Marney, and devastated the country with fire and sword.

This at first looks like a mere savage raid, but when we consider Barcarry Sardow's close connection with the French in Senegal, suspicion arises that other influences are at work behind the savage king, and that this raid is but a portion of the scheme for disgusting the English with the Gambia and to make them willing to cede it to France.

Fortunately for the trade of the Gambia, Cantora is situated so high up the river, and so little trade is done there, that it will scarcely affect our commerce."}, {'id': 4312, 'article_title': 'West Coast News', 'full_section_title': 'West Coast News', 'last_edit_date': '11-01-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1881#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_11_1881', 'content': 'The British and African Royal Mail steamer Corisco, Charles Hamilton commander, arrived in the Mersey on Saturday, Oct. 15th, from the West Coast of Africa, with mails and passengers. She brings news to the effect that the rainy season had set in with unusual severity along the windward coast, accompanied by strong winds and heavy seas, causing the bars at many of the ports to be impassable for days together.

Prince Buaki, the leading Ambassador of the Ashantee King to the Governor of the Gold Coast, was at Winnebah at September 19, on his way to meet Sir Samuel Rowe at Accra, where the final arrangements were to be made for drawing up a treaty to open all the interior Ashantee roads for trading purposes. The Prince was escorted during the journey by Captain Lonsdale, of Zulu celebrity, and was accompanied by thirty-two Ashantee chiefs of various degrees, with their followers, all over five hundred in number.
**[NOVEMBER 1, 1881.]**

hundred persons. It is said that his Highness was wearing a massive necklet of rare and curious native workmanship in solid gold, which reached nearly to his knees, besides other jewellery. The Prince and his train were received everywhere with the greatest cordiality and respect, and were hospitably entertained by the chiefs of the various native towns through which they passed. The authorities at Cape Coast had offered to provide a passage by sea for the Prince, but he declined to venture on the water, being afraid of the British man-of-war, which he said might carry him away to some distant foreign port. Whilst at Winnebah, the castle and fort were thrown open for the inspection of his Highness, who expressed the greatest pleasure and admiration at all he saw. Guns were fired incessantly from the fort, and great rejoicings took place while the royal party stayed in the town.'}, {'id': 4352, 'article_title': 'The West Coast of Africa', 'full_section_title': 'The West Coast of Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1882#article-1', 'issue_date': '02_01_1882', 'content': "The Liberian Government have paid the fine of 5,000 dollars imposed by the German Government for the ill treatment of the crew of the German steamer Carlos. The amount was paid to Captain Valois, of the German corvette Victoria.

An order has been issued by the French governor of Senegal and its dependencies prohibiting the sale of arms and ammunition in the colony under his jurisdiction. Merchants and traders are warned that they will render themselves liable to punishment if they contravene this decree. The importation of all war material into any of the French possessions north of Sierra Leone is also prohibited, and the order is understood to have been issued with a view to prevent any war material reaching the Tunisian insurgents.

**Accra, November 11 (via Liverpool).**  
Mr. Woodcock, Queen's Advocate for the Gold Coast, has lost his life under very painful circumstances. He was sailing in a surf-boat, in company with three English officers, when it was capsized in the heavy surf on the beach. The three officers got ashore safely, and Mr. Woodcock had almost reached the shore when he became unconscious. He was pulled ashore by a number of people and conveyed at once to the Treasury House, but he died on his arrival there.

**Congo River, November 4 (via Liverpool).**  
The French factory at Banana Creek has been attacked by King Y'malan and his followers. A great number of the latter were killed and wounded. The dispute arose in consequence of the theft of a seine net from a French gunboat, which was lying in the creek a few days before. After the departure of the gunboat the net was discovered in the possession of some natives. They refused to give it up, and the agent of the factory ordered three of them to be arrested and kept in custody until the return of the gunboat, and upon this being done they attacked the factory. The dispute is still unsettled."}, {'id': 4855, 'article_title': 'LITTLE POPO.', 'full_section_title': 'LITTLE POPO.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1884#article-19', 'issue_date': '01_05_1884', 'content': 'As considerable attention is being attracted to the recent outbreak of hostilities between British residents and the German authorities on the Gold Coast, we reproduce the following in extenso from the Gold Coast Times: "On Wednesday, January 30, a German ship-of-war anchored in the roads, and the Captain came on shore to inquire into the causes of the recent troubles, as they had also militated greatly against the interests of German merchants. A grand meeting of all the chiefs was therefore held; but at this meeting, strange to say, it was arranged that one Cojo Jeyowhy, who is cousin to Pedro Cudjoe, should be crowned. Pedro Cudjoe is against the Lawsons—who are English—so the arrangement to put his cousin on the stool produced universal dissatisfaction among the British residents, including the Lawsons. The latter then persistently refused to acknowledge Cojo Jeyowhy as king, much to the indignation of the other side. The German Captain seeing this, all at once, sent for 100 Marines and blue-jackets to enforce the claims of Cojo Jeyowhy. These were landed, and their presence was the signal for a series of outrages. They surrounded the English houses, killed an English resident, perpetrated certain outrages, and seized the Lawsons, including Mr. W. T. G. Lawson, and sent them on board their man-of-war as prisoners. The greatest consternation prevails. The Germans are seemingly bent on playing a big game at Little Popo. British ships and troops are expected to secure redress for the British residents. A few days later the German ship-of-war, Sophie, left Little Popo for Lagos for coal, with the Lawsons (including Mr. W. T. G. Lawson) on board, with a view, after coaling, of carrying these people on to Germany as political prisoners. Directly the vessel arrived in the roads of Lagos, Mr. Lawson very prudently managed to get the fact of his arrival made known to Mr. Griffiths, the Lieut.-Governor, who, as soon as he got the news, ordered his release, there and then taking care to remonstrate with the German naval officers for the rash step they had taken in daring to sail from neutral waters into waters which were British, with British subjects on board as prisoners, and giving orders simultaneously that, in case of non-compliance, twenty-four hours afterwards, he would certainly enforce his claims. A meeting was then called of all the German officers on board, and it was deemed advisable that the Lawsons, including Mr. W. T. G. Lawson, should be released on shore.'}, {'id': 4912, 'article_title': 'THE FRENCH IN MADAGASCAR', 'full_section_title': 'THE FRENCH IN MADAGASCAR', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1884#article-12', 'issue_date': '01_09_1884', 'content': 'With regard to the alleged outrage on the British flag at Bageida, at present there are so many conflicting accounts that it is difficult to arrive at the truth; the facts, so far as we learn, appear to be that in June last the Gold Coast authorities arranged with the native chiefs for the cession of the Beh territory to the Colony. In July a German gunboat appeared, with Dr. Nachtigal on board, who seems to imagine himself the holder of a roving commission to annex territory wherever he pleases along the African coast. Among the traders in the Beh country were a small number of Germans, who appear to have taken the proposed annexation in rather bad part; and, as soon as Dr. Nachtigal learnt this, he hastened to the British flag-staff and hauled the flag down, and then with a salute of cannon hoisted the German ensign in its place, at the same time proclaiming the Beh territory a German protectorate. Of course, if these facts be true, the British flag has, long ere this, been replaced. But there is no reason to make political capital out of such an incident, of which the grotesqueness more than counterbalances the insult. No doubt Dr. Nachtigal acted very rashly, and in ignorance of the true facts of the case; and we trust we have heard the last of it. It would be well, perhaps, for Germany to bear in mind, now that she has developed a desire for founding colonies, that nothing is likely to so prejudice her efforts in that direction as the adoption of a high-handed policy with regard to the colonies and trading stations of her European neighbours. Upon the West Coast of Africa, Great Britain, France, and Portugal have long established a footing; it depends upon Germany herself whether she will in the future, by her policy abroad, strengthen or weaken her position among the colonising nations of the world. Meanwhile, we have every wish for the success of her mission on the West Coast. England and Germany are too closely allied by affinity and commercial interest to allow such petty incidents as the one alluded to above to disturb their mutual good-will. And we are sure the day is still very far distant when the two great branches of the Teutonic race, who owe so much to each other, will fall to quarrelling over such small matters as the "protection" of a particular trading station on the African coast.'}, {'id': 5371, 'article_title': 'Massacres in East Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Massacres in East Africa', 'last_edit_date': '04-25-1886', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1886#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_05_1886', 'content': 'Cairo, April 25.

News has been received from Aden of the massacre, by the Emir of Harrar, of the members of an expedition sent out by the Geographical Society of Milan. The victims are Counts Porro and Montiglio, Professor Sicata, Dr. Gethardi, Signori Romagnoli, Janni, Bianchi, and two servants. They were induced by treachery to pack up their arms, and were then set upon between Geldessa and Artou. At the former place there is a detachment of fifteen Indian soldiers, who were also surrounded and disarmed, but were not killed. The Emir of Harrar is a native of Harrari, a descendant of the old Emir, who was allowed to assume power when the Egyptians abandoned this territory.

"Aden, April 25.

"News has been received here from Zeila that all the members of the Italian Scientific Expedition, under Count Porro, which left that place on March 27, have been treacherously murdered by the Emir of Harrar, in the Somali country."

A letter from Aden to the Journal des Débats confirms the report. It appears that M. Barral had set out from Obock, to explore a great part of Abyssinia, and to establish commercial relations in the country. The caravan included M. Barral, Madame Barral, M. Savoure, and Dimitri Righas, an interpreter. It carried 3,000 muskets and a large supply of ammunition. It had left Harrar to go to Fare, when, after a two days' march, M. Barral and his wife, and a brother of the Sultan of Loitah, with nineteen well-armed Abyssinians, set out in search of water. At a short distance from the caravan they saw coming from the brushwood a number of native Assaimaras, who evidently meditated an attack. To intimidate them, M. Barral ordered his Abyssinians to fire a few shots into the air. They did so, and were reloading, when the natives attacked them with their lances. A struggle followed, in which the troop of M. Barral was entirely massacred. The main body of the caravan was next attacked. But the camel-drivers cut the belts binding the loads to the backs of the camels, and took flight towards Harrar.

Two days afterwards, another caravan came to the spot where the loads had been thrown down, and finding upwards of 2,000 muskets on the ground, and boxes broken open, they understood what had happened. Monseigneur Louis de Conzague, Vicar Apostolic of Shoa, sought for the remains of M. and Madame Barral, and, with much trouble discovering what had been left by the hyænas, gave them Christian burial.

In Rome, it is announced that a telegram has been received from the Italian Consul at Aden, stating that the Emir of Harrar, after putting to death all the Europeans in his capital, attacked, near Geldessa, with 200 soldiers, the Scientific Expedition under Count Porro, and massacred the whole party. The Emir then proceeded to Geldessa itself, and captured the town, taking prisoners the Anglo-Egyptian garrison, consisting of about a hundred men.'}, {'id': 5474, 'article_title': 'Further Troubles on the West Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Further Troubles on the West Coast', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-2', 'issue_date': '01_02_1887', 'content': 'From Grand Bassam, under date December 17, a few days ago, the French warship Golande, lying here, sent an expedition up the Grand Bassam river to punish the natives for what is said to be an old-standing offence. A detachment of blue-jackets and marines were landed and destroyed several villages. The villages were situated in the bush, and it was with some difficulty that the expedition carried out their operations. It was not stated how many of the blacks were killed, but it is believed that there were no casualties on the French side, at least not from the fire of the enemy.

After the expedition had returned an English trading launch was attacked, and six of the native crew on board were killed. The launch, which belonged to a London firm, was on its way to the seaboard with several lighters in tow containing cargoes of palm oil. It is thought that the natives, incensed at the punishment they received from the French, attacked the launch out of revenge. Besides killing six men, the natives seized a quantity of the oil.'}, {'id': 5790, 'article_title': 'THE FRENCH IN WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'THE FRENCH IN WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-1', 'issue_date': '04_02_1889', 'content': "News received at Lagos about the middle of December from Abeokuta reports that the French Catholic missionaries there have been ordered by the chiefs to leave the district, owing to the steps taken by some of their number in reference to the action of the French authorities.

It appears that in April last, M. Viard, a Frenchman, paid a visit to Abeokuta, and it was understood that he had a commission from the French Minister of Marine to explore the country to the north of Porto Novo, the French Protectorate, and to make his way northward to Boussa, on the River Niger, to meet Colonel Callieni. M. Viard was refused permission by the chiefs to go forward by way of Oyo, and while in Abeokuta it is reported he succeeded in inducing the chiefs to sign a Treaty placing their country under French protection, and that they had consented to the making of a railway from the neighbourhood of Porto Novo to Abeokuta.

The chiefs who were supposed to have signed the Treaty emphatically denied that they had entered into any such arrangement. M. Viard and the French missionary, Father Brun, averred that such a Treaty had been signed. M. Viard left for France to get the sanction of the French Government to what he had done, and promised to return in September last, which, however, he did not do.

In the interval a feeling hostile to any connexion with France manifested itself in Abeokuta, and on Nov. 7 a town's meeting was held, to which the Roman Catholic missionaries were summoned by the chiefs. The missionaries were questioned as to what they knew of M. Viard's movements, and were bidden to write and tell him that the chiefs said that he was on no account to return to Abeokuta, and that if he should persist in going to that town after the warning given him, they would kill him, no matter what the consequences might be.

Notice was also given to the missionaries that they must leave the town, taking with them all their property. Twelve days were given for this, the time allowed expiring on Nov. 19. According to the latest intelligence, however, the missionaries are still at Abeokuta, and the upshot of the matter is not yet known at Lagos."}, {'id': 5824, 'article_title': 'THE GERMANS ON THE WEST COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'THE GERMANS ON THE WEST COAST.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1889#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_04_1889', 'content': 'The British & African Company's steamer Gaboon, which arrived at Liverpool March 18, brings further news of the landing of a German force at Bibundi, in the Cameroons territory. It appears that the town was burned on Feb. 10 by a force of German sailors, who landed from the German gunboat Hyæna. Bibundi is part of the Cameroons territory, and it is alleged that the natives on the seacoast had some dispute with the tribes in the interior, which resulted in the coast men going up the country and burning down the enemy's town. Dr. Rabbe, the German Resident, afterwards went to the Cameroons to get instructions from the Governor-in-Chief, and returned with the war-vessel Hyæna. After a little "palaver" of an unsatisfactory nature, two boat loads of bluejackets were landed and marched on the place. They met with little or no opposition, but as a punishment on the coast tribes two of their towns were burned by the German sailors. This occurred on the evening of February 10, as the Gaboon lay at anchor at Bibundi, and the whole place was lit up by the flames of the burning houses.'}, {'id': 5837, 'article_title': 'ARREST OF AN AFRICAN CHIEF BY THE GERMANS.', 'full_section_title': 'ARREST OF AN AFRICAN CHIEF BY THE GERMANS.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_05_1889#article-11', 'issue_date': '06_05_1889', 'content': '

The steamer left the Old Calabar river on March 17, when there was considerable stir amongst the natives through the action of a German man-of-war, on board of which King Eyo, known as Honesty VII., had been taken as a prisoner. The proceedings on the part of the Germans was considered as very high-handed, as Old Calabar is a British protectorate, and the German vessel simply entered the river, landed an armed force, and without further ado took the King prisoner. King Eyo belongs to Creektown, Old Calabar, and the circumstances which led to his arrest are said to be as follows: Some trivial dispute taking place between two men belonging to the Bomboko and Rumby tribes, a gun accidentally went off, a woman belonging to the former tribe being killed. The Bombokos then made a descent on the town of the Rumbys, pillaging it. The inhabitants fled to New Wamaso. The Bomboko people then attacked New Wamaso, the inhabitants of which fled to the bush. Both the Rumby and Bomboko people are under German protection. There were two Old Calabar natives traders at New Wamaso, and the Bombokos made them pay redemption money and also carried off six of their servants. The Old Calabar traders for this blamed the New Wamaso people, and took seven of their people to Ikoneto, a town in the Old Calabar river, intending to keep them until their own people were returned to them. This was the circumstance which led to the visit of the German war-vessel to Old Calabar. A force was landed, and a messenger sent to King Eyo telling him that he was wanted by some white men. The King came down from Creek Town to confer with the white people. The German officer then told the King he must get the Rumby men at once, or he would be taken prisoner until they were released. He did not at once comply with the request, and was taken prisoner on board the gunboat. He was kept all night under arrest, and released next morning, when the Rumby men were restored. The two Calabar traders were also arrested and put on board the war-vessel, the Germans requiring a fine of two bullocks and three goats to be paid for their release. The King objected to this, but nevertheless sent the animals to Duke Town next day, when the gunboat had left the river with the traders on board. The affair caused considerable excitement on the river. The British Consul, Mr. E. H. Hewett, was absent at the time, but it was thought that the Germans would never be guilty of such a proceeding without first conferring with Her Majesty’s representative. It was said in the despatch that the natives in Old Calabar had too much confidence in the British protection to believe that such an action as that taken by the Germans would ever be allowed by England; but the strong-handed proceedings of the Germans in this instance and their equally peremptory action in taking Cameroons some time ago have led the natives to moderate their views of the importance of the English protection. Nothing was said of the restoration of the Old Calabar prisoners, so that it is believed that they are still in the hands of the Bombokos. The proceeding of the Germans was at first thought to savour very much of their action in the case of Malietoa, of Samoa, who strange to say is in exile in the adjacent river of Cameroons.'}, {'id': 5963, 'article_title': 'THE PORTUGUESE ON THE SHIRÉ RIVER.', 'full_section_title': 'THE PORTUGUESE ON THE SHIRÉ RIVER.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1890#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_04_1890', 'content': 'The following letter, which serves to throw some light upon the recent action of the Portuguese in Africa, has been sent to several of the London papers:—

Sir,—In view of the statements of Major Serpa Pinto, I think it right to hand you for publication the following extract from advices just received from our settlements in the Shiré highlands. It gives a clear account of the procedure of the Portuguese officials.

It will be seen that the Portuguese Expedition crossed the boundary line of the Ruo, penetrated to Katungas, a long distance into the territory of the British Protectorate, and there hauled down the British flag. It is not likely that European opinion will accept Major Serpa Pinto's assurance that too much is being made of these matters:—

"Katungas, January 3, 1890.

"About 1.30 p.m. on the 2nd inst. the news arrived that the Portuguese were coming, to test the truth of which Messrs. Wilson and Nash went over to the village Mwanza, and there met about one dozen of their soldiers, who, on being asked what they wanted, ran off, taking with them a gun which was standing against a tree,' with Messrs. Wilson, Nash, and several of the Makololo in pursuit, who followed them as far as the stream; they failed to recapture the gun. Mr. Wilson then returned to the station, and sent off letters to Mr. Moir, and then again went to the village with MacCulloch and Nash. They had not been there very long when the full force of 500 men arrived, followed by their leaders, Senhor Páiva and two half-castes. Páiva shook hands with them, and after a little said, 'I see you have the English flag up here. Can you show me a written permit from the Governor of the Shiré to have it flying?' Mr. Wilson replied that it had been hoisted by the British Consul, and was 'on the ground of the English protectorate—no permit was necessary. He then said, 'It is on Portuguese ground, and I request you to take it down,' which Mr. Wilson refused to do. He was very polite, and said he was, of course, only following his instructions. He again said, 'I respectfully request you to take the flag down,' and after being refused again, said, 'Well, I proceed to do so.' Mr. Wilson told him that he had might on his side; of course, he could not prevent him. He then hauled down the Red Ensign amid a salute of twenty-one guns and the 'Boo, boo, boo' of his soldiers, and then in its place hoisted the Portuguese, amid another salute of twenty-one guns. Mr. Wilson was then requested to haul down the flag at the station, which he refused to do. Then Páiva hauled it down, and offered it to Messrs. Wilson, Nash, and M'Culloch separately, all refusing to take it. Mr. Wilson told him that he could keep it, and that we would get it back with all the others when we were hoisting them up again.'}, {'id': 6026, 'article_title': 'Attack on a French Expedition in Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Attack on a French Expedition in Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/07_11_1890#article-2', 'issue_date': '07_11_1890', 'content': '### ATTACK ON A FRENCH EXPEDITION IN AFRICA.

**Intelligence** has been received in Paris of an attack by natives on a French commercial mission up the Niger. It seems that the French Hautenito Syndicate of the Congo recently sent an expedition, under the command of M. Mizon, to ascend the Niger and Binué. On arriving at Yola the expedition was to divide into two parties, one of which was to proceed from Barrona, on Lake Tchad, if possible to Algiers, while the other was to descend by Baghirmi as far as the river Sanga and the Congo, and to form a catalogue of all articles of commercial value they met with.

A telegram from Akassa, received on Oct. 24, announced that the mission has been attacked by natives in one of the arms of the estuary of the Niger. Commander Mizon received two wounds, and one of his Arab auxiliaries was wounded in six places. They are both being cared for at Akassa.

In consequence of this information M. Tharel, president of the syndicate, addressed a letter to the French Government, demanding that the Royal Niger Company shall be called upon to insure the safety of the navigation of that river, upon which freedom of commerce was guaranteed by the Berlin Conference. M. Tharel also claims an indemnity from the Niger Company.'}, {'id': 6244, 'article_title': 'The Germans in Africa', 'full_section_title': 'The Germans in Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_07_1892#article-14', 'issue_date': '04_07_1892', 'content': 'The Colonial section of the German Press is apprehensive that the agreements made by the French explorer, Lieutenant Mizon, with native chieftains in West Africa will be prejudicial to further progress in the Cameroons, which, of all German colonies, is considered the most capable of development. These arrangements, which are said to extend over the district between the Binue and the Songha, a tributary of the Congo, might block the way to Lake Chad, and consequently to the Hinterland of the Cameroons. The Vossische Zeitung remarks that Germany will always be able to reach Lake Chad from the south-west, if France still continues to look upon the east bank of the river Schari as the boundary of the French sphere of interest. There is reason to believe France will do this from her conduct in colonial matters towards Germany and her respect for the Berlin Agreement of 1885. Nor is it probable any hindrance will come from England, as the most easterly point in the British sphere of interest is Yola on the Binue, and the access to Lake Chad was last year assured to Germany by England. However, says the Vossische Zeitung, if England breaks her promise and attempts to cut off the Germans from Lake Chad, Germany can retaliate by raising claims on Sokoto, on the ground of commercial and friendly agreements formerly made by German travellers in that district.

At the general meeting of the German East Africa Co., held in Berlin, on June 14, the president stated that the Company was in a position to pay a dividend of 5 per cent. on the preference shares. This is the first pecuniary return yielded by German colonial enterprise.

In reference to the report from Zanzibar that Baron von Bülow, commander of the German station at Kilima-Njaro, had told the English missionaries to leave the Moschi district, as he was on the point of making an attack upon it, the Reichsanzeiger publishes the following official explanation: "This information is so far in accordance with the news received here from German East Africa that Herr von Bülow was intending to attack the Moschi district and warned the English missionaries in time. The British representative in Zanzibar has been informed by the Governor of the true state of the case, and that hostilities against the natives were only sanctioned under extreme pressure.'}, {'id': 6275, 'article_title': 'White and Black in South Africa', 'full_section_title': 'White and Black in South Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_12_1892#article-11', 'issue_date': '05_12_1892', 'content': 'A trial which has lately taken place at East London has created no little feeling throughout Cape Colony. Five white farmers were charged with tying up natives and cruelly flogging them. Two of the natives were so badly injured that they had to be removed to hospital, and one of them died of blood poisoning resulting from his wounds. The defendants were indicted for culpable homicide in the one case, and assault in respect of the others; and the Solicitor-General, who prosecuted for the Crown, described the narrative as exhibiting "a monotony of brutality."

For the defence it was alleged that nothing more than a "common assault" had been committed, and only by one of the farmers, Mr. J. P. T. Hart. Mr. Hart himself gave evidence, in which he said that he had only used a "reim," not a "sjambok," in flogging the natives, who had been killing valuable sheep belonging to him. His anger at his losses had something to do with the severity of the punishment. The jury found the defendants guilty of "common assault under great provocation," but acquitted them altogether on the other indictment.

Mr. Justice Jones, while admitting that there was some reason for the merciful view taken by the jury regarding the former charge, characterised the verdict of acquittal on the charge of homicide as "a disgrace to the community." For the assault, Hart was fined £125 or fifteen months' imprisonment, and the other sentences varied from £45 to £100.

The Judge's comments are strongly endorsed by a portion of the colonial Press, and resented by another section. The *Cape Times* says the jury decided that killing was no murder. The effect of the trial on the native mind cannot fail to be mischievous and disquieting. They "will see that they are liable to punishment without law, without proof of guilt, without fair inquiry of any sort, and that against such violence they are practically left without protection. The only remedy seems to be abandonment of trial by jury, and the establishment of a special Court, as on the diamond fields, or the adjudication of cases subject to the influence of racial prejudice." The *Eastern Province Herald*, while agreeing that men must not take the law into their own hands, calls upon the Government to suppress the crime which led to the present case. "Here is an owner of valuable stock losing them day by day, his own herds being in the conspiracy to rob him. He obtains from one of the boys a confession implicating several others, and he finds the skins of slaughtered sheep in the bush. He finds that sheep worth £30 apiece have been slaughtered for a beer-drink, and yet he can get no evidence which will hold water in a Court of law. Unless one of the thieves turns Queen's evidence, which he knows they will not do, he has no remedy whatever.'}, {'id': 6449, 'article_title': 'AN AFRICAN AGENCY DISPUTE.', 'full_section_title': 'AN AFRICAN AGENCY DISPUTE.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1894#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_06_1894', 'content': 'At the Liverpool Court of Passage, on May 18, Thomas Brown Bonning, seaman, brought an action against David Jones & Co., African merchants, Liverpool, for damages for breach of agreement.

The plaintiff said that he had twenty years' sea experience. In October 1893 noticing an advertisement for "An assistant trading master, aged 30 to 40, for the West Coast of Africa," he called on the defendants and entered into an agreement to go to the Cameroons for a period of two years, to assist in shipping produce and looking after the interests of the defendants. Plaintiff left England on Oct. 26, and on arrival at the Cameroons found a man named Thomas Sutton in charge there. Plaintiff was ready and willing to do his work, and asked Sutton every morning to give him something to do. There were between thirty and forty negroes to look after. He and Mr. Sutton fell out, and the latter told him to "pack his traps" and go, as he had a man of his own choosing coming out. On Feb. 2 Sutton (who had since died) came home to England, leaving plaintiff in charge with a letter of instructions. While there the witness sent a weekly account home as to the progress of the business. On leaving the Cameroons, Sutton informed plaintiff that an assistant was coming out from England. On Feb. 19, a man named Armitage arrived and showed plaintiff a letter from the firm, instructing him to give Armitage the full control of affairs. Plaintiff, however, contended that there was some mistake. Armitage replied that if plaintiff cabled home to Messrs. Jones he would abide by the decision. He did so, and received a cable in reply, "Give Armitage charge." He thereupon gave up his authority, merely retaining the keys until stock was taken. Armitage said that Mr. Jones desired that he (plaintiff) should return home. Plaintiff then left for England. On arrival he called on the defendants and asked them for wages. Mr. Jones said he would not be "particular to a pound or two," when plaintiff replied, "You are not going to get rid of me like that," and demanded the balance of his two years' wages.

Cross-examined.—He was of opinion that both Sutton and Armitage could discharge him. When Sutton, however, told him to go home, he replied, "Mr. Jones is the man who sent me out, and Mr. Jones will have to send me home."

Further cross-examined.—Plaintiff said that he had cabled home "signed agreement from Sutton to take charge; character irreproachable; will not be subordinate to Armitage." He alluded to his character on account of Sutton having cast reflections on him. Armitage had told him that if he did not go he would be given in custody to the German Government.'}, {'id': 6680, 'article_title': 'THE ASHANTI ENVOYS', 'full_section_title': 'THE ASHANTI ENVOYS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1896#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_01_1896', 'content': 'The Colonial Secretary has received the following telegram from Governor Maxwell, dated Dec. 27:—

"Ansah arrived this morning. Admitted to an interview with me at once. Delivered credentials. In reply to questions admitted document not signed by King. Prepared at Cape Coast Castle; mark of King made by Kwaku Toku, King's linguist, who held pen while he and Ansah made cross. Seal, British manufacture, London. Admitted that impression added on arrival there. I absolutely refused recognition of document as binding the King."

The Secretary of State for the Colonies desires to warn the public that concessions purporting to be obtained from the King of Coomassie will not be recognised by her Majesty's Government.

Mr. Jonathan E. Harris, the solicitor representing the Ashanti envoys, in explanation of the above official statement, declares that the King authenticated the original credentials, and it was thought necessary that triplicate copies thereof should be made on parchment. On arrival at Cape Coast Castle parchments were purchased, and these copies were duly made. By order of the King a seal made in London was affixed thereto. During the envoys' stay in London it was always represented that these triplicates were "copies," but that the envoys had possession of the original for production. Mr. Harris maintains therefore that the allegation that Prince John Ansah forged the credentials is unfounded, and furthermore that the envoys were the accredited representatives of the King, that their insignia of office were sent with them to London, and that these were accepted by Governor Griffith as sufficient evidence of the position of the messengers. Before Prince John Ansah can be accused of forgery, Mr. Harris submits, the Government should ascertain from the King himself the correctness or otherwise of these statements.

In spite of the plausibility of Mr. Harris's statement, most persons will doubt whether it was not the intention, should occasion arise, to repudiate engagements and concessions certified in this way; though it is, of course, conceivable that ignorance of European customs led these envoys into innocently perpetrating what is nothing more nor less than forgery.'}, {'id': 6820, 'article_title': 'Leaders', 'full_section_title': 'Leaders', 'last_edit_date': '02-04-1897', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1897#article-12', 'issue_date': '04_02_1897', 'content': "**THE TREACHEROUS CONDUCT** of the king of Benin towards a peaceful mission from the Niger Coast Protectorate has aroused a feeling of horror throughout the civilized world. It seems that, on or about New Year's Day, an expedition, whose object is averred to have been perfectly peaceful, was despatched to Benin city. This place is situated to the west of the Niger, and some 60 miles up the Benin river, which empties itself into the sea about 130 miles from Akassa. Besides Acting-Consul General Phillips, Major Copland Crawford (Deputy-Commissioner for the Protectorate), and a few other Europeans of note, there were about 150 Kroomen and native carriers composing the expedition, which left Sapele on Jan. 2. Nothing more was heard of it until, about a week or ten days later, the Consul-General's yacht arrived at Bonny with the tidings that the party had been attacked at Gwato by the Benin people, and massacred almost to a man. It appears that the members of the expedition were entirely unarmed, and were at first well received: but a few days later they were set upon by an immense number of Natives who were in ambush, and only two Englishmen and six or seven Natives escaped—and that almost by a miracle. It is almost needless to remark that the next expedition which approaches Benin will be equipped very differently from that which has just been destroyed. The King, a monster of the Prempeh stamp, unless his reputation belies him, must be promptly brought to book for his proceeding. A number of British officers, accompanied by Mr. Moor, the Consul-General of the Protectorate, left Liverpool at once for the Niger. Benin is easily accessible from the coast, and delay in exacting stern retribution is obviously undesirable.

---"}, {'id': 6830, 'article_title': 'THE BENIN EXPEDITION', 'full_section_title': 'THE BENIN EXPEDITION', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_04_1897#article-3', 'issue_date': '05_04_1897', 'content': "On the following day the advance guard moved on. On either side of the narrow path, only wide enough for us to go in single file, the bush was so dense that we could not see what was going on behind, but it swarmed with Natives, who on one side had cut a path some ten yards distant, running parallel to our own. From this they kept up a constant and harassing fire. They could see us, whereas we could hardly get a glimpse of them. That day we only got five miles, as every few minutes we had to halt and fire the Maxims at random into the bush, the whole column at the same time firing a volley on either side, every alternate man pointing his rifle in opposite directions. After a most difficult day we came at night to a large camp of the enemy at a place called Cross Roads. After an hour's fighting, in which three or four Hausas were hit, the place was captured. The Natives, who were massed in the clearing, rushed at us as we approached, but the Maxims were too much for them. Later we found a heap of twenty-eight bodies piled behind the village, where they had been carried by the enemy.

Next day the whole force moved up to Cross Roads, and continued the march. During the whole of these operations we had to halt every few yards and fire into the bush. The Maxims, two of which were in the front of each division, were mounted on tripods. Every few minutes the whole force had to drop on their knees and fire, then get up and go on as hard as possible. When Colonel Hamilton with the advance guard had got some three miles beyond Cross Roads, he sent back word that there was no water between there and Benin city. The Admiral at once decided to form a flying column of 250 white troops and Hausas, with Maxims and field guns, and to make a dash for Benin city.

On the morning of Feb. 16 the flying column started with three days' water and five days' provisions. We joined the advance guard at Agagi, where the Consul-General was. On the 17th we marched to Awoka, six miles distant, fighting the whole day and exposed to a straggling fire from both sides of the bush, which greatly harassed us. We camped at Awoka the same afternoon. In the evening our camp was fired into, but as the Natives never attack in the dark the night passed quietly. At daybreak on the 18th we started for Benin. The moment we started the enemy's fire opened and continued without intermission until noon. So difficult was our progress that at midday we had only made five miles. One bluejacket and a Hausa were shot dead, and were buried in the path by the rear-guard. Shortly after noon we reached a high bank with a gap in it. This was stockaded, and we found mounted an antiquated breech-loading gun. Three rounds from the field guns drove the Natives away, and the stockade blew up with guncotton. Later we captured the village, which was a small one, after a sharp fight, in which an enormous quantity of ammunition was expended."}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'TROUBLES IN CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Professor Bastian, of Berlin, has received the following letter from Dr. Fischer, the German African explorer, dated from Kagei: "The state of affairs at Uganda is very serious. The Arabs have lately been inciting the King against the Europeans, alleging that they purposed seizing the whole of Central Africa. Difficulties have also arisen with Unjoro, the Chief of that district having refused to receive any Europeans since his recent dispute with the Egyptians. Emin Bey is reported to have left Uganda, and there is consequently now no means of communication down the Nile. Mr. Mackay, the English missionary, is stated to have considerable influence over King Mwanga, who, however, has issued orders to all the neighbouring tribes not to allow any Europeans to pass through their territories unless coming from Uganda. King Mwanga's authority extends as far as Usakuma, and Englishmen, as well as Arabs, may do nothing in that district without his permission."', 'last_edit_date': '1886-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1886#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Having glanced at African exploration during the past 400 years, the lecturer proceeded to inquire what had been the net outcome of direct and indirect efforts and sacrifices and intercourse between the European and the African. He knew that the impression they had acquired from various sources was that the beneficent results were enormous; but he had been enabled to see for himself the nature of those results and to draw his own conclusions, and he appeared before them to put a pin into the beautiful iridescent bubble which they had blown for themselves with the materials supplied by the ignorant, the interested, the colour-blind, and the hopelessly biassed. Taking a bird's-eye view of the whole situation in time and space, so that each factor might assume its proper relative position and proportion, he unhesitatingly affirmed in the plainest language that so far their intercourse with African races, instead of being a blessing, had been little better than an unmitigated curse to them. These were strong statements, they would say, and required confirmation. If true, what could possibly have caused this frightful miscarriage of the noblest aspirations of a Christian people? The answer was simply the nature of their commerce with Africa in the past and present. To the slave and gin trades, and that in gunpowder and guns, must he ascribed the frightful evils they had brought upon the negro race, beside which the good they had tried to achieve was hardly discernible.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.644, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Reported Troubles in the Cameroons', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A recent telegram from Liverpool says that news received by the West African steamship Boma from the German colony of the Cameroons, which arrived in the Mersey on Nov. 11, shows that some serious disturbances have occurred there. The Boma left the Cameroons River on Oct. 11, at which date six chiefs had recently been sentenced to five years’ imprisonment, and were then awaiting transportation to the German Togo territory, which adjoins the Gold Coast. Some time ago trade in the Cameroons was so unsatisfactory that the traders, both English and German, formed a “conference,” and agreed to pay only certain prices to the Natives for produce. This agreement was maintained for some time, but appears to have been broken at last by one of the German houses. After this the Natives formed a “conference” against the traders, which one of the Natives broke in the same way by trading with an English house on the old terms. This Native and his people were seized by the other members of the “conference” and very badly treated, besides having everything in their canoes taken from them. Dr. Seitz, the Acting Governor, was administering the colony, and promptly had the offenders arrested. They included all the leading Natives of the place, and they were tried and found guilty of the offence charged against them. Three of them, including a king, were each fined a money payment, and six other chiefs were sentenced to five years’ imprisonment. The Natives of the place were in a state of great excitement. Governor Puttkamer arrived in the Cameroons just as the Boma left, and it was believed by the Natives that he would cancel the sentences on the chiefs. Although one of the reports said that the Natives would rise against the Germans and drive them out of the river, it was not believed by the English that anything of the kind would be attempted, as the Germans a few years ago gave the Natives a lesson of their strength which they are not likely to forget.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-12-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_12_1896#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.645, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The year 1892 promises to be a most eventful one in the history of West Africa. From all sides we hear of complications and troubles between the Natives and those who have taken upon themselves the functions of rulers and protectors. So far as Great Britain is concerned it would seem, happily, as if the difficulties were in a fair way towards a satisfactory solution. With the successful close of the military operations which have been found necessary in the Gambia, and the ready acceptance of the terms which were placed before the Jebus, we may hope that a more peaceful future lies before British intercourse, commercial and social, with the Natives, than has been the case during the past few years. But the Germans appear to have considerable trouble before them in the administration of the Cameroons. With the exception of Belgium, Germany stands in the position of being the youngest of the European nations as a Colonial Power. Ten years ago the German Colonial policy had no existence, and the great speed with which the resuscitated German Empire set about the task of founding and developing a Colonial Empire has not been without its visible drawbacks, in the lack of experience in government which has, both in the East and West of the Dark Continent, gone a long way towards damping their ardour in forming a vast Teutonic Empire in Africa. Even more difficult than the task before the Germans is that which confronts the French in West Africa. The existence of the uncivilised and independent kingdom of Dahomey has long been regarded as one of the great difficulties in the way of the peaceful development of the West Coast; and the conflict which has been forced upon the French Government is one which in some form or other was inevitable.
