[{'id': 340, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '04-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': 'Immediately after this tragedy, they placed his nephew on the stool, and made him swear eternal enmity to the Ashantees and allegiance to the British Government, and friendship to the allied tribes of the Accra district. All these circumstances took place during the time I was in Krepee, not twenty miles from the scene of action. However we may regret such a barbarous execution, still it must be admitted that it was done for the good of the public; and if it was unlawfully carried out, it was only because the Government that ought to have done it had long ceased to do its duty in those parts, and had formally withdrawn its protection from them. During the last twelve months the King of Ashantee has expended in Aquamboe alone no less than 1,500 or 2,000 ounces of gold in the purchase of salt, gunpowder, and lead, only. Without these supplies he must have given in to the demands of the British Government. The trade is still going on, or rather was, up to the time of the execution of Darko Yaw.

If the Government had despatched a force to occupy Aquamboe twelve months ago, it would have done much more to put an end to this war than could possibly be done by sending some 600 troops to perish in a useless campaign on the Prah.

It is very difficult for thinking men to believe that the British Government is sincerely desirous of bringing this disastrous war to a termination, for while the regular troops are encamped on the Prah, and supposed to be only waiting for the junction of the allied native forces before marching on Coomassie, the Government is issuing proclamations declaring its own people enemies; and to crown the whole, at the same time the Accra tribes are ordered to take the field, the Government is threatening the Kroboes with an invasion. What for—for aiding the Ashantees? No; but to compel them to pay an iniquitous fine, which has ruined all who ever had anything to do with it. The present phase of this Kroboe business is most disgraceful. We hear that the Government is enforcing the payment of this fine, and even threatens to sell the palm oil tree plantations of the Kroboes to the Aquapems to pay the contractors for the fine, thereby setting one tribe against another, and this at a period when unanimity is required amongst the tribes of the Eastern Districts.

The Governor called at Accra on the 6th inst., in H.M.S. Rattlesnake, Commodore Wilmot, but did not land. His Excellency was going on a cruise for the benefit of his health. Trade is very dull indeed at present in general produce, but that in cotton appears to be rapidly on the increase, as this mail will convey about 12,000lbs. to England of that article grown in this neighbourhood, and shipped at Accra. There is also a little gold trade, thanks to the apathy of the authorities in regard to the matters of the Aquamboe and Krepee districts.—Yours faithfully,'}, {'id': 503, 'article_title': 'INTERIOR OF THE EASTERN DISTRICTS.', 'full_section_title': 'INTERIOR OF THE EASTERN DISTRICTS.', 'last_edit_date': '11-10-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1864#article-18', 'issue_date': '23_12_1864', 'content': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Bibrassee, near Croboe, Accra District,  
November 10, 1864.

Sir,—I had intended to forward you a long account of the present state of affairs in these Eastern Districts by this mail, but am prevented doing so till next month. I may, however, inform you that, bad as things were twelve months ago, they are now infinitely worse, and it is difficult to describe, and impossible to imagine, the state of utter confusion in which the whole country is at present.

this moment the Government have not the slightest influence or authority out of James Town and Christiansborg.

It is true that constables are daily sent to other places with summonses or warrants, but not the least notice is taken of them; and not unfrequently parties summoned or to be arrested take it into their heads to cudgel the constables within an inch of their lives, and then kick them out of the place; yet even when such an incident occurs, no attempt is made on the part of the Government to vindicate their authority.

The consequence is, that travelling in the interior, or indeed in any place five miles from James Fort, is absolutely dangerous, from the almost certainty of being panyarred (seized) and sold, if a black, or if an European or Mulatto, detained for some fictitious claim of a party with whom the individual so detained has no connexion. What with the stoppage of trade on account of the Croboe fine, the insecurity of life and property, and the expected disturbances on account of the spirit tax, the whole country is in a nice state, and you may expect to hear of some fine goings on ere long.

No doubt the British public will be glad to learn that, through the vigilance of their cruisers on this coast, the slaves intended for shipment in the celebrated steam slaver have become so expensive to their owners at Whydah and other places, that they have been resold, in the neighbourhood of the Volta, to the Bush people for half price, some having even found their way up here, and also at Accra.—Yours, &c.,  
VOLTA.

P.S.—The mortality from smallpox in James Town and Dutch Town, &c., Accra, amounts to above 500. Although the paths have not been opened for communication and trade between Cape Coast and Ashantee, the Volta remains open to the Ashantees as before, and a fine trade in gold dust is going on in that direction. Is not this shameful on the part of the Government? All communications ought to be opened, or none at all. In this way there is neither peace nor war. That old Croboe fine affair is working constant mischief too.'}, {'id': 1958, 'article_title': 'SUPPLEMENT—Trial of Whobay', 'full_section_title': 'SUPPLEMENT—Trial of Whobay', 'last_edit_date': '10-21-1870', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1870#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_12_1870', 'content': "1. That I lived at Gondomah for seven years and was there when it was burnt by Whobay and others; that I have read the affidavit of Whobay, sworn on the 10th day of October; that I know Cabby, mentioned by him in the said affidavit. He was a blacksmith, but he is now a trader, resident out of the jurisdiction of this honourable Court. He is a headman. I was at Gondomah when it was destroyed by Whobay and other men. Many of these men told me that Cabby sent for them to invade Gondomah and British Bagroo. I believe that Cabby never would come to this settlement.

2. I know Mousah mentioned in the said affidavit made by Whobay. He is a headman. He was not at Gondomah when it was destroyed, but he sent many of his men; one of his men, named Phah Jongah, caught me at Gondomah and made a prisoner of me. Mousah does not live in British territory. I am sure that if either Cabby or Mousah could be found they would not, for any consideration, come into this settlement. If any British subject now went to Gangamah, or to the Imperreh country, he would not be safe. I believe the chiefs would either kill him or detain him.

3. I don't believe that either Cabby, Mousah, Forday, Bonay, and Labi, named by Whobay in his said affidavit, would come to this settlement, on any account; they would be afraid. They sent the war. They never will come to Sierra Leone. Cabby does not live at Gangamah; he lives at small boom two days' walk from Gangamah. Mousah does not live at Gangamah; he lives at Ma-Foy, eight days' walk from Gangamah. Labi does not live at Gangamah; he lives at Morkelleh, two days' walk from Gangamah. I have been living at Gondomah for seven years before it was captured, on Friday, March 11, last. I saw Whobay at Gondomah on Friday, about two o'clock in the afternoon; he came and spoke to me, and asked me what I was doing there; I was at that time with a rope. On Saturday, Whobay told some of the warriors to take me outside and kill me; I was too old, and only fit to be killed. I saw Whobay on Sunday, at Gondomah, about ten o'clock in the morning. I am quite sure he is the man that told the men to kill me. I got away from them on Sunday in a canoe.

**EDWARD GREEN CONOLLY.**

I, Bundoh, of Momalikay, in the Imperreh country, make oath and say:—

That I was one of the war men sent by Chiarka, Chief of Gangamah, to Gondomah.

I went to Gondomah with Whobay. No person of Gangamah can now come here. Whobay has a father at Gangamah, he was one of the war headman, his name is Bongy; he is brother to the Chief of Gangamah."}, {'id': 2988, 'article_title': 'The Expedition against the Congo Pirates', 'full_section_title': 'The Expedition against the Congo Pirates', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1875#article-17', 'issue_date': '01_11_1875', 'content': "

**Congo River, August 24.**—Her Majesty's ships Encounter, Spiteful, Merlin, and Foam have arrived here, and a conference with Commodore Sir W. N. W. Hewett, K.C.B., V.C., will be shortly held at a rendezvous about 150 miles off the coast, when our line of operations will be decided upon. The undertaking before us is a dangerous one, and it would be foolish to underrate its difficulties. The whole of the delta of the Congo is inhabited by a tribe of rascals called Missionghis, who live almost entirely by pillaging vessels proceeding peaceably up the river. The villages of these fellows are secreted in the midst of deadly mangrove swamps, which can only be approached by narrow mud creeks. During the past four weeks Captain Medlycott, R.N. (H.M.S. Spiteful), and Mr. Hopkins, our consul at St. Paul de Loanda, have been engaged day and night in surveying these creeks, and they are certainly the first Englishmen who have ever ventured so far in. The natives were often heard talking in the bush, but they never discovered the explorers. The result of their exertions is that a correct chart of the whole of the delta has been prepared, and will be laid before the Commodore without delay; he will be enabled to see at a glance how to get at the pirates, and it is to be hoped that he will teach them a sharp lesson. One of their latest acts of piracy was the attack upon and utter destruction of the British three-masted schooner Geraldine, and the murder of four of the unfortunate crew. This took place in January last. The Commodore and Mr. Hopkins went in March to a place called Ponta da Lenha, in the Congo River, convened a meeting of the so-called princes of that place, and desired them to give up the names of the chiefs who had instigated the attack on the Geraldine. They not only refused to give any information, but were most insulting and impertinent in their demeanour. When Mr. Hopkins told them that their conduct would go a long way to show that they were enemies of the Queen, they laughed in his face, and said they cared nothing at all about that. One of their practices is to catch white men and tie them up in their villages, and keep them there till a ransom is paid. When the Consul expostulated on this point with one chief called Capeta, of Macotetla, he threatened to serve the Consul the same if he got the chance. Mr. Hopkins jumped up to seize the ruffian, when his native followers immediately drew their bayonets and attempted to stab the Consul. This took place immediately under the guns of two men-of-war, and in the presence of several officers. I may say that I have had a long experience of West African natives, but these men are the worst I have ever known. It will be necessary, I fear, to punish them severely, as nothing else will curb their insolence. They actually began collecting their forces to attack H.M.'s gun-boat Foam when she went ashore on one of the numerous sand banks of the river, but she fortunately got off without damage as soon as the tide rose. I heard upon good authority that the natives had collected nearly 2,000 canoes, and that they would have fallen upon the ship at midnight. Two days after the Commodore and the Consul had their interviews with the chiefs at Ponta da Lenha they attacked another boat in the river, and stole all the goods it contained. The leaders of these pirates are Manuel Vacca, Ani-Zanzi, and Ani-Quango. It will, perhaps, be in the recollection of your readers that Manuel Vacca was removed from the Congo a few years ago, and left a prisoner in the island of Ascension. By what I cannot but consider an act of mistaken leniency he was allowed to return. He very soon commenced his old practices, and thus many valuable lives have been sacrificed, many cruel tortures practiced, and a great deal of property lost. There are English, French, and Brazilian traders in the Congo, most of whom have established credits with England. It is, in fact, English money that keeps them going, and a very valuable trade is done in ivory, gum, copal, bee's-wax, india-rubber, and palm oil, in exchange for cotton goods, guns, gunpowder, beads, and rum; but unless the depredations of the pirates are checked with a firm hand it is to be feared that the trade will languish and die away."}, {'id': 3815, 'article_title': 'The Difficulties at the River Scarcies', 'full_section_title': 'The Difficulties at the River Scarcies', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1879#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_08_1879', 'content': 'A correspondent, writing from the West Coast of Africa on July 7, says: "Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, in his reply to Mr. A. McArthur, states that the Island of Kikonkeh was ceded to Her Majesty in 1847, and that duties would naturally be levied there. This, however, is not the issue. Kikonkeh is a very small desert island, having no trade whatever; but from this vantage ground the Government seek to tax the trade of the whole of the rivers Pouncearia and Scarcies, two large and important native rivers, which the English might have had years ago if they had liked, but they would not: then have them. There is no treaty giving Great Britain the sovereignty of these rivers. The truth is that all the trade from these rivers used to go to Sierra Leone, but the high Customs tariffs have of late years diverted it from that colony and, in consequence, the merchants, both English and French, have preferred to take the risk of establishing their fortunes out of British jurisdiction. Sir M. Hicks-Beach was a little premature in supposing that all difficulties with the natives were over. Her Majesty's gunboat Pioneer, which was to have gone to the Gambia last month, is still detained there, unless she has been obliged to leave owing to sickness, she having, it is said, lost her doctor."'}, {'id': 6330, 'article_title': 'Anticipated Troubles near the Niger', 'full_section_title': 'Anticipated Troubles near the Niger', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_07_1893#article-1', 'issue_date': '03_07_1893', 'content': "Captain Lendy's position at present is by no means a pleasant one. His total force along the frontier consists of four white inspectors (all English military officers), four native sub-inspectors, and 350 men, with a Maxim gun, a seven-pounder, and rocket-troughs. Of these Captain Lendy has only fifty police with him at Falabah, but detachments have been left at Bafodia and Kimiki. It is expected that the frontier police will be reinforced shortly by the addition of one officer and a hundred men. Even then its number will be few enough for effective combination, as Falabah is 250 miles up country, and in the midst of turbulent tribes. The Merotays, who were defeated at Pambi a year ago, when Captain Lendy won his D.S.O., are in arms again, and have assembled at a town called Yana, are attempting to spoil his line of communication with Freetown. Intent upon that object they attacked Fafodia a few days ago, but were driven off, leaving thirty-three men dead on the field, while seventy-two prisoners fell into the hands of the Bafodia people, whose total losses were four killed and nine wounded. The Merotays, however, were not disheartened. Quite recently they attacked and captured another town close by, named Kadanou, and there they have erected a stockade to serve as a base from which they will probably attack Bafodia again, as the two places are a very short distance apart. Meanwhile fighting has been going on also at Kimiki, where parties of the Sierra Leone frontier police are stationed. Except the town which they hold, all Kimiki has been destroyed by Sofas, Kurankos, Connors, and Mendis, who have banded together for the purpose of attacking our friendlies. Captain Lendy's

position is thus rendered dangerous, and in a country so devastated by war he finds difficulty in getting a sufficiency of food even for his small force. He has advised that an expedition shall be sent up to punish the offending tribes, but the Colonial Government is always slow to quell disturbances of this kind. If Captain Lendy's force now at Falabah should have to fall back, it must skirt the area of war at Kimiki in order to reach Freetown, and that would involve camping four days or more in the open, a prospect far from pleasant since the rains begun, and, with the chances of being harassed day and night by hostile natives. The tribes are not deterred by dread of punishment. They have learned that though it may be sure it is very slow, and they have sufficient time to make preparation for it. They therefore do what pleases them at the time, and care not much for what may follow.

The British talk a great deal about their dislike to the slave trade, but by allowing these small wars to go on we encourage slavery. The warriors want slaves, and it is for the purpose of procuring them that they fight."}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'THE STATE OF THE OIL RIVERS DISTRICT.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There have lately been serious complications in this district, though happily they are not likely to lead to any very lasting results. Ever since the deportation of Ja-Ja, four or five chiefs, under the leadership of Kukiagam have obstructed traders passing their territory. The trouble occurred at Opobo, near Bonny river, and, notwithstanding the presence in the river of H.M.S. Bramble since September last, the chiefs have thrown a boom across the river to oppose the passage of steamboats belonging to the traders. The cause of their defiant action is easily understood. They occupy a commanding position in the river, and being possessed of thousands of men and arms to man their canoes, they are a dangerous enemy. Originally the traders purchased the produce of the interior entirely from them, but of late years have sent their steamboats higher up the river to buy at first cost. Hence their determination to prevent the traders passing through their territory. Major Macdonald, who had been sent from England as Commissioner, arrived off Opobo in the Pheasant, on March 3, immediately after the arrival of Admiral Wells in the Raleigh. The Bramble came out of the river to join the flag, and next morning was under weigh, the Admiral shifted his flag to the Pheasant, and, with the Commissioner, proceeded up the river, where they were met by Consul Hewett, from Bonny. This place is in telegraphic communication with England, so that on March 11 the Admiral, with the sanction of the Admiralty, was able to hold a grand palaver, which was attended by the Commissioner, the Consul, the leading traders, and the turbulent chiefs. Hundreds of natives came with their chiefs, and the Pheasant was anchored off the place with her guns loaded and the ship cleared for action. The chiefs were fined 300 puncheons of oil, were ordered to deliver up their guns and war-canoes, and to deposit £1,000 as security for good behaviour. On the following evening the Admiral signalled by electric light that the Bramble was to be sent for him, the Pheasant remaining up the river until the arrival of the Brisk, with Commander Winsloe. On Thursday, the 14th, the Admiral shifted his flag to the Bramble, and again, on coming out of the river, to the Raleigh, when the Bramble was ordered to proceed to Fernando Po, and then, by way of Saint Thomé and Ascension, to the Cape.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-05-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_05_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.681, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Letter of Chiefs of Sherbro' to Governor Rowe", 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—We, the undersigned Chiefs in the Big Boom River and adjacent countries, beg most respectfully to state for the information of his Excellency the Governor-in-Chief the following facts.

For some time past, and up to the present, this river and its neighbourhood have been in an agitated state, consequent upon the fixed determination of the Bompeh people to destroy Ticonco and afterwards to cross the river and make war, if possible, upon the Lubus.

The instigator of all this mischief is the notorious Cannagbo, who by his duplicity successfully evaded the British Government and re-entered the country, from which he had with much trouble been expelled. Since this man's return a continual disturbance has been kept up; order has been overthrown, the authority of the Government defied, and a fatal blow given to the industries of the country. Hence it is that the great dullness of trade is everywhere complained of in the river, for the constant kidnapping by the Bompeh people, headed by Cannagbo, of the Ticonco people and other tribes from the interior on their way to the river-side with commercial products, has dealt a death-blow to trade, and cannot fail to affect materially and directly the revenue of Her Majesty's Government. Even now, notwithstanding the actual presence of his Excellency at his seat of government, a fresh plot is being entered into by the same Bompeh people for the invasion of Gberry's territory at the very first favourable moment,—and how soon that moment may arrive we have no means of knowing; we apprehend, however that the dry season only is awaited to enable the disturbers of the peace to carry out their mischievous plans.

As Chiefs in treaty with Her Majesty's Government, we deem it our imperative duty to bring these facts under the notice of his Excellency at an early time, and not delay until the calamity,

has actually fallen upon the land. Experience has taught us that hesitation on our part in such-like matters caused the destruction of Mongrey and the overthrow of the Imperreh country; it therefore becomes us for the future to give at once the alarm whenever fresh dangers threaten, in order that effectual measures might be taken by the Government to destroy the very first symptoms of disorder.", 'last_edit_date': '1877-10-14', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1878#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Trans-Volta Districts', 'section_title': '', 'content': '---

We had written thus far when the following news, by the Senegal mail steamer, was published in the daily papers:—"West Coast of Africa.—Accra, Feb. 22 (viâ Liverpool).—An expedition is about to be sent to the Volta against the Awoonah tribe, to punish them for their recent outrage on a party of Excise officers, two of whom were killed. The inhabitants of Danoe have been already punished for their share in the affair, the town having been attacked and the natives driven out of it." Here we have the old course being pursued—bloodshed, and more bloodshed—to enforce upon people not under British law a two shillings-and-sixpence per gallon duty on spirits, and other Customs' duties of the Gold Coast Colony. Do not such conflicts and subsequent reprisals, or punishment, as it is here called, support our argument of the absolute necessity of the incorporation of the remaining Coast districts into the Gold Coast Colony—an incorporation earnestly prayed for by the importing traders in those districts? To all who know what those districts are, and the character of their people—notorious wreckers of every unfortunate vessel coming to grief in their waters—nothing could be more absurd than to qualify the annexation and bringing them under British law as an iniquity, or a gratification of the Imperial thirst for territory, which thirst we have already repudiated, and which the British Government has been far from evincing in that part of the world. Conflicts such as are shadowed forth in the paragraph we have here copied into our columns must and will continue while a two-and-sixpenny duty on spirits, and an equally onerous duty on tobacco, two imports in the greatest request, continue to be levied on a portion of that small line of coast, while the importation is free on the remaining small portion, except as regards certain small payments to the native chiefs, who, in the event of annexation, could be equitably remunerated. Our aim has ever been the civilization of the people of West Africa. None stand more in need of it than the Coast people of whom we are writing; and we do not hesitate to affirm there is little, if any, hope of their making any progress in civilization, which there means the suppression of a host of iniquities degrading to humanity, unless they be incorporated as above suggested. We, therefore, once again repeat our oft-recorded prayer, that the Home Government will authorize that of the Gold Coast Colony to confer on those districts and their people the benefits of British rule and law. We have avoided saying anything as to the effect that might be produced, and would unquestionably be produced, among the Awoonahs, whose territory and influence extend far into the interior. This is too large a question for us to treat of at present, beyond stating that they would come gradually under British influence, with results of no trifling importance to the Gold Coast Colony, and no slight advantage to themselves.', 'last_edit_date': '1882-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1882#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Sherbro' Affairs", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The merchants and traders in the Sherbro' owe you a debt of gratitude for having placed so fully on record in your columns the events connected with the plundering and murderous outbreak of Cannaghbob, and the extraordinary supineness of the head of the Sierra Leone Executive under circumstances so fraught with peril to the entire British trade in these countries, where the Commandant has no disposable force with which to maintain order.

By referring to the Blue Book, I find that Governor Berkeley, in his despatch to Lord Carnarvon, dated June 25th, 1874, remarks on the inadequacy of the armed police force at the disposal of the Commandant in the event of any outbreak, and thinks it necessary to augment the same by twenty men. He also states that "the occupation of certain stations on the mainland, within our jurisdiction, by a police force, would give satisfaction," although doubting that the then condition of the district was such as to call for immediate action in that respect. Governor Berkeley likewise wrote as follows:—

"Doubtless a more active interference on the part of the Government in native quarrels, and greater readiness to espouse, unconditionally, the cause of the merchants and petty traders in their disputes with the natives, would be a line of policy likely to meet with general approbation; but one that I could not recommend, inasmuch as I believe in many instances the subjects of this Government are at fault."

Just so; but I do not advocate "unconditional interference;" and most certainly, in the affair of Cannaghbob, "the subjects of this Government were not at fault," but quite the contrary; and at the present time scarcely a day elapses without bringing intelligence of the encroachment of the chiefs, whose attitude towards peaceful traders daily becomes more aggressive. In the Boom-Kittam and Big Boom, duties are to be levied by the chiefs on all produce bought by traders; and in the Kittam, traders are, without cause or reason, driven away from places at which they had long traded unmolested, and thus made to sacrifice all credit given to the natives. Not only this; they have been compelled to pay black mail in order to obtain permission to sell the little stores of salt in their factories, with the alternative of having their houses closed by force, in case of refusal to comply with this exaction, which is most unwarrantable and unjust.

Under date of March 1st, 1875, Mr. Darnell Davis, at that time Commandant, mentioned in a despatch to Lord Carnarvon, among other matters, the following:—

1. The desirability of fixing the seat of Government at Bendoo.  
2. The almost utter absence of representation in the Legislature of the interests of Sherbro'.  
3. The advantage to Sherbro' of having soldiers stationed in the district.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1878#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Anticipated Native Troubles in the Bight District', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The steamer Sherbro' arrived in the Mersey on Sept. 9th with mails and passengers from the West Coast of Africa. The Sherbro' brings news from the rivers to the 3rd August. Considerable anxiety was felt in Bonny and New Calabar lest the absence of all consular officials from the Bights should lead to a recurrence of the recent disturbances between the chiefs of those places in connexion with the Endelle markets and the Chief Will Braid's opposition to the Consular decision. The dispute was referred to Consul Hewitt when he was last out on the coast, and an award was given which should have been carried into effect last December, under a threat of fine and the presence of an armed vessel to enforce it. In consequence of the absence of Consul Hewitt and the sickness or death of the Vice-Consuls, nothing has been done in the matter. It is reported that the natives of New Calabar are now menacing the Bonny men on their way to and from the Endelle markets, and in such a way as will certainly lead to another of those native wars which are so ruinous to British interests. The treaties recently entered into between these people and Her Majesty's Government expressly forbid their entering upon war without first appealing to the Consular Court for redress of any wrongs; but the consular officials being now in England, this cannot be done, and much harm may occur unless they soon return to their posts.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE WITH THE GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. J. F. Hutton said that for years past the Manchester Chamber of Commerce had been in correspondence with the Colonial Office in reference to the West Coast of Africa, and had constantly called attention to the neglect of the authorities to attend to the interests of our trade, and to the responsibilities that ought to be undertaken in connexion with it. This trade especially concerned Manchester and the district around, because the bulk of the goods that went to the West Coast were cotton goods. For that reason, the Manchester Chamber of Commerce felt greatly interested in this question, and they asked the Government to consider whether they could not accept a greater amount of responsibility, not only as regarded the merchants, but also as regarded the natives in the interior. This country held possession of a mere fringe of the coast; but the goods that passed up the river were taxed, and merchants got no protection for their trade in return. The policy of the Colonial Office deterred merchants from going into the interior, and disheartened them. They had been urged, and in fact warned, not to go into the interior. The result was that our trade had fallen off considerably. He considered that the cause of this decline was, in a great measure, the absence of that order and responsibility that ought to exist on the coast of Africa. Complaints had been made of internal wars. These wars were continually arising among the tribes, and in some cases merchants had been ruined. A substantial duty was levied on goods passing along the Gambia, and the protection accorded in return was most inadequate. The case of Gambia was, perhaps, the worst of the class. It had been troubled by wars and robberies to such an extent that trade was almost ruined, and there was scarcely a merchant left of any position. The trade of the district was gradually passing into the hands of the French, from the want of activity and determination on the part of the British authorities. The British traders were being taxed without getting any adequate protection in return. The merchants had no representative on the Council. It was true there were...', 'last_edit_date': '1887-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1887#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.673, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the present time, from all parts of the West African coast, we have reports of troubles and disturbances, which must hamper trade and retard the commercial and civilising development of that part of the Dark Continent. For some months now the trade of Lagos has been blocked by the closing of the roads which, running through the district inhabited by the Jebu and Egba tribes, connect that port with the interior; but we are pleased to learn, from the latest telegrams received, that the careful and earnest steps that are being taken by the authorities to secure the opening of these trade routes, have not been without their moral effect upon the tribes implicated, for they are already making overtures of peace and reconciliation. It is much to be hoped that this is the case, for at the present time trade needs fostering on the West Coast more than perhaps ever before, and this object can only be attained by the cheerful co-operation of all interested in its maintenance. The British administration in West Africa has been by no means free from faults in the past; and these faults have born their natural fruit. The secret of good Colonial government would seem to consist in interfering as little as possible with Native customs and prejudices, but at the same time making it thoroughly understood that laws and ordinances must be respected. Now that the dispute with the Jebus and Egbas would seem to be in a fair way of settlement, it affords an opportunity to the Governor of Lagos to insure that, though these tribes are to be treated fairly and with patience, they must quite understand that any infraction of the engagements now or subsequently undertaken by them, will be visited most severely upon the offenders.

But the troubles in this part of the world are by no means confined to the British. It appears that the French have been forced into a war with Dahomey, the only...

[MAY 2, 1892.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have numerous treaties with the natives, beginning from 1826; they relate, in some instances, to cessions of territory, and always contain engagements for the protection of trade, the abolition of slavery, and the preservation of peace. They are not entered into by the natives without great consideration, and as they are rarely, if ever, broken, they are decidedly beneficial to the colony. Moreover, they afford us the plea for proffering our intervention when they show a disposition to quarrel amongst themselves, and in some recent instances our interference has been attended with very good results. The practice which has been long and successfully followed at Sierra Leone, of paying the chiefs small stipends to encourage them in observing these engagements, might advantageously be introduced at the Gambia.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Increased Troubles in the Eastern Districts', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—I regret very much to inform you that our war troubles on the Volta have assumed another serious aspect. A party of the enemy have crossed the Volta and have burnt one of our towns on the side of the banks, by name, Asuchary. Enough for "the peace at any price party." They will one and all one day feel the effects of it. Report reaches us to-day on the Coast that the Aquapims are coming themselves against the Croboes, and that a conflict will soon take place. I can only express the hope that this is not true; if so the country has come to its lowest ebb. I hear this new trouble originated by a party of the Croboes in Odumasie, where there is a missionary establishment, all owing to some Ashantees and Aquamoos trading for the purpose of supplying themselves with powder, guns, lead bars, and salt, at the time they are at war with our allies, and from which place they are getting all their supplies. This affair put some old people in mind of the war of 1821, when Sir Charles M'Carthy sacrificed himself for the salvation of this country. Whilst we are at war with Aquamoo and their allies, some people in Odumasie (through the advice of whom I don't know) are carrying out vigorous trade with the enemy, and should the Aquapims and others sit still we are indiscriminately cut off from existence.

Mr. Chief Magistrate Parker told us plainly and distinctly during his last visit here that we have no more claim for British protection. We all lament a war like this between Aquapim and Croboe. The country and all will have to go to the dogs at once.—Yours,', 'last_edit_date': '1868-10-21', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1868#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.671, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Menace of War by Ashanti', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'circumstances, of appointing a mere military man. Sir Samuel Rowe having had experience in those countries, having been at Coomassie with Sir John Glover, and shared, no doubt, with Sir John the disgust of not being allowed to remain there awhile and place the affairs of the countries beyond the Prah on a permanent peace footing, he knows the people with whom he has to deal, and has no more fear of an Ashantee than of any other untutored savage. Such a man, we hope, will see the necessity of something more than to be content that no invasion has taken place, or that it has been repulsed. It is not compatible with the dignity of the British Government, or with the duty of the latter to the countries under its protection, that the latter should remain liable to a repetition of the “Golden Axe” insult whenever it may suit a vain and ignorant barbarian to inflict it. Sir Samuel Rowe will, we hope, recognize the necessity, and make that necessity to be fully comprehended in Downing-street, that a definite line of policy must be adopted, and certain efficient measures be taken and maintained, as regards Ashanti and the other native States beyond the River Prah such as shall put an end for ever to the possibility of the recurrence of insulting threats, with their disturbing influence on industrial pursuits in the countries of the protectorate, and needless expense both to the Imperial and Colonial Exchequer. To give security to a country as well as to preserve peace and order in it, is one of the first duties of a sovereign power. This security the British Government must now give to the Fantee countries. We have made them dependent on us for protection, and we must make that protection efficient—not spasmodic, according to the varying humour of an insolent neighbouring barbarian, but constant and assured beyond the possibility of doubt. If it be said that the British Parliament, uninstructed by the fate of Old Rome, would not consent to any charge on the British Exchequer for any requisite measurer, then we say that the revenues of the protected territories, now not less than 100,000l. a year, are adequate for securing the interest on a public loan for the small amount that would be required. We have before contended that this revenue should be made available for guaranteeing railroads, and for other works of public improvement, that may aid in the development of the natural resources, vegetable and mineral, of those territories; but though we have the construction of railways there deeply at heart, we would postpone these and all other aids to industry in favour of that one great first aid without which all others are liable to fail in their object—security, perfect security, for life and property against the threat of barbarian invasion. We venture to hope that Sir Samuel Rowe will be the instrument through whom this great aid will be obtained. For ages past Ashanti has been the curse of all neighbouring countries. It was delivered into our hands in 1873-4 for destruction, and we failed in our duty, allowed it to be revived, and again to become insolent, and are now suffering the temporary disturbance of important industries, and compelled to incur considerable expense, because of that insolence. The line must be drawn somewhere; let it be drawn at the late “Golden Axe” menace; and then, within a few years, our great expectations of national wealth to come from those territories will be realized.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Report of the Commissioner appointed to Inquire into the Condition of the British Settlements on the West Coast of Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "As the trade, the revenue, and the general prosperity of the Colony depend entirely on the preservation of peace throughout the country, it is natural that the authorities should desire to extend as far and as widely as possible their influence over the people. By the acquisition which was forced upon us in 1853 of the native territory south of the Island of St. Mary, known as British Combo, and which has since been settled by military pensioners and captured Africans, we have interposed a barrier between the colony and a warlike and troublesome race, and have thus not only diminished the chances of future collisions, but have done much to ensure the peaceful cultivation of a large and valuable tract of country. On the northern side of the river, although we have long been the nominal possessors of a considerable portion of the Barra country, we have never ventured to exercise over it the slightest jurisdiction, and it has now been largely built on by the Marabouts, fanatics with whom it would be impossible to interfere; all thought of obtaining any influence over a country which they inhabit must therefore be abandoned. There is, however, one Sonninkee town, Essow, situated within the ceded mile of Barra, and just opposite St. Mary's Island, which, at the intercession of Governor d'Arcy, was spared by Maba when he burnt all the Pagan towns in the neighbourhood. Conscious of their weakness, the chiefs and people have expressed to the Governor a desire to live under British rule, the simplest mode of effecting which would be by the cession of their country, but this is impracticable, from the fact that they are shareholders. There are also strong objections to their country being made a protectorate, in the sense in which this word is understood in England. It would, however, be a subject of much regret if this small, harmless, and useful community should thus be abandoned to destruction through the fear of our becoming involved in unnecessary responsibilities, and it is to be hoped that the local Government may, without risk to itself, find some means of extending to them the protection they seek. Such a step would further our obtaining that influence on the northern side of the river of which, as has been stated, we are reaping the benefits on the south.

The natives not being British subjects, with the exception of the few residing permanently in the colony, are not, of course, liable to direct taxation, but the principal part of the revenue being derived from an export duty on ground-nuts, the produce of their labour, they do contribute largely, though indirectly, their share of taxation.

The export of slaves has been unknown at the Gambia for many years. In the wars which are constantly taking place between the natives, the prisoners are made slaves, and are either retained to work for their masters, or are sold to other parts of the country for the same purpose.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-03-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_04_1865#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Letter of Merchants and Traders to Governor Rowe', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Your Excellency having already been informed by the chiefs and traders of the Boom River that war has recently broken out there, it is needless for us to again enter into particulars concerning the same. We have, therefore, only to corroborate all they have written to you on the subject; but in justice to ourselves, we must inform your Excellency that the correspondence above referred to was not shown to the majority of us until Monday last.

We regret very much to learn from your Excellency's reply to the chiefs and traders that you have thought fit to decline to interfere between the belligerents, or to in any way punish the murderers of the two British subjects—the war men who first burnt and afterwards plundered every factory between Mobungo and Wymah.

From a previous knowledge of your Excellency's prompt and effective demonstration against the natives of the Jong and Bagroo Rivers, we are induced to believe that you will take such steps as you may deem necessary to re-establish peace in the country and vindicate the honour of the Government you represent.

We earnestly request your Excellency's immediate interference, in order that the war now raging in the Boom may not extend to the Kittam and other rivers.

We must remind your Excellency that we are entirely dependent on these two named rivers for the largest portion of the produce we collect. In the event of both being closed against commerce, we should have no alternative but to at once reduce our establishments until such time as peace shall be re-established throughout the country.

From your Excellency's letter to the chiefs of the Boom, we very much regret to learn that you so strongly advised them to seek redress by force of arms; although your predecessor, Mr. Kortwright (about two years ago), thought it advisable for British interests to enter into a treaty with the chiefs of Boom River, binding them to raze their war-fences to the ground; and also, in the event of any of the neighbouring tribes bringing war on them, that they should, before taking any active steps, submit the matter to the Commandant, and in the event of his not being able to settle the "palaver," they were then to lay the matter before the Governor-in-Chief for the time being. They further bound themselves to protect the lives and property of British subjects: and we are pleased to be enabled to say that they have carried out their part of the treaty in a manner little to be expected from an uncivilized tribe, though how far we have performed our obligations your Excellency knows better than we do.

Should your Excellency still decide not to interfere, the consequences will be most disastrous to us all, as the natives in the adjacent rivers will know then that they can plunder and murder British subjects with impunity. Trade will, in consequence, be stopped, and the prestige of the British Government entirely forgotten.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-03-15', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1878#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.69, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Wars among the Natives of the River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our informant, to whom we have alluded in our notice of the River Gambia, on our second page, writes in substance as follows, relative to those wars among the natives of the Gambia Districts, to which we have more than once alluded, and which have been generally represented as resulting from a Mohammedan propaganda by fire and sword:—

According to his version, the origin of this disturbance is to be found in the mismanagement of the late British war against the kingdom of Badiboo; and, therefore, that what seems now to occupy almost exclusively the heads, hearts, and hands of the Government, is traceable distinctly to their own acts. He seems to consider that the chief Mahabah is performing a duty which the Government neglected to do, and for doing which it envies the man who is really performing very important public services, and preparing the way for the progressive civilization of the country. That man, Mahabah, he says, is not seeking his own interests only, but that of all British subjects. British merchants have been without any real, efficient protection in the river of late years, and Mahabah has made a vast improvement in this respect during the last 24 months. It is true, he proceeds, that, partly owing to the war, and partly to the famine that prevailed during the rainy season, there has been a great deficiency of produce, "but it is far better to prepare the ground before sowing seed, than to sow it in unprepared soil." The Pagsoos, in this river, are a people that do not work, but who go about plundering those who do work; pillaging the merchants and traders, and committing many other and great enormities. They are, in fact, a lazy, predatory, and degraded people. The late war between the British and Badiboo was caused by such deeds as are above alluded to. The British effected really nothing, but Mahabah has made an entire change. These people, before so troublesome, having been brought by him under subjection, are now learning to depend on their own labour for the means of support; so that British merchants, who previously scarcely dared to commission any traders in that part, have now been able to find employment as traders there for those who have been (so arbitrarily, as he contends) dismissed from the Government service.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sir C. M. Macdonald on West African Development', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'and arrangements for that purpose had already been made. The best district was that of Benin, which was in charge of Captain Gallwey, of the East Lancashire Regiment. In a very able despatch forwarded by that officer, it was pointed out that the trade in this district for the past year was not satisfactory. The reasons were—first, the predominating influence of the great middleman chief Nana, who had had for many years past a monopoly of the trade, and who is jealous of any interference; second, the continued petty quarrels that occurred between the middlemen and the oil producers; third, the fetish rule of the King of Benin, who had placed religious prohibition on certain articles of trade, which prohibition was only removed by paying a heavy tax to the King; fourth, the inability of the natives to understand the varying price of products in the home markets. These obstacles to an increase of trade were being most ably and successfully dealt with by Captain Gallwey, an officer whose energy and tact in dealing with the natives was beyond all praise. Captain Gallwey had recently effected a treaty with the King of Benin, a potentate who hitherto refused all efforts in this direction. As to the districts of Brass and Warree, which marched with the Niger territories on the east and west, the chiefs of Brass were a difficult factor to deal with; they had many grievances, some real and some imaginary. Captain MacDonald, in charge of this district, had had a troublesome task to perform in dealing with them—a task he had carried out with much tact and skill. (Cheers.) A force of Mohammedan troops, 250 in number, had been raised—fully armed, drilled, and equipped—while barracks had been provided for them at Old Calabar. Fresh enlistments were taking place, but the supply of recruits was limited, owing to the demand for men in the West African colonies from whose territories the recruits were enlisted. The general plan, which was based on lines laid down in the Brussels Act, was to establish fortified posts at certain distances in the interior, to form between them lateral communications by means of roads well kept and guarded, and then to advance another parallel, leaving nothing unfinished or unguarded behind, and by such means to bring the whole of the ground covered under the influence of civilisation and Christianity. (Loud cheers.) But that was not so easy a task. By far the greater part of the native population were steeped in practices which were abhorrent. He alluded to human sacrifice, cannibalism, the slaughter of twins, and slave-raiding, with all its attendant horrors. To do away with these without setting the country in a blaze would require time, immense patience, and an intimate knowledge of the native character. Above all things with the African natives, they should be just; they should say what they were going to do and do it. (Cheers.) They should be gentle, but just and firm, and, above all, let the native feel that if he did wrong there was an iron hand of justice, backed by the law and power of England, but tempered by its mercy, from which in the long run there was no escape. (Cheers.)', 'last_edit_date': '1892-11-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_12_1892#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "A Snubbed Colony—Dr. Gouldsbury's Expedition", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Well, his lordship sends us an answer through the Administrator here, which being summarized is, "his lordship regrets that in your opinion trade should be in such a depressed state." Now, the words "your opinion" mean it is his lordship's opinion, based on that of the Administrator, that trade is good. And how does he arrive at that? Well, he takes the return of the revenue for the past couple of years and compares that with former years, and it looks well; but then importers and exporters had to pay duties each year whether they lost or not, hoping for the best; but really the past two years have been most disastrous. Four small mercantile houses have been smashed and disappeared; all the other houses have lost heavily, and some are considering about reducing or giving up the trade. The revenue will not increase then. His lordship "will not allow the use of force to stop native wars; counsel and persuasion must be used." Now, as for the latter, even accompanied by presents, the natives only laugh at them, and accept the presents. "As to protection of traders in Gambia River he cannot depart from the policy laid down already. (See Parliamentary Papers.)

"Expedition planned in the interests of Gambia; any disappointment as to its effect not caused by those who planned and conducted it. So Gambia must pay.

"Other parts of your letter are engaging the attention of the Colonial Office." Such was our answer.

Last mail brought me out a copy of the "Report of the Upper Gambia Expedition," better known as the Timbo Expedition, as printed for Parliament. It is got up so as to impress the M.P.'s "that something has been done." I always said it was suddenly conceived, hastily planned, and insufficiently supplied with stores and means of transit. I now find it was hastily and superficially carried out, but that was not the leader's fault, it was "orders." Fancy timing a man to do a journey in an almost unexplored region in Africa to a certain date; a race against time across country. The result has been very little. Space will not permit of more than notice of salient points.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-11-20', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_01_1882#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: The Ashanti War, initiated by an unprovoked Ashantee incursion, became a significant and contentious issue in British politics, influencing colonial policy, political debates, and election strategies in the UK.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide differing perspectives on the claim that the Ashanti War, initiated by an unprovoked Ashantee incursion, became a significant and contentious issue in British politics, influencing colonial policy, political debates, and election strategies in the UK. The General History of Africa offers a detailed account of the Ashanti-British conflicts, focusing on military engagements and diplomatic efforts, such as Prempeh's rejection of British protection and the subsequent British expedition against Ashanti. However, it does not explicitly support the claim regarding the war's impact on British political debates or election strategies, emphasizing instead the interactions between the Ashanti and the British. In contrast, The African Times articles provide substantial evidence supporting the claim, noting that the war began with an unprovoked incursion by the King of Ashantee, leading to loss of life and property. The articles highlight the war's impact on British politics through discussions and debates in the House of Commons, political maneuvering to avoid further parliamentary discussion, and its influence on colonial policy, with calls for more definitive measures to prevent future conflicts. Prominent political figures like Mr. Gladstone and Sir Charles Adderley are mentioned as being involved in the debates, and the war is depicted as a point of contention between political parties. While the articles suggest the war influenced election strategies, as seen in Mr. Gladstone's address to his constituents, they do not explicitly mention this influence, which is a notable difference from the claim. Overall, the African Times articles provide more direct support for the claim, with some minor differences in the specifics of election strategy influence, while the General History of Africa focuses more on the military and diplomatic aspects without addressing the political ramifications in the UK.

The textbook describes various Ashanti-British confrontations, including the Ashanti's military engagements and diplomatic efforts, such as Prempeh's rejection of British protection and the subsequent British expedition against Ashanti. However, it does not mention any direct impact on British political debates or election strategies. The focus is more on the military and diplomatic interactions between the Ashanti and the British, rather than the influence of these events on British domestic politics. This absence of information about the political ramifications in the UK is a notable difference from the claim.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that the Ashanti War, initiated by an unprovoked Ashantee incursion, became a significant and contentious issue in British politics. The articles mention that the war began with an unprovoked incursion by the King of Ashantee, leading to loss of life and property, which aligns with the claim. The war's impact on British politics is evident in the discussions and debates in the House of Commons, as well as the political maneuvering to avoid further discussion in Parliament. The articles also highlight the war's influence on colonial policy, with calls for a more definitive line of policy and efficient measures to prevent future conflicts. Additionally, the war's significance in political debates is underscored by the involvement of prominent political figures like Mr. Gladstone and Sir Charles Adderley, and its use as a point of contention between political parties. The articles also suggest that the war influenced election strategies, as seen in Mr. Gladstone's address to his constituents and the political implications of the war's outcome. However, the articles do not explicitly mention the war's influence on election strategies, which is a notable difference from the claim. Overall, the African Times articles provide substantial evidence supporting the claim, with some minor differences in the specifics of election strategy influence.
