[{'id': 431, 'article_title': 'CAPE OF GOOD HOPE.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE OF GOOD HOPE.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1864#article-17', 'issue_date': '23_08_1864', 'content': 'According to last advices, apprehensions were still entertained by the authorities, at the Cape, of a new Kafir war. Reinforcements had been sent to Natal. At the same time, traders coming from the Kafir country expressed the belief that the Kafirs "were quite peaceably disposed, and had no intention whatever of any warlike rising."

The Bishop of Cape Town was still at Natal, from whence he was expected to return in about a month. Bishop Tozer, of the late Central African Mission, was in Cape Town.

The weather had been very seasonable for the farmers, and a great breadth of land had been placed under cultivation. The prices of colonial produce, particularly grain, were on the increase.

Trade was rather dull, and the rates of interest were on the decline.'}, {'id': 479, 'article_title': 'LORD STANLEY ON AFRICAN AFFAIRS', 'full_section_title': 'LORD STANLEY ON AFRICAN AFFAIRS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-18', 'issue_date': '23_11_1864', 'content': 'In the course of a speech at West Lynn, on the 19th ult., the Right Hon. Lord Stanley, M.P., made the following remarks on the British West African settlements. It cannot be looked upon as unimportant that so distinguished a member of the House should have expressed such opinions: "There is another matter which Parliament must shortly deal with—our relations with the African coast. There has been a waste of life and money in that, the most pestilential climate which exists, of which I believe few persons are fully aware, and the risk is even greater than the loss. Take the thing called the Cape Coast Protectorate. That may at any time involve you in war—it last year actually did involve you in war—with some barbarous chief like the King of Ashantee, in a country where men die like rotten sheep, and never see the face of an enemy. And what is the return for all that? I suspect, uncommonly little. The whole subject of these African settlements and of the African squadron wants inquiry, and I am glad to learn that it is about to be taken up in the course of next session by an independent member. My own idea is, hold on to places where you can develop an important traffic, if by abandoning them you would sacrifice that traffic, but do not go inland; hold nothing except where you can reach by water; keep clear of protectorates and alliances; and recollect that, though civilising Africa may be a very noble idea with those who are willing to undertake it, still England ought to be just before she is generous, and we have plenty of that work to do nearer home." (Applause.)'}, {'id': 613, 'article_title': 'GENERAL OBSERVATIONS', 'full_section_title': 'GENERAL OBSERVATIONS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-21', 'issue_date': '23_05_1865', 'content': 'The new President of the United States has offered a reward of 100,000 dollars for the apprehension of President Davis, and 10,000 dollars for prominent members of the late Confederate Government.

The British Troops from Lagos have driven the Egbas (Abeokutans) from before Ikorodu. The rockets and Enfield rifles produced great havoc among them.

The following are, it is said, to be examined before the House of Commons Committee during the next month: Governors Pine, Blackall and D'Arcy, Colonel Conran, Colonel O'Connor, Mr. Ross, late Colonial Secretary at Cape Coast, &c.

The people in Natal do not agree with Colonel Ord about roads. "What wonder," they say, "that trade is suffering, when transport is impeded and difficult." They clamour for a perfect system of roads throughout the colony.

Major Jones, now acting Governor of the Gold Coast, agrees with the late Duke of Wellington, and not with Colonel Ord, about roads. Major Jones, traversing the Aquapim mountains, on his way to Kroboe, has obtained a promise from the Akropong King to complete that section of the Basle Missionary-road, between Aburi and Abokobi. If he does this there will then be forty-five miles of cart road from Accra to the interior.

Bullocks are now employed in traction on the Basle Missionary-road, between Accra and Abokobi. _Four gigs, with horses, are now driven on this road by residents of Accra!_

There are prisoners in James Fort, Accra, who have been there _waiting for trial_ for above twelve months, because the English judge neglects to come down from Cape Coast.

Mr. Tobin, managing director of the Company of African Merchants, in giving evidence before the Committee of the House of Commons, said that he looked forward to an _immense increase_ of the trade of West Africa, both with British settlements and with native ports. Many new articles of export from the Coast to England were likely to become very important.

The Sierra Leone Industrial Exhibition was closed by the Governor on the 22nd April. His Excellency stated that the success had even exceeded his anticipations. Governor Blackall comes home to give evidence before the Committee.

Another Kafir war seems imminent; and well-informed people at the Cape of Good Hope attribute it entirely to the vacillating policy—or utter want of policy—of the Governor, Sir Philip Wodehouse. Colonial Governors seem to be an expensive luxury.'}, {'id': 1097, 'article_title': 'The Lamentations of Cape Coast', 'full_section_title': 'The Lamentations of Cape Coast', 'last_edit_date': '04-10-1867', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1867#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1867', 'content': 'Mr. Editor, we are afraid, as Quashie Attah, the usurper, has been appointed headman against the people's consent, that they will not hear anything good from Cape Coast. King Aggery's removal from Cape Coast in such a manner will not end in good. Man proposes, but God disposes. Through the opposition of your Government, those who stood security for the money given to the delegates to the Parliamentary Committee are not yet paid, and the men are suffering. Very likely they will lose their houses and all they have in the world for it, because whenever a meeting was convened for the purpose the Government called it seditious, and letters have been sent to all districts not to render Cape Coast any assistance to defray the expenses incurred by sending delegates to England. Oh pity! these chiefs King Aggery sent men to for the money were committed before the delegates were sent to Parliament, and it was to redeem their promise that King Aggery sent messengers to them. Colonel Conran changed the meaning, and called it "King Aggery taxing the people." We expect to give more information by our next, if the town of Cape Coast by that time is not bombarded. However, King Aggery is true blood of the late King Joe Aggery—his own son. Quashie Attah's parent was servant to this present King Aggery's grandfather—he is no Royal blood at whatever. More shall be explained in our next.

Of course the English Government is wanted to remain here to unite us together and teach us how to govern ourselves in time to come, and how sad it is that so great a division has been effected through the mismanagement of Colonel Conran and the Governor-General. What a deplorable state Cape Coast is in now! We are now left as orphan children. Now Apollonians are by themselves, Gomoah, Arkankanwassee, Argoonahs, Aifwah Agimacoons, Akims, are by themselves, and all at variance with the Government here; and now the King of Cape Coast is removed to a strange land, and we hear the heavy rumour of Ashantee invasion. Oh, what trouble! what misery! what deplorable confusion!

Oh, Thou Almighty God, the Father of the fatherless, the God of justice; Thou, O Lord, who hatest all liars and deceitful men; O Lord, we commend to thy fatherly goodness thy servants who are afflicted and distressed in mind, body, and estate, that it may please Thee to comfort and relieve them, according to their several necessities, giving them patience under their sufferings, and a happy issue out of all their afflictions!—We are, Sir, your obedient servants,'}, {'id': 1702, 'article_title': 'The Fantee Confederacy', 'full_section_title': 'The Fantee Confederacy', 'last_edit_date': '12-13-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_01_1870#article-5', 'issue_date': '24_01_1870', 'content': 'Sir,—It is not necessary that I should say to you that the Fantee Confederate Government is an established fact. It labours of course under great disadvantages from want of funds, because the Queen's authorities get all the money that is paid for duties. But this does not prevent its becoming of importance. Ashantee messengers have now been sent direct to the confederate kings and chiefs, and I hope this may bring about peace. The Confederate Government has now its national seal, which has been made in first-rate style in England, and will now be used to seal all documents. The body of the seal is an elephant standing against an oil palm-tree, encircled by the letters, "The Government of the Fantee Confederacy, Mankessim." Since the Accras have now become one with the Fantees, I hope the time will soon arrive that another seal may have the words, "The Government of the Fantee and Accra Confederacy." The change of territories brought about fearful hostile disturbances to the Coast. The kings felt sure it would be so, and would encourage our old enemies to hostilities from the side of Elmina; so they forwarded petition after petition to the Imperial Government against it; but they treated the petitions with contempt, and took no notice of them, and so the Elminas and their allies have now been able to invite the Ashantees to assist them by the way of Elmina. The Government of the Fantee Confederacy being determined to drive them out of their territories has quickly mustered troops and moved them up to that part. It would be doing something really good if the Queen's Government would get the Dutch to leave the Coast, so that the native Government might be established under British counsel and advice. Mr. Ussher, soon after he arrived, sent for the President of the Confederacy, and said he would give any advice or assistance that might be required, and sent his good wishes to the kings and chiefs of the newly-formed Government. The Fantee Government is, I believe, in daily communication with the Accras.'}, {'id': 2947, 'article_title': 'West African News, Per Bonny', 'full_section_title': 'West African News, Per Bonny', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1875#article-0', 'issue_date': '01_10_1875', 'content': 'At Cameroons trade was very bad, owing to low prices, the interior traders holding back their produce; some have stopped trading, awaiting advance in prices.

The natives have declared war against the settlement of Cape Palmas. An attack was to be made on the night of the 27th of August (date of sailing). Trade was entirely stopped, and women and children, as far as possible, had been sent away in craft, the only resource, the natives having surrounded the settlement landward.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'CAPE COAST GOVERNMENT.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The complaints from the protected territories are great and many. Our letters teem with them. Those we have inserted may be received as a fair specimen. The _quasi_-abandonment of the eastern districts, except for purposes of taxation—the ignoring of chiefs and kings in the matter of peace negotiations with Ashantee, while at the same time we signify that we do not feel bound in any way to protect the protected territories from hostile inroad or internal commotion, or to afford any protection to our traders at a distance beyond fifteen miles from Cape Coast Castle, or other military tax-collecting stations—the assuming the sole administration of justice while taking no measures to make that administration effective and respected, figure prominently among those complaints. The fact is, that we are trying a new experiment (if it deserves even such a name) in government on the Gold Coast, as a means of carrying out the recommendations of the House of Commons Committee of 1865. Economy the most rigid is the professed order of the day; Christian civilisation is to be promoted free of cost to Christian and civilised England. People whom many among us profess to believe are scarcely better than apes, are to do what none of the proud races of the world did—i.e., elevate and purify themselves; impelled only by the brilliant examples afforded by a few military officers and mercantile agents. We have come, indeed, to as near an abandonment of the protected territories as we could possibly arrive at without quitting them altogether. We pity the Governor, or Administrator, as he is now called, who is placed by the Colonial-office in so brilliant a position. All tongues and pens have praised Colonel Conran for what he has effected at Cape Coast Town, previously poisoned in its atmosphere by every conceivable filthiness; and we believe he has done all that man could do, _consistently with orders from home_, for the wellbeing of the protectorate. But it is evident he is so fettered that it is difficult, if not impossible, for him to maintain the dignity of his responsible office. To this, and to nothing else, we attribute the inconsistencies exposed by our able correspondents. The Administrator could not humble himself and his Government so much as to say to the clamouring merchants and kings at Accra, "I am altogether powerless to protect you," and so he had no alternative but to do a little bombast, and trust to the chapter of accidents. The latter going against him, the former is put to the test and shown to be what it is; and he gets sore with those who ruthlessly (because they have been injured, and despoiled, and are suffering) expose the want of agreement between high words and meagre action, and falls into the error of trying by recrimination to improve his position; that of the Government whose servant he is, and of which he is evidently most anxious to support the prestige.', 'last_edit_date': '1866-08-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1866#article-17', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'State of Cape Coast Territory', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—By letters just received from the Gold Coast I regret to observe that the political atmosphere of that unhappy country still gets darker and darker, and is fast approaching that state that, if the present suicidal policy of the Colonial-office towards the colonies and settlements be continued, it must inevitably result in the fearful calamity of an intestine war. The Ashantees, who have long threatened the Fantees, would take advantage of this and march into all parts of the Fantee territory their barbarous hosts and sweep everything before them, and England would again find herself obliged to fight her old enemy under the greatest disadvantage, or abandon for a second time her valuable possessions on that coast.

The Colonial-office is entirely responsible for this state of things, and it is greatly to be wondered at that the Fantees and other neighbouring tribes have not long ere this rebelled against such a miserable mockery of a government as has been imposed upon them ever since the good time of Captain Maclean, and has managed to turn a most loyal and devoted people towards our Queen into the bitterest enemies that have ever acknowledged the English rule. Under his firm but beneficent government the country enjoyed almost uninterrupted peace. Life and property were protected, commerce fostered by the most liberal measures, and, freed from all unjust imports, was far more prosperous than it has ever been since.

My first visit to that country was during his government, and I have known it under nearly every governor since his time, and, from personal observation, can positively affirm that, morally, politically, and physically, it has declined, and in all respects is now in a far worse condition than it was when he was unjustly superseded.

He only received about 4,000l. a year for all the expenses of his government; since then it has cost this country 20,000l. a year.

Such is the difference between the government of a company of merchants and that of the Imperial Colonial office. This will always be the case so long as that office sends out such objectionable men as have of late years been foisted upon the country. Fancy the Queen's representative walking about the English capital settlement on the Coast, smoking a dirty short pipe, in shirt-sleeves up to the elbows! I will write more fully for your next number.—Yours truly,", 'last_edit_date': '1869-12-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/24_01_1870#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.684, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MR. W. A. ROSS ON GOLD COAST AFFAIRS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

Sir,—Under the signature of "Cape Coast," a writer in your paper of the 23rd of September requires to learn of you where I am. I can only say, as Mr. Fechter says in the play of "The Duke's Motto," "I am here."

I must thank "Cape Coast"—and I do so heartily—for his estimation of my skill in unwinding tangled skeins of official thread, but I am sadly afraid that the Secretary of State for the Colonies has at his call more men of high mental attainments and of singular administrative acuteness than my good friend in Africa dreams of; and I am as sadly afraid that the day is far off indeed when I shall be invoked to mend the ways of a Government which is, without exception, the most difficult in the gift of the Crown. Were I as wise as the serpent and as long-suffering as Job, the Government of the Gold Coast would still exhaust my experience, and would overtax my patience too.

I have been provoked to the expression of an opinion. I think, then, that the tangible faults of the Government of the Gold Coast are these:—

1. The changes of the governors are too frequent. The frequency of change is inseparable from the hardness of the labour, if conscientious, and from the doubtfulness of the reward, if ever so fairly won. With every new governor is inaugurated a new code of legislation and administration. One governor lands imbued with a spirit of centralisation, another is moved by the generous convictions of a spirit of decentralisation. One governor establishes municipal corporations, another demolishes them; one founds hospitals, another roots them out. And so this incessant introduction of new devices in the government of the settlements, at a pause of about every eighteen months, brings the Executive sagacity into contempt, and conveys to the minds of the most loyal chiefs a distrust in the power of the Government to entertain and to succeed in the maturing of any definite idea relative to the development of commercial or social reforms. The injunctions of the Government are, therefore, generally treated with indifference; not from a disloyal or refractory motive, but from a suspicion that the wisdom of the Government of to-day may be utterly tabooed by the wisdom of the Government of to-morrow.

2. The Government is faulty by reason of the scandals involved in the miserable squabbles which are always distracting its own officers from their legitimate duties, and by reason of the petty wars which are perpetually festering between the Government and the tribes who live under its flag, and between the tribes whose country is conterminous to the Protectorate.

The palm oil trade has been well-nigh obliterated from the ledgers of the merchants at Accra, on account of the monstrous fine of 8,000l. imposed on the Croboes in 1858, and the trade of Cape Coast has followed suit by being paralysed by our last broil with the Ashantees.', 'last_edit_date': '1868-10-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1868#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Lamentations of Cape Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—Oh what grief, what sorrow of heart, what conflicts we are to encounter! We do not desire to give you long and tedious details of the present deplorable and fearful state of affairs at Cape Coast, but we beg to ask what do the English Government wish to do with our country? and what do they consider the town and people of Cape Coast to be? Do they intend to change the protectorate to a colony? In June, 1865, Lord Stanley said in Parliament that "a native of the Gold Coast in the eye of the law is not a British subject," and if so, how is it that we are in such a deplorable state, living dangerously without any rest, as with enemies rather than friends—enemies who seek to destroy us by taking our own countrymen as tools to deprive us of our rights.

We know that the English Government are wealthy, and do not desire the revenue of a poor country such as this to add to their riches, but certain it is that your officials here are greatly our oppressors. A European, when he was upbraided in gaging palm-oil, said, "Woe to that man who taught you all to know how to read and write!" and officials seem to think the same.

What has become of the arrangements for the interest of this country recommended by the Parliamentary Committee in the year 1865?

Foolish and simple as we are considered to be, we yet understand that only civilization can improve a country; but threats, brute power, and force are not the means to improve a country. The spread of the Word of God, which has now penetrated into the interior of these countries, and which has turned many to embrace the religion of Jesus Christ, is that which would remove difficulties and bring civilization and peace; and how pleasant, how happy would it be if the Christian Government and Christians should pull together in Africa. Good ministers and faithful Christian men will do more good here than 10,000 warriors.

Colonel Conran's acts, we are sorry to say, have destroyed all confidence and faith in the English Government.

Of the fines inflicted on the chiefs of several districts we need not say anything, vide your paper of February, 1867, p. 97.', 'last_edit_date': '1867-04-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1867#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Threatened War with Ashanti', 'section_title': '', 'content': "London, Feb. 7.—Cape Coast Castle, Jan. 23.—An Ambassador from the King of Ashanti has arrived here, and demanded of the Governor the surrender of Ganim, a native chief, who is at present a refugee in the colony. In the event of a refusal, the Ambassador declared that the Colonial Government must take the consequences. The Governor declined to comply with the demand, and has since sent a company of Houssas with three guns to Prahsue. Fighting is reported to be proceeding between the Ashanti and Adansi tribes.

The British and African Steam Navigation Company's steamer Corisco, which arrived at Madeira on Saturday, February 5, brought information of a threatened war with King Mensah of Ashanti. The immediate cause of the outbreak is said to be the refusal of the Governor of Cape Coast Castle to surrender a native chief named Ganim, at present a refugee in the colony. Upon receiving from King Mensah's Ambassador the declaration of his Majesty's intentions, the Governor of Cape Coast Castle acted with considerable promptness in conveying information to the Home Government. The British and African steamer Corisco was chartered to proceed direct to Sierra Leone, without calling at her usual intermediate ports, and having apprised that town, which is the seat of the British Government on the West Coast of Africa, and is a depôt for a military force, to go on direct to Madeira without stopping at Teneriffe or Grand Canary, as is done in the usual course. By this means the intelligence was received at Madeira, and was telegraphed to England six days earlier than would have been the case had the Corisco been left to pursue her voyage under ordinary conditions.

The Corisco also brings news that, acting upon the information received from Cape Coast Castle, the Governor of Sierra Leone at once dispatched by the mail steamer Cameroon, also belonging to the British and African Company, a body of 250 men of the 2nd West India Regiment, which rendered excellent service during the late Ashanti war.

The forces at Cape Coast Castle consist mainly of Houssas, these being natives of superior education and discipline, who ordinarily fulfil the duties of military police, and whose valour in the field during the last war was repeatedly displayed. The Cameroon left on the 29th January, and proceeding direct, would reach Cape Coast in about four days' time, so that the threatened colony would be relieved on the 2nd inst., before which time it is hardly likely that any actual outbreak can have occurred.", 'last_edit_date': '1881-02-07', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.702, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Universal Disturbance', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"The world at large presents nowhere a scene of perfect calm. A desperate war is ravaging the richest region of South America. The South Seas are perturbed with anxieties and desires concerning New Guinea and the New Hebrides. Asia has its Tonquin question in the south, and throngs of other questions in the west and north. Europe is overridden with armies and with difficulties, civil, religious, and international. But any who love to fish in troubled waters may be recommended to turn their thoughts to Africa in preference to all. Africa riots in questions of every sorts and to suit every taste. Spain has its eyes upon new possessions in Morocco. France, besides its latest preoccupation with Madagascar, remains busy with Tunis, and has not made up its mind about Tripoli. A British army holds half of Egypt, and a religious war engages the rest. Abyssinia is so habituated to anarchy that itself and its neighbours are scarcely conscious of agitations which are as violent as ever. On the West Coast every few months the British public hears that it has been warring with negro tribes and desolating their homes in the interests of civilization and commerce. A new element of curiosity and excitement may at any moment be now anticipated from the contiguity of Mr. Stanley and M. de Brazza. Mr. Stanley, it is announced, has been instructed by the Association which commissions him to be as friendly towards M. de Brazza as is compatible with the defence of its territory against trespassers and a protest against annexation. Mr. Stanley's acquaintances will know how he is likely to interpret those liberal instructions. It will be surprising if an iron will like his and a fiery ambition like M. de Brazza's find the Congo or an entire continent sufficiently spacious to contain both. In North Africa and in the central west various white races share the duty of preserving the country from stagnating in peace. In the south the European ingredient is less multifarious. It is not at all less proficient in the art of setting itself and its native neighbours by the ears. The Cape Government enjoys a profuse choice of subjects for solicitude and controversy. Basutoland has not ceased to be a care because the colony has determined to wash its hands of the glory and cost of its custody. All its chiefs are proposing to fight, and they are too close to the colonial borders for Cape colonists to look on with composure at the conflict. The Pondos are as restless as the Basutos, with the additional vexation that when they are not fighting one another they are lifting the cattle of white farmers across the frontier. In the interior a multitude of critics are inclined to scrutinize suspiciously the new policy towards the Basutos. The Transvaal has its hands still full of contentions with Caffres within and without. It wants British money, and it wants to curtail the little British influence the Convention allowed. On the southeast coast, Natal, according to its custom, is equally uneasy and unable to decide on the precise form the remedy for its grievances should take. Hardly a section of African soil, north and south, and east and west, is without its vexations and feuds, in which Europe is obliged to interest itself, and of which the telegraph is compelled to attempt to chronicle the shadowy stages. A predominant sentiment of Englishmen at home, as they read these fragments of obscure African news, must be a desire either to know more or nothing, to be able to intervene with effect or not at all. On the Congo it is pleasant to feel that Mr. Stanley may be left to himself. He is not an English subject; and his enterprise, however sincere the sympathy of Englishmen with its objects, is not an English enterprise. Yet even on the Congo England has considerable mercantile interests at stake, and owns corresponding rights which it cannot surrender or suffer to be trampled on. Higher up, on the Gold Coast, its powers are larger, and it exerts them more amply. There would be a satisfaction in knowing the principles on which the periodical shelling of negro villages for offences against English trade proceeds, and whether the Colonial Office have a policy in relation to such matters, and what it is. On the Gold Coast there is nobody to interfere with England, and English supremacy, it may be suspected, is used at times somewhat too vigorously. In Egypt it might be wished on behalf of Egypt itself that it were used more masterfully than at present. Europe regards England as responsible for the health of Egypt; and England hesitates to assume the prerogatives which that responsibility implies. South African embarrassments permit an easier remedy, with a diminution instead of an increase of the burdens of empire. England often finds imperial responsibilities heavy without being free to abdicate them.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1883#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.695, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Petition to Colonel Harley for the Defence of Cape Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'To His Excellency Colonel R. W. Harley, C.B., Administrator-in-Chief of H.M.'s Forts and Settlements upon the West Coast of Africa, &c., &c., &c., Cape Coast Castle.

The Petition of the undersigned ladies, merchants, agents, traders, and the inhabitants of Cape Coast and the vicinity thereof,

Humbly sheweth—

That your petitioners are daily becoming more anxious at the rapid approach of the invading army of Ashantis, and that their alarm is not diminished by the utter absence of any precautionary or defensive measures to oppose by any organized effort their actual entry into this town.

That, inasmuch as the utter defeat and rout of the allied forces has, on almost every occasion, been the result of an engagement with the army of the King of Ashanti; as the army of the invaders has on every occasion been enabled to advance further into the so-called "British Protected Territories;" as they are now nearer to the seat of this Government by many miles than they have been at any period of this war; and as there is now a smaller and more demoralized force opposing them than any one with whom they have formerly been brought into contact,—your petitioners respectfully submit that no obstacle of any moment really opposes an entry into this town by them at any hour of the day or night when they see fit and feel prepared to make an organized attack.

Your petitioners, who are all resident upon this coast, and who have had more experience than any of Her Majesty's officials here can possibly possess, are far from having that "feeling of complete security" which your Excellency assures the Colonial office, is felt here and along the coast; in fact, no such thing as "confidence" either has or has had any existence, as your Excellency puts it, either "here or along the coast," from the commencement of the present invasion, a proof of which may be readily found in the speedy concurrence of several residents residing within a mile of the Castle to remove themselves and their effects into the immediate vicinity thereof, at the suggestion of your Excellency's Special Commissioner.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-05-30', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_06_1873#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.697, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Condition of the Gold Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following letter appeared in a recent number of the *Globe*:

Sir,—As you have before now placed the Gold Coast Colony under obligation by bestowing some attention upon that God-forgotten place, I hope you will find room to publish the following extract from the *Western Echo*, published at Cape Coast, and dated November 18, 1885. It may be of interest to your readers as showing what things are frequently occurring in a British colony which extends nowhere more than 80 miles back from the sea, and which has a Governor with £3,500 a year, a secretary, and four assistant secretaries, to govern less than half a million people, living in a country of only 12,000 square miles:—

"The Accrofuls and Puttooboos, who have always been creating disturbances in their district, had recently a quarrel, which terminated in a fight. On Monday morning, the 9th instant, the Puttooboos caught a native of Accroful, and this man, it is reported, they cruelly treated. They first took him and put him to death. This done, they surrounded the body with knives and cut it into small pieces, scattering the latter subsequently in various parts of their town, and taking the blood of the poor man and sprinkling it over their fetish. The Puttooboos, bent still on mischief, it is reported, then prepared their arms, and marched towards Accroful. Evidently the action of the Puttooboos was the outcome of certain ill-will which they bore towards the Accrofuls, and which, it is believed, was partially occasioned by the action of either the one or the other with respect to flags. Company fights are generally brought about by demonstrations with flags, and it is, perhaps, superfluous to add that those between villages or towns may often trace their origin to the very same source. The Accrofuls, it is stated, were suddenly surprised by the arrival in their village of an armed band of Puttooboos, who, on nearing the village, and seeing people, fired on them. From this account, it would appear that the Puttooboos were in Accroful before the Accrofuls could know that one of their natives had been killed and cut to pieces. The work of arming for a contest did not, however, occupy many minutes, and before the Puttooboos could believe it, their opponents were ready for them. Each party must then have retired to a spot close by, and there butchered one another. The fight commenced at 6 a.m., and lasted till 2 p.m., several being killed and wounded. Meanwhile news of the disturbance reached Cape Coast, and Captain Stewart, the District Commissioner, left with a party of armed police for the scene of hostilities. But the fighting was over. The combatants had scattered. Some Houssas, too, arrived on the scene from Elmina. The District Commissioner only succeeded in bringing to Cape Coast four natives of Puttooboo as prisoners. All the chiefs of that place are said to have escaped."', 'last_edit_date': '1886-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1886#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.685, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Fresh Troubles on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In the Opobo river a still more serious state of affairs exists. King Ja Ja has not only stopped all trade, causing the trading firms there to close their houses, but has endeavoured to prevent the firms from sending their letters through the creeks to the Bonny river to catch the homeward-bound mail steamer. In the diminutive colony in Ambas Bay, annexed by England the year before last, grave discontent prevails at the prospect of its transfer to Germany, without the wishes of the residents being consulted in the least; as a matter of fact, it is directly opposed to them. The Consul came to see the Admiral, in order to endeavour to induce the latter to visit the rivers and land men from the Raleigh when necessary, as he is of opinion that some decisive step of this nature is necessary to put an end to the existing state of affairs and restore the Oil rivers to their normal condition. The Commander-in-Chief has not, however, seen his way to do this. He considers his presence at the Cape of Good Hope of such importance that he has not time to devote a day to visiting the Oil rivers, which are undoubtedly the most important part of his station. He has placed at the disposal of Consul Hewett the Watchful and the Wrangler, and has authorized force being used if considered necessary by the Consul. These two vessels, accordingly, were to leave for the Old Calabar river, meeting there Consul Hewett and Vice-Consul Johnson.

From Cape Coast Castle we learn that recent advices from Ashanti show the country to be in an alarming state. The Becquahs, numbering 15,000 strong, are encamped at Donquassie; whilst their rivals, the Adansis, numbering only 3,000, are at Dumpoassie, within about four hours' march of each other. The Becquahs threaten that unless the Adansis consent to their nomination to the throne of Coomassie, further hostilities will be at once commenced. Meanwhile Captain Firminger, the English Commissioner, has sent a message to the King of Becquah, asking him to wait pending further communication from the Governor; but it is doubtful whether this will have the effect of delaying hostilities. Already the trade with Cape Coast Castle is absolutely closed, and it is feared that if once warlike operations recommence it will be a long time before the trade can be reopened.

The number of troops at the disposal of the Governor of the Gold Coast, in view of these threatened native troubles, is not large, the Gold Coast Colony and Sierra Leone between them only possessing about 800 officers and men of the 1st West India Regiment, besides the local police. There are, however, several war vessels on the station, including the Alecto, Express, Flirt, Racer, Raleigh, Rapid, Rifleman, Watchful, and Wrangler, mostly gunboats, but carrying about 1,500 officers and men.", 'last_edit_date': '1886-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1886#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Cape Coast News', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'His Honour Mr. Parker, Chief Magistrate, has been unwell lately, but is now better.

Although peace is said to have been made by the Governor-General with the Awoonlahs, the war is still raging in the interior, Ajiman of Akim having sent down some of his warriors. This is the Ajiman that caused much of the irritation that culminated in the Ashantee war. As he has put his spoon in the dish, there can be but little hope of peace for some time to come.

Trade dull at Cape Coast. At Accra and Prampram the palm-oil trade is brisk.', 'last_edit_date': '1867-06-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_06_1867#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.691, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Anticipated Native Troubles in the Bight District', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The steamer Sherbro' arrived in the Mersey on Sept. 9th with mails and passengers from the West Coast of Africa. The Sherbro' brings news from the rivers to the 3rd August. Considerable anxiety was felt in Bonny and New Calabar lest the absence of all consular officials from the Bights should lead to a recurrence of the recent disturbances between the chiefs of those places in connexion with the Endelle markets and the Chief Will Braid's opposition to the Consular decision. The dispute was referred to Consul Hewitt when he was last out on the coast, and an award was given which should have been carried into effect last December, under a threat of fine and the presence of an armed vessel to enforce it. In consequence of the absence of Consul Hewitt and the sickness or death of the Vice-Consuls, nothing has been done in the matter. It is reported that the natives of New Calabar are now menacing the Bonny men on their way to and from the Endelle markets, and in such a way as will certainly lead to another of those native wars which are so ruinous to British interests. The treaties recently entered into between these people and Her Majesty's Government expressly forbid their entering upon war without first appealing to the Consular Court for redress of any wrongs; but the consular officials being now in England, this cannot be done, and much harm may occur unless they soon return to their posts.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Conflict of Authorities at Cape Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': "But it is of so much importance to the Gold Coast territories that the British power should be there respected and upheld, that we cannot pass over in silence the contents of the letters alluded to. We gave an account in our last of the installation of the first Christian King of Cape Coast. We published a very praiseworthy speech made by the King. Before his election the royal stool had been for rather a long time vacant. The kingship of Cape Coast—of a town under the very walls of Cape Coast Castle, and within which town (from the time when an influx of troops took place at the Castle during the Ashantee War) the Governor and other civil authorities have been actually residing—was looked upon as a matter of so little consequence, that some of the best English friends of the Gold Coast have been of opinion that no such person ought to be recognised. But the new King seems to have taken his dignity and position and power seriously—to have looked upon them as facts to be asserted, and not mere myths. He has appointed magistrates, one of whom bears the title of Chief Magistrate, and taken other measures for making his rule effective. A conflict of authority was necessarily one of the earliest results. One of the King's magistrates having by artful means got a clerk of a British subject, and said to be himself a British subject, though his family are natives of Cape Coast, within his clutches, refuses to allow him to make a journey on which his master had sent him, and on his disputing the authority which detained him, and asserting his right to leave, orders him to be thrown violently to the ground by some half-dozen of his myrmidons, and there severely flogged. His master, on the facts coming to his knowledge, complained to the Governor, who, as in duty bound, immediately interfered. The King of Cape Coast, however, came forward and took upon himself the responsibility of what had occurred. Communications take place between Governor and King, and the former considers himself treated with so much insolence, that he counsels and authorises the bringing a civil action for damages against the King's magistrate, who had committed the offence. This order of civil action, instead of criminal proceedings, was in itself weakness; but the Governor is reported to have promised that he would insist on the payment of any damages that might be awarded. We cannot enter at length into all the details of interviews between the Governor and his counsellors and the King, in which his Excellency's efforts failed so much, that the Governor, before the King left, informed him, in the name of Her Majesty, that he could no longer recognise him as the King of Cape Coast, and very properly, that he would not allow him to have prisons in Cape Coast Town.

The court gave damages and costs against the King's magistrate, who had refused to appear.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-24', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE GOLD COAST', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Cape Coast Castle, Feb. 19.

The Gamins have attacked Inquansah, a village near Coomassie, and taken many prisoners. The Ashantees, who have been expecting the British to interfere, are now said to be tired of waiting, and to be preparing for war with the Gamins. Trade is nearly entirely suspended. Sir Samuel Rowe, the Governor of the Gold Coast, has gone to Danoe to enquire into the disturbances between the natives and the authorities of that place.', 'last_edit_date': '1882-02-19', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1882#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.697, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Political Troubles on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The British and African steamer Opobo, with mails and passengers from the West Coast of Africa, arrived at Liverpool a short time since. Health on the coast was still unsatisfactory, and trade dull. At Bonny and Opobo there had been no further hostility since the British Consul had held a "palaver," and both peoples were settling down to trade. At Salt Pond trade was at a standstill, owing to fighting going on a few miles from the coast. The trouble was between the tribes in the interior, those on the sea-coast, and the natives known as the "middlemen." Both parties were desirous of direct intercourse, which the "middlemen" natives were doing all they could to prevent. The effect was that business was stopped, and several encounters had taken place. The war in the Ashantee country showed no signs of abatement.

Affairs in the Cameroons are in a very unsatisfactory state. It is said that the natives have boycotted all the whites, and refused to trade with them or supply them with food. No white man can buy a fowl or a bullock, and the natives have barred the way to the fresh water, so that the whites have to depend upon rain for all the water they require. Large numbers of the factories up the river are closed, and the traders are sending their working staffs home. The natives are determined that the German Government shall derive no advantages from the port. They are paying up all the debts they owe to the white traders, but are doing no fresh business. The people on both sides of the river have joined together, and made common cause against the Government. They do not threaten, nor will they fight, but they will not work. Their houses as well as their plantations were all destroyed when the Germans bombarded the town, so that they have nothing to lose. The English traders have had an interview with the Vice-Consul and the German Governor, and unless some compromise is effected, it will only be a question of how long the traders will keep their factories open, as they are losing money daily.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1886#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WEST COAST NEWS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Trade dull in the oil rivers, and no prospects of improvement, complications having taken place among native tribes arising out of a dispute between King Amachree, at New Calabar, and one of his chiefs named Will Braid, which progressed to such a point that on the 12th July the latter, after assembling all his people and collecting his goods, withdrew from the town altogether, and proceeded up the country. Here he took possession of the oil markets, and blockaded the creeks, and by these means put a stop to all traffic. Negotiations were in progress for the settlement of the dispute, but it was feared the outbreak would prove a serious matter; and in the event of hostilities taking place, it was anticipated that they would become general, for in Opobo and Bonny both sides would find sympathisers who would render active assistance. In this case the feud would assume much greater dimensions than the long and tedious warfare which followed Ja-Ja's secession from Bonny under somewhat similar circumstances several years ago.

The surf on the Gold Coast was very heavy, and communication was impossible in many places.

(By Benguela, August 29.)

Acting-Governor Maloney left Lagos on the 24th July in the colonial steamer Gertrude, and proceeded up the river for the purpose of investigating a charge which had been brought against one of the chiefs of capturing and selling the natives for slaves. At Little Popo communication with the shore was interrupted in consequence of a panic amongst the canoe men. Five of their number had been seized and devoured by sharks in one day, and all the rest became terror-stricken, and could not be induced to continue at work. In consequence of this, several steamers had been obliged to proceed without landing their outward cargo or mails. At Addah, a steam launch, belonging to Mr. Rhodes, of Little Popo, was driven ashore and became a total wreck. At Accra, it was ascertained that the native oil dealers had "struck" against the prices offered by the merchants, and rather than accept the reduced rates, had buried their oil and resolved to wait until better times had arrived.

From Sherboro' information was obtained of an expected attack by hostile natives on the town of Bendoo, up the Roquelle River. Preparations for defence were being made. With regard to the disturbances in the Scarcies River, it was learned at Sierra Leone that the threatened attack by natives on the newly-erected British Custom House had not been made.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1879#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Internal conflicts among Yoruba groups, such as those involving Ibadan, Abeokuta, and Ilorin, significantly disrupted trade and economic stability in the region, impeding potential growth and highlighting the interconnectedness with Lagos.
result: The observations from the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that internal conflicts among Yoruba groups, such as those involving Ibadan, Abeokuta, and Ilorin, significantly disrupted trade and economic stability in the region, impeding potential growth and highlighting the interconnectedness with Lagos. The General History of Africa textbook details the collapse of the Old Oyo Empire, which ushered in a period of continuous warfare and insecurity, disrupting coastal trade and encouraging European intervention, thus aligning with the claim of impeded growth. It mentions significant internal conflicts like the Owu War, Ijaye War, and Ekitiparapo War, although it does not specifically connect Ibadan, Abeokuta, and Ilorin to these disruptions or explicitly address their roles in trade instability. The interconnectedness with Lagos is implied through the broader impact on coastal trade. In contrast, The African Times articles provide specific details on how wars and tensions among these groups, including the Egbas and Ibadans, led to the closure of trade routes and hindered the movement of goods, particularly between Lagos and the interior. The blockade of roads and prohibition of trade through key routes like Ikorodu and the river Ogun are highlighted, along with economic consequences such as cowrie scarcity and difficulties for merchants. The articles emphasize Lagos's dependence on trade routes through Abeokuta and Jebu, noting the broader impact on regional growth, including disrupted agriculture and declining exports of cotton and palm oil. Together, these sources illustrate how internal conflicts among Yoruba groups disrupted trade and economic stability, underscoring the region's interconnectedness with Lagos.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides several details that align with the claim regarding internal conflicts among Yoruba groups and their impact on trade and economic stability. The text highlights the collapse of the Old Oyo Empire, which led to a period of continuous warfare and insecurity in the region, disrupting trade along the coast and encouraging European intervention. This aligns with the claim that internal conflicts impeded potential growth. The textbook also mentions the Owu War, Ijaye War, and Ekitiparapo War, which were significant internal conflicts among Yoruba groups, further supporting the claim of disruption. However, the text does not specifically mention Ibadan, Abeokuta, and Ilorin in the context of these conflicts, nor does it explicitly connect these cities to the disruption of trade and economic stability. The interconnectedness with Lagos is implied through the broader impact of warfare on coastal trade, but not directly addressed in relation to these specific Yoruba cities. This difference highlights a gap in the textbook's coverage of the specific claim regarding Ibadan, Abeokuta, and Ilorin's roles in trade disruption.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that internal conflicts among Yoruba groups, such as those involving Ibadan, Abeokuta, and Ilorin, significantly disrupted trade and economic stability in the region. The articles describe how the ongoing wars and tensions between these groups, including the Egbas and Ibadans, led to the closure of trade routes and hindered the movement of goods, particularly between Lagos and the interior. The blockade of roads and the prohibition of trade through key routes like Ikorodu and the river Ogun are highlighted as major impediments to commerce. Additionally, the articles mention the economic consequences of these conflicts, such as the scarcity of cowries, the currency of the region, and the resulting difficulties for merchants and traders. The interconnectedness with Lagos is evident, as the city depended on the trade routes through Abeokuta and Jebu for its economic activities. The articles also note the broader impact of these conflicts on the region's potential growth, with references to the disruption of agricultural pursuits and the decline in the exportation of goods like cotton and palm oil. Overall, the articles align with the claim by illustrating how internal conflicts among Yoruba groups disrupted trade and economic stability, emphasizing the region's interconnectedness with Lagos.
