The British and French foreign ministers, Hoare and Laval, therefore met in Paris on 7 December to devise a new compromise. It had two main principles: first, an 'exchange of territories' whereby Ethiopia would cede to Italy the Ogaden and a large part of Tigre in exchange for a port on either the Red Sea or the Gulf of Aden; second, Italy would be given a 'zone of economic expansion and colonization' in the greater part of Ethiopia south of Addis Ababa; this area was to remain part of Ethiopia, but Italy was to have exclusive economic rights therein. News of this plan, which was a criminal surrender to the condemned aggressor and a total abandonment of the League, leaked to the French press, and created a storm of indignation in many countries, particularly in Britain where Hoare was obliged to resign on 18 December. 118 Ethiopia at the close of 1935 was thus in the forefront of world news and the centre of international excitement and indignation. ' '$^{9}$ A British Foreign Secretary had fallen for what was considered as Britain's betrayal, while in Ethiopia's rugged mountains a powerful Fascist army using the most modern weapons of war, including poison gas, was temporarily halted by the heroism of Ethiopia's relatively poorly-armed warriors.$^{120}$ It was a case of David and Goliath re-enacted in the greatest colonial war ever fought on the continent of Africa. Though the Ethiopian army was soon to be defeated, much fierce fighting lay ahead before the Italians occupied Addis Ababa on 6 May 1936. This was followed by five long years of Italian Fascist usurpation, during four of which the Ethiopian patriots were to fight on alone. 121 The Duce's invasion evoked instant reaction in and around Africa. 122 In August 1935, a group of Africans and persons of African descent in London founded the International African Friends of Abyssinia, whose committee included C. L. R. James of the West Indies, Dr P. McD. Millard of British Guiana, Marcus Garvey's wife Amy Ashwood Garvey, Mohammed Said of Somaliland, and Dr J. B. Danquah of the Gold Coast. The", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.636, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'European partition and conquest of Africa: an overview', 'section_title': 'The partition of Africa and the new imperialism: a review > Global strategy', 'content': 'There is a third school which maintains that the European interest in Africa which gave rise to the Scramble was a matter of global strategy, not economics. The foremost exponents of this view, Ronald Robinson and John Gallagher, who stress the strategic importance of Africa to India for Britain, blame the partition of Africa on the impact of atavistic \'protonationalist\' movements in Africa which threatened the global strategic interests of European nations. These \'romantic, reactionary struggles\' gallant anachronisms in their view - compelled reluctant European states› men, hitherto content to exercise informal paramountcy and moral suasion in Africa, to partition and conquer the continent. Africa was occupied, therefore, not because of what it could offer materially to the Europeans for it was economically worthless - but because it was threatening European interests elsewhere. 18 One primary aim of the psychological theories as well as of their cousins, the diplomatic theories, has been to debunk the notion that the partition of Africa was motivated by economic impulses. But the prestige argument only appears unconvincing when its economic concomitant is eliminated or unduly played down. Hayes, for example, has documented in detail the tariff war which took place between the European nations during the crucial period of the partition. \'$^{9}$ He even concedes that, \'What actually started the economic push into the "Dark Continent" and the sun-baked islands of the Pacific was not so much an overproduction of factory goods in Europe as an under-supply of raw materials\';$^{20}$ and that therefore \'to prevent too much of the world from being ... monopolized by France, Germany, Italy, or any other protectionist power, Great Britain moved mightily to gather the lion\'s share into her own free-trade empire\'. In other words, neomercantilism, once established, had very important consequences for the emergence of imperial rivalries.$^{21}$ And yet, on the very next page, Hayes sets out to argue confidently, as we have seen, against the economic under› pinnings of the new imperialism. H. Brunschwig, too, while positing a non-economic interpretation of French imperialism was faced with the stark economic dimension of empire, and was thus compelled to assign it some role. Thus, while he sees Anglo-Saxon imperialism as economic and philanthropic, that of France is seen as being motivated by prestige. 22 With respect to the global strategy', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Dahomey, Yorubaland, Borgu and Benin in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'The growth of European interest', 'content': "Because the lands and peoples were so interwoven, developments in one part always had effects and implications in other parts. European abolitionists found, for example, that to stop the slave trade and the wars in the interior, they had to reckon not just with the coastal rulers but also with the different power bases in the interior. Both British and French abolitionist missions from different parts of the Lower Guinea coast commonly had to visit Dahomey kings at Agbome in the first half of the century. To mediate in the Dahomey-Yoruba wars, visits had to be arranged to both Abeokuta and Agbome. Similarly, British peace› makers involved in resolving aspects of nineteenth-century Yoruba warfare had to travel virtually throughout the length and breadth of the culture area.\nUnfortunately, the European approach was divisive, tending towards politically structured differentiation. This was already noticeable in the late 1840s and early 1850s. The appointment in 1849 of John Beecroft as British Consul for the Bights of Benin and Bonny (formerly Biafra) signalled the dawn of a new era. British interests came to be specifically protected visà-vis the interest of other European nationals; British interests were also advanced against those of Africans. We have already drawn attention to the penetration of the Benin kingdom from the Niger delta and the resultant whittling down of Benin's trading hinterland to the extent of the eventual abandonment of Ughoton, Benin's traditional port. Further west, suspicion of British political intentions grew in 1851 when Lagos was bombarded by the anti-slave trade squadron.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'European partition and conquest of Africa: an overview', 'section_title': 'The partition of Africa and the new imperialism: a review > The beginnings of the Scramble', 'content': "Although by the end of the third quarter of the nineteenth century, the European powers of France, Britain, Portugal and Germany had acquired commercial interests and were exercising considerable influence in different parts of Africa, their direct political control there was extremely limited. Both Germany and, especially, Britain were able to wield all the influence they wanted, and no statesmen in their right senses would have freely elected to incur the costs, and court the unforeseen contingencies of formal annexation when they could derive the same advantages from informal control. 'Refusals to annex', it has been remarked perceptively, 'are no proof of reluctance to control'.$^{34}$ This explains both the attitudes of Salisbury and Bismarck and indeed of most of the major actors in the partition.\nBut this attitude began to change as a result of three major events which occurred between 1876 and 1880. The first was the new interest which the Duke of Brabant, crowned a constitutional king (Leopold I) of the Belgians in 1865, proclaimed in Africa. This was signified by the so-called Brussels Geographical Conference which he convened in 1876 and which resulted in the setting up of the African International Association and the employment of H. M. Stanley in 1879 to explore the Congos in the name of the Association. These moves culminated in the creation of the Congo Free State, whose recognition by all the great European nations Leopold managed to obtain before the Berlin West African conference had ended its deliberations. 35 The second significant series of events was the activities of Portugal from 1876 onwards. Piqued by the fact that it was invited to the Brussels conference only as an afterthought, Portugal sent out a flurry of expeditions which by 1880 had resulted in the annexation to the Portuguese crown of the practically independent estates of the Afro-Portuguese rulers in Mozambique. So far as the Portuguese and King Leopold were concerned, then, the Scramble was under way by 1876.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.635, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Liberia and Ethiopia, 1880-1914: the survival of two African states', 'section_title': 'European aggression on Liberian and Ethiopian territory, 1880-1914', 'content': 'Both Liberia and Ethiopia had enjoyed more or less amicable relations with the European powers up to 1879. During the period of the Scramble from the 1880s onwards, these relations began to change and both of them were subjected to varying degrees of European imperialist pressures and aggression with contrasting results and consequences.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Politics and nationalism in North-East Africa,', 'section_title': 'Conclusion', 'content': 'In Somalia and the Sudan the nationalist struggle was not yet strong enough to achieve substantial results. But the Egyptian struggle had a demonstrable impact on its neighbours. The seeds of liberation were indeed being sown in the Nile Valley and the Horn of Africa in these inter-war years.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The First World War and its consequences', 'section_title': 'The African challenge to European authority', 'content': 'At a time when the Allied colonial regimes in Africa could least afford trouble in their own backyards, their authority - still only tenuously established in places like southern Ivory Coast, much of Libya, or Karamoja in Uganda - was widely challenged by armed risings and other forms of protest by their subjects. As a result the Allied powers had to divert scarce military resources, needed for fighting the Germans in Africa as well as on the Western Front, to dealing with local revolts. So scarce were these resources, and so widespread the revolts in certain areas such as French West Africa and Libya that the reimposition of European control over the revolted areas had to be delayed until troops became available. Large areas of Haut-SØnØgal-Niger and Dahomey remained out of French control for as long as a year for lack of troops. Thus the French were initially unable to deal with the revolt of 1916 in Dahomeyan Borgu because neighbouring groups - the Somba of Atacora, the Pila Pila of Semere and the Ohori among others - were also in revolt. In Morocco Lyautey, its conquistador, feared that metropolitan instructions to return half his 70000 troops to France and withdraw to the Atlantic coast might lead to revolt. Though he had to release the men, he did not withdraw and managed to avert challenge to his authority. As it was, France had to keep the other 35 000 troops in Morocco throughout the war. In Portuguese East Africa the German invasion inspired Portuguese subjects to take the occasion to overthrow their hated overlords. 31 The causes of the widespread revolts and protest movements that took place during the war varied considerably and were not all directly connected with the war itself. In some cases what were described as revolts were, in effect, as in Libya, just the continuation of primary resistance to European occupation. In many cases the motives for revolt or protest were mixed. There can be no doubt that the visual evidence of the apparent weakening of European authority as represented by the exodus of Euro› peans encouraged those contemplating revolt just as the influx of Europeans, in particular British troops, discouraged it in Egypt.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Niger delta > The western delta', 'content': 'In the nineteenth century, the western delta did not become as important as the eastern delta as a centre for the overseas trade in slaves, palm oil and palm kernels. Thus, in the 1840s there were only two British firms trading at the ports of Bobi and Jakpa followed by three others in the following decade. The first British consul to the Bights of Benin and Bonny in 1849, John Beecroft, settled at Fernando Po, close to the Cameroon coast and the eastern Niger delta. It was only in 1891 that a vice-consul was sent to the inland port of Sapele in the western delta to monitor the penetration of the Nigerian hinterland in this area. By this time, the scramble for African territories had started, and Nana Olomu had to fight to try to stop them. The missionaries followed the flag in the western delta.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Niger delta > The eastern delta', 'content': "The British consuls on the coast tried to use these inter-state wars as a lever to obtain an opening for their own traders and missionaries to move into the hinterland. The consuls served as mediators between the states in the making of peace treaties. Thus, consular-mediated treaties were signed between Bonny and Elem Kalahari (New Calabar) in 1871, Opobo and Bonny in 1873, Bonny and Elem Kalahari in 1879, Elem Kalahari and Okrika in 1871, Nembe and Elem Kalahari in 1871. The inter-state wars did not weaken the resolve of each of the states to keep European traders from encroaching on their spheres of trade or in the maintenance of their sovereignty. The British had clashed with King William Pepple of Bonny as early as 1854, when they exiled him to Fernando Po, Ascension, Sierra Leone and London. They used disturbances caused by local feuds as an excuse. In 1887 they could find no such excuse when they removed Jaja of Opobo for his opposition to direct British trade in the Imo river valley. The rulers of Nembe (Brass), lying on the main Nun estuary of the Niger, were involved in quarrels between exploring and trading British expeditions and local peoples from the 1830s when British citizens got killed or shot at. The final showdown came in 1895, when the Nembe attacked the major depot of the Royal Niger Company at the port of Akassa and destroyed it. This was in protest against the Company's attempt to establish monopoly trade all the way up from Akassa in the delta to Lokoja at the Niger-Benue confluence. Also in 1898, King Ibanichuka of Okrika was seized by the British consul for his refusal to take orders from the new British Protectorate government of Southern Nigeria. King Koko of Nembe managed to escape capture by hiding in remote villages in his kingdom.\nBy the end of the nineteenth century, then, the British had taken over political control of the eastern Niger delta and, for the first two or three decades of the twentieth century, the states could not crown new kings. However, the loss of sovereignty did not mean the final dissolution of these states or their basic cultural and social structures and values.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Cameroon coast and its hinterland 14', 'content': "British interest in the abolition of the slave trade and the establishment of legitimate trade led to treaties and the gradual loss of the sovereignty of the local rulers. Although the treaty of 1833 between Nicolls and King William was rejected, British agents concluded treaties between 1840 and 1844 that provided them with the legal basis for intervention in local politics. Such interventions often involved the use of British gunboats to bully chiefs who violated the terms of these treaties, or to collect trade debts owed to Europeans. In 1852 John Beecroft even presided at the election of a new chief of Akwa Town. Sometimes British intervention and arbitration was invited by local rulers: for example, by King William to establish his authority over Bimbia and Rio del Rey. But the more frequent excuse for British intervention arose from the disputes between European and local traders over the repayment of credit or 'trust'. In 1856, the system of arbitration and settlement of disputes between Africans and Europeans was institutionalized in a Court of Equity established at Duala.\nThe missionaries represented an important element of foreign influence. In 1843, Joseph Merrick, a West Indian mulatto, was sent to Fernando Po by the British Baptist Mission Society. In the same year he established a mission at Bell Town, and in 1844, at Bimbia.$^{21}$ He and his colleagues gradually built churches, schools, carpenters' workshops and, at Bimbia, a printing press. Local opposition was soon aroused by efforts at mass conversion. Conflicts with the missionaries became intensified in the 1850s because of smallpox epidemics, inter-ethnic wars and famines, and the British had to intervene to protect the missionaries and their converts. When the Spanish governor proclaimed Catholicism as the official religion of Fernando Po in 1858, the position of the Baptists became untenable at Clarence. Accordingly, Alfred Saker built a new settlement at Ambas Bay which he named Victoria, in June 1858. But local opposition to the Baptists continued to be high, especially as many of the Anglo-West Indian settlers at Victoria also traded in competition with the Bimbia population.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.641, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The First World War and its consequences', 'section_title': 'The African challenge to European authority', 'content': "The desire to return to a life independent of white rule, that is a return to the status quo ante, comes out clearly in the revolts of the Borgawa and Ohori-Ije in French Dahomey and of various Igbo groups in Owerri province of Nigeria.$^{32}$ To a greater or lesser extent the desire to get rid of the white overlord runs through the majority of revolts against French authority in West Africa. Certainly one of the exacerbating factors in the rising of the Egba in 1918 in Southern Nigeria was the very recent loss of their semi-independent status at the outbreak of the war. In Egypt, the Wafd riots which took place immediately after the war were largely inspired by a desire to shake off the recently imposed British protectorate, which, in its short wartime life of four years, had proved itself excessively ob› noxious to nationalists and fallähtn alike. In Madagascar 500 Malagasy, mainly intellectuals, were arrested at the end of 1915 and accused of 'forming a well-organised secret society with the aim of expelling the French and restoring a Malagasy government'. 33 A major concern of the Allied powers during the war was that Turkey's entry on the German side might encourage dissidence among their Muslim subjects. While Turkey's call to djihäd evoked less response among the subject Muslim populations of Africa than the Allied colonial authorities feared, they were constantly on the alert in case of disaffection among their Muslim subjects and were at great pains to reassure Muslim chiefs and leaders that the Allies were not hostile to Islam. The imposition of martial law and the imprisonment of nationalists in Egypt was partly inspired by fear of a sympathetic response to the Turkish call for djihäd among the Egyptians. The British in Northern Nigeria, which was predominantly Muslim, were very sensitive to the possible impact of Islamic propaganda there, but the community of interest established between the Sultan and emirs of the Sokoto Caliphate and the British ensured the loyalty of the bulk of Northern Nigerian Muslims.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.651, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]

[{'id': 474, 'article_title': 'NAVIGATION OF THE RIVER NIGER.', 'full_section_title': 'NAVIGATION OF THE RIVER NIGER.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1864#article-13', 'issue_date': '23_11_1864', 'content': '* Vide our September Number.

altogether"!! And if our information from Paris be correct, this wise and patriotic gratification of selfish desires will lead to precisely those results—a French possession, and our total exclusion from the Niger—from a river the course of which, to the sea, was first traced by a British subject—from a river our mercantile title to which has been consecrated by the sacrifice of so many valuable lives.'}, {'id': 5000, 'article_title': 'THE AFRICAN INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION.', 'full_section_title': 'THE AFRICAN INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1885#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_01_1885', 'content': 'An official contradiction has been given to the report that the Association is negotiating with an English company for the construction of a railway between the Lower and Upper Congo regions; and that the administrative staff of the Association is composed in great part of Englishmen. The central administration at Brussels is composed exclusively of Belgians, and of the 160 whites employed on the Congo stations, 38 only are English.

M. Jules Ferry is now (January 2nd) engaged in negotiations with a delegate of the King of the Belgians, in relation to the delimitation of the frontiers of the respective territories claimed by France and by the International African Association. Dr. Ballay, the colleague of M. De Brazza, who has been acting for France in conjunction with M. De Courcel at the Berlin Conference, has gone to Paris for the purpose of giving M. Ferry all the necessary information for his guidance.'}, {'id': 6563, 'article_title': 'ENGLISH AND FRENCH DIPLOMACY CONTRASTED', 'full_section_title': 'ENGLISH AND FRENCH DIPLOMACY CONTRASTED', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_05_1895#article-8', 'issue_date': '04_05_1895', 'content': 'The London Herald of Peace & International Arbitration for May, remarks as follows:—**

The recent speech of the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, Sir Edward Grey, in the House of Commons, in which he said that the encroachment of France upon the British sphere of influence on the Upper Nile could not but be regarded by this country as "an unfriendly act," has occasioned considerable uneasiness amongst the friends of Peace, at home and abroad. But it was replied to in an admirable manner and spirit by M. Hanotaux, the Foreign Minister. M. Hanotaux succeeded in cutting the ground from under the feet of the young English Minister, when he showed the inaccurate character of his assumptions, put forth by the latter. For example, in referring to the claims of Egypt in the regions of the Upper Nile and Eastern Africa, he pointed out the obscure geographical limits of the territories, or jurisdictions, in those regions of the respective countries assuming to be concerned. He said: "No one can dream of attaching to delimitations vaguely explained, on unreliable maps, the precise character which the sanction of tradition gives to the frontiers of European States."

*The Times* remarked of M. Hanotaux, on this occasion: "It is a real pleasure to acknowledge the moderation of his tone and his evident desire to avoid anything that might tend to throw obstacles in the way of friendly discussion."

When we consider the importance of maintaining peace between England and France, and the terrible results to both countries in the case of a war between them, it is obvious that wisdom and patriotism alike prescribe the utmost caution and conciliation to the authorities in each nation.

The Press has a vast responsibility. And it is gratifying that the most influential organs of public opinion habitually show a sense of their obligations in this respect. There is, however, more to be desired in the position taken by some of the Paris journals. It is alleged that the conductors of some papers too often wait for pecuniary inducements to influence their pens in behalf of the interests of their own country and of England, and that some even attempt to exact a sort of blackmail. But we hope such insinuations are calumnies, or as applicable only to a few of the least respectable Parisian journalists.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'FRANCE ON THE CONGO', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'French and English possessions and claims elbow one another in many parts of the world. It is almost inevitable that this should sometimes lead to strained relations between the two Powers. This is eminently the case just now in the heart of Africa. The vast basins of the Congo and the Nile are separated from one another by a long and narrow watershed. The valley of the Congo is occupied on the left bank by the Congo Free State, and on the right bank partially by France. The great lakes which constitute the sources of the Nile are mainly in our occupation. The southern boundaries of these spheres of influence were definitely settled some time ago; but their northern extension has been left much more indefinite. They all cross the equator, but it has been an open question how much farther north each of these Powers can go. Have France, the Congo State, and Great Britain equal rights to press forward into this Hinterland, or are their claims mutually exclusive? This was the problem which we attempted to solve a year ago by a treaty with the Congo State. It was in some respects an unsuccessful experiment. A portion of the treaty with which we are not at present concerned offended the Germans, and we had to grant the request of the King of the Belgians to cancel this part of it. The French ignored the treaty altogether, but proceeded to make another treaty on their own account with the King of the Belgians, which fixed the northern limit of the Congo State, and secured for themselves, as far as that State was concerned, a free hand beyond. If they use this free hand to the full they may skirt the northern boundary of the Congo State, cross the watershed of the two great rivers, and drop down into the valley of the Nile. That is what they are said to be now doing. Rumours are afloat of French expeditions, armed with secret instructions, making their way in this direction, with the ultimate intention of seizing some point on the upper waters of the Nile, which we at present regard as being under our sole control.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-05-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_05_1895#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.706, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Sir Charles Dilke on the Scramble for Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"I still hold that the possession of Egypt heavily handicaps our foreign policy, and I should be glad to see us out of the country. That, I believe, is the sincere view both of Lord Salisbury and Mr. Gladstone. It is probable that the unsatisfactory bargain which Lord Salisbury made with Germany when we gave up Heligoland and, at the same time, lost the wasp's waist in Africa, was due to Egyptian complications. The same complications constantly hamper us in dealing with France. The difficulty is that nobody now believes in our sincerity when we talk of coming out, so that it is by no means easy to negotiate a reasonable arrangement. By the way," added Sir Charles, "it is rather amusing of the French to throw the integrity of the Ottoman Empire in our faces. They disregarded it coolly enough when they took Tunis, and the Sultan has never forgiven them."

"In Africa itself the French may do a good deal—until they are stopped. They may, for example, make a dash for Darfur. Captain Monteil is one of the ablest and most energetic of the French colonial officers. He has a large force at his command, and he is certain to go as far as his orders allow him, and perhaps beyond. But the occupation of Darfur is a project that the French Government would not lightly sanction. The province lies just north of the territory which we have leased to the Congo State. It is an old province of Egypt, and Egyptian rights over it have been formally recognised as still existing. The French could get at it by advancing north-east from their present possessions on the Congo. If they reached it, they would find themselves within easy distance of Kordofan on the Nile, and in a direct line to Cairo. But they would also find rather serious European complications—more serious than I think they would care to face. I fancy they already realise that Germany is quite willing to lead them on now and make the pace, and then to leave them in the lurch as soon as matters begin to get serious. With regard to our proper course in Africa, we should do as little as possible in the interior, except where the land is suitable for permanent European settlement, and instead of spending money on speculative annexations we should strengthen the Navy. If we have the command of the sea we have everything. In the event of a great war the whole of Africa, including Egypt and Algeria, and possibly even the Cape, will fall to the Power that commands the sea. It is because that I know that our Navy is not yet as strong as it should be, that I try to discourage in every way I can enterprises that must cost much immediately, and may bring no return.', 'last_edit_date': '1894-07-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_07_1894#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE ON THE CONGO', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We may assume, then, that the nation will support the Foreign Office in the policy it has announced. But that makes it only the more necessary to be satisfied that the claim advanced is founded in right, and justified by its importance. The French papers—for we have no reason yet to suppose that the French Government disputes our claim—allege with truth that we have no treaty with France on this subject. But we have treaties with Germany and Italy, subsequently recognised by the Congo State, in which our claim to control the whole valley of the Nile has been stated and allowed. It is matter of common knowledge for five years past that we have made this claim. French statesmen cannot be ignorant of this, and they have never thought it necessary to protest against it. But there is yet another ground for our position. We are, by the consent of Europe, in occupation of Egypt, and Egypt cannot tolerate a Great Power in possession of the upper waters of the Nile. It is a matter of life and death to her. Herodotus told us long ago that Egypt was the gift of the Nile; and the gift may be recalled by anyone who can place a strong hand on the sources or the upper course of the great river. The responsibility of protecting Egypt carries with it the responsibility of protecting that which gives Egypt its existence. Technically, no doubt, the plea is weakened by the abandonment of the Soudan, which has perhaps ceased thereby to be Egyptian territory—though it might be argued that the abandonment was only a temporary measure occasioned by pressing emergencies. But the practical necessity remains unaltered, and it cannot be denied that France would be doing an "unfriendly act" in coming across Africa to interfere with us. Her statesmen cannot but know that we hold, in Sir E. Grey's carefully corrected words, that "the British and Egyptian spheres of influence together cover the whole of the Nile waterway." With a certain section of French politicians this, indeed, is no objection. They are quite conscious that it would be an "unfriendly act," and for that very reason they wish to do it. They have no desire for themselves to colonise either the Upper Congo or the Upper Nile, but their sole aim—as Mr. Chamberlain quoted from a speech in the French Chamber—has been "to make England feel the harm she is doing us in not keeping her engagements in Egypt, and to show her that we can come up to her elsewhere than in the Mediterranean." That is language which may suit an excited debate, but which cannot be gravely used by any serious statesman; and we trust that French Ministers may take some opportunity of repudiating it. French and English interests rub one another, as we have said, all over the globe. They may require frequent explanation and adjustment, but none of them ought to be enough to bring about the calamity of "unfriendly" relations between two great countries. We have certainly done our part to avert this calamity. Sir E. Grey said with truth that "during the last two years no provocation whatever has come from our side." But, as he added, "something else besides our own effort is necessary, and that is the co-operation of the French Government and the French public." We hope this appeal will not be in vain, and that the grave, moderate, and restrained language in which these matters have been discussed in the House of Commons will find an appropriate echo in the French Chamber.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-05-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_05_1895#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FRANCO-BELGIAN DISPUTE IN CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It appears—if the organs of the French Ministry may be relied upon—that the force which is to leave France this month for Africa, under the command of Captain Monteil, will number when it has joined the contingent of Captain Decazes, now guarding the Ubanghui, about 600 men and 18 or 20 officers. It must be noted that this force, backed up as it will be by two gunboats, several steam launches and lighters for transport purposes, consists, not of raw, undisciplined Native levies, but for the most part of white soldiers of the Foreign Legion and Senegalese tirailleurs, men who besides being well drilled and armed, are inured to the African climate. The officers, too, who have been chosen, are picked men. Captain Monteil is well known for his remarkable voyage, lasting two years and a half, in the course of which he traversed Africa from west to north, beginning at St. Louis and ending at Tripoli, a voyage of which the result has been to increase tenfold French ambition, and to establish, or at any rate to lay the foundation, of French influence in countries where no Frenchman had set foot before. Over and above this fact several of the officers accompanying him have also seen service in Africa. One of them was for many years an active political agent on the Upper Niger; another was with Captain Binger in his lengthy exploration of the Gold and Ivory Coast "hinterlands"; all are men of exceptional merit. When we consider all this; when we are very palpably and unpleasantly made aware of the fierce opposition of France to the Anglo-Belgian agreement; when we are plainly informed of the ambitious schemes she nourished with regard to Africa generally; when her Chauvinists bring home to us with praiseworthy frankness that they intend to use every means in their power to prevent this country from monopolising the course of the Nile, surely it becomes imperative that we should be informed of the ultimate destination of this expedition. But even then, even if we receive binding and definite assurances from the French Government that no advance to the Nile is included in the instructions handed to Captain Monteil, we have still much room for doubt as to whether those instructions will not be exceeded. Former experiences have taught us that when French officers embark on some military enterprise in Africa, and think that by making a great coup they can cover themselves with glory, they will do so, instructions or no instructions, knowing well that no French Ministry is strong enough to convict them for breach of discipline in the teeth of popular admiration. It behoves, then, the Government of this country to watch with the greatest attention the developments of the Franco-Belgian dispute. England cannot remain inactive in the face of the feverish activity displayed by other Powers. France must never be allowed to establish herself on the Nile under pretext of protecting the rights of the Ottoman Empire, or under any other pretext. We are willing to meet her in other ways, as far as our national dignity and our national interests will permit us, but she must clearly understand once and for all that the Nile she must not touch. Meanwhile, how do we stand? What guarantees have we? What line of action are we about to adopt? These are questions to which the people of Great Britain expect an answer, and that promptly, before dilatoriness and vacillation shall have had time to work incalculable injury to interests of which the stupendous future magnitude is, even at this day, but imperfectly realised.—*Pall Mall Gazette.*', 'last_edit_date': '1894-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1894#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The New Agreement between France and the Congo Free State', 'section_title': '', 'content': "As might be expected, the English Press does not take at all kindly to the terms of this new agreement. Apart from the question of feeling induced by the present state of home politics, *The Times* points out that the questions which are now settled have been in dispute between King Leopold and the French Foreign Office for some years, and no doubt it was the publication of the Anglo-Belgian Agreement of May last that brought matters to a crisis and compelled a settlement. It will be well to recall the position taken up by the two disputants. On the one hand, the French Government contended that from the point where the Ubanghi passed south of the 4deg. of north latitude to the 30 deg. of east longitude that parallel was the northern boundary of the Free State. On the other, King Leopold maintained his right to extend his frontiers in any direction where he did not encroach on territory of another European Power. Acting on this view he established posts in the neighbourhood of the Mbomu, an important affluent of the Welle-Ubanghi, which it entered not far from the point where the main Ubanghi stream dipped below the fourth parallel; and also despatched a large force into the valley of the Upper Nile. Against this expedition the British Government protested, and the Congo State was warned that it had invaded territory within the British sphere of influence. As the result of negotiations, the famous agreement of May last was concluded. The storm of indignation which this agreement excited in Paris was such that almost the first act of the new Ministry was to announce that France declined to recognise the validity of the new agreement; and the position taken up in Paris was that it was incompetent for the Congo Free State to extend its boundaries beyond the limits fixed by the General Act of the Berlin Conference, and that the principle involved in the granting of a lease by one Power to another could not be in any way recognised. An examination of the new agreement reveals the fact that the French Government has receded from both these positions. The *thalweg* of the Mbomu, and not the fourth parallel, is now recognised by France as the northern boundary of the Free State to the parting of the Congo and Nile basins, which boundary follows the water-parting to 30°, the eastern limit of the Free State. Beyond 30° the Congo State binds itself not to occupy the leased territory to the north of latitude 5° 30' N. Thus clear France has recognised the right of the Free State to go north of the 4th parallel, and also the principle of leasing to which they at first so strenuously objected. In return for these concessions, the Congo State has renounced its rights to occupy the leased territory to the west of the 30th meridian and north of latitude 5° 30' N. This is practically an undertaking that the Free State will not occupy the Bahr-el-Ghazal and will leave the road to the Nile open north of Lado. It is important to remember, however, that the British Government is in no way a party to the new arrangement. All the agreements under which arrangements between European Powers in Africa have been concluded is that they affect only the rights of the contracting parties and leave untouched the rights of others. We understand that the terms of the agreement between France and the Congo State were submitted to her Majesty's Government; but as we were not a party to it, we could neither approve nor disapprove of its terms. The new agreement, therefore, leaves untouched the question of our rights in the Upper Nile Valley. It cannot detract from the title of a lessor that his lessee does not enter into possession, and our claims on the Upper Nile are precisely what they were before the signature of the latest Franco-Belgian agreement. What that position is has frequently been stated. Germany, Italy, and the Congo State have all recognised the Upper Nile Valley as within the British sphere. France could neither approve nor disapprove of its terms. The new agreement, therefore, leaves untouched the question of our rights in the Upper Nile Valley. It cannot detract from the title of a lessor that his lessee does not enter into possession, and our claims on the Upper Nile are precisely what they were before the signature of the latest Franco-Belgian agreement. What that position is has frequently been stated. Germany, Italy, and the Congo State have all recognised the Upper Nile Valley as within the British sphere.", 'last_edit_date': '1894-08-15', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1894#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.678, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND ENGLAND ON THE NIGER.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It may be asked whether French settlements might not be created in countries on the east of Lake Tchad, outside of the British sphere. This question leads at once to the political benefits to England of the railway. The regions between Bornu and the Nile form the very crater of the active Mohammedan volcano in Africa. Mahdists and Senoussists would soon combine against the advance of the Nazarene. A great military nation such as France could undoubtedly "smash the Mahdi," and occupy those countries, if determined to make the necessary sacrifices; but it would have the constant disadvantage of its only line of communication being a desert railway 2,000 miles in length, menaced by the Tuaric tribes, by the possible hostility of Turkey on its Tripoli flank and by the probable disaffection of its Mussulman subjects in Algeria and Tunis. It needs no demonstration that the success of such a struggle against Islam militant would be of incalculable political advantage to England in its Niger Protectorate, in Egypt and in its East African possessions; but to anticipate having the chestnuts thus pulled out of the fire for us would be to reckon too much on French idealism.

These considerations, however, suggest a collateral and important question. Assuming that my belief is wrong as to the necessary slowness of development in Central African regions, and that the outposts of French settlements advance with rapid strides to our frontiers, ought this to be a subject for our regret? To me there seems but one rational answer. England, too, has a gigantic task before her in developing the 500,000 square miles which fall within her sphere of action in the Niger-Tchad basins. Every new success of France in the work of civilisation in her own sphere would not only encourage us in our labours, but would certainly afford us many new and useful ideas of procedure; while every passing failure—and there must be many—would teach us what to avoid. The two nations are so distinct in their genius and methods that each will have much to learn from the other in the creation of agricultural wealth in these vast regions, where every feature is abnormal and where the experience of colonial expansion elsewhere is of little use. It cannot, indeed, be denied that there would be a tendency to friction on a long and not very clearly marked frontier line in the heart of Africa; but firm administration and friendly diplomacy should easily dispose of this difficulty. In any case it would surely be better to have on our borders a civilised nation, with interlacing interests in many parts of the globe and with much to lose from war, than barbarous, ferocious or anarchical tribes, to attack whom is like cutting water with a sword.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1891#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE POSITION IN EQUATORIAL AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'That it would be regarded as a distinctly unfriendly act by the British Government is obvious, and it is to be hoped that the French Government does not harbour any such design. At present the most advanced French post in the direction of the Egyptian Soudan is at Semio, on the right bank of the Mbomu, due south from Dem Zobeir, the old capital of the Bahr-el-Ghazal when Zobeir Pasha was Egyptian Governor of the province, and the only place still held for the Khalifa. At Semio the French garrison consists of two European officers and 50 black soldiers, and the other French posts on the Mbomu, at Yakoma, Bangasso, and Rafay, are also held by similar small garrisons. The difficulties of transport here are very great, and, although two new steamers are being taken up the river for the purpose of studying the hydrography of the Mobangi and its tributaries, it is doubtful whether they will be ready for the work for fully a year. There has recently been sent up the Congo by the French a small expedition, with a steam launch which it was announced was destined "for Lake Chad," but some doubt has been raised as to the ultimate destination of this launch—a doubt not without justification when the relative positions of the Congo and Lake Chad are borne in mind. There remains, however, this fact—that so far as we know at present no French expedition has as yet found its way into the Bahr-el-Ghazal.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1896#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ENGLAND AND FRANCE IN THE NIGER REGION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The region between Sokoto and Lake Tchad belongs to the kingdom of Bornu, which extends to the north and south, and probably to the east of the lake. The Niger Company have no treaty with Bornu, but a portion of their trade is drawn from that country, which touches the Sokoto territories. Constant communications are maintained between the Company's territories and Kuka (the capital of Bornu, on Lake Tchad) by the numerous native caravans. France draws no trade from Bornu, and it is believed no Frenchman has ever visited it. Bornu is the immediate Hinterland of the existing Niger territories, and is separated from the southernmost point of Algeria or Tunis by more than 1,000 miles of the Sahara. To cede a portion of Bornu to France would prevent the acquisition by the Company of this region, which is necessary to their trade and extension. The new treaty with Borgu prevents any advance by France on the west of the Lower Niger. Indeed, French influence does not extend fifty miles below Sego, on the Upper Niger.

It will be seen that the line from a point on Lake Tchad to Say, on the Niger, would dock the companies of at least one-half of the territories which they claim, their claim being supported by the clearest possible treaties. The statement cannot therefore be taken as representing the real facts of the case. Not only so, but we may rest assured that our Government will do nothing to prevent the future extension of British influence over Bornu, Wadai, and Darfour, as well as the rest of the Egyptian Soudan. Certainly, if France is able to obtain treaty claims over Bornu and Wadai and Kanem, she will be justified in enforcing them. But British enterprise ought not to be excluded from the chance of extending over these desirable Soudan States. French influence has ample room for expansion, even when the extreme claims of the British Company are admitted. The only direction in which the Company can expand is eastward; and to prevent such expansion in the future would be a serious blunder.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1890#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.653, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Anglo-French Situation in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The French Expedition which set out for Nikki from Porto Novo reached that place without meeting with any resistance from the Natives. The report that a conflict had occurred between the British and the French at Nikki is shown to be entirely without foundation.

A representative of Reuter's Agency recently called upon the Governor of the Royal Niger Company, and drew his attention to the grave statements which have appeared in the Temps. Sir George Goldie replied as follows:—", 'last_edit_date': '1897-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1897#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND ENGLAND ON THE NIGER.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'To England, where the cry "What shall we do with our sons?" grows louder every year, the opening up of Central Africa is a pressing necessity; to France, it is the realisation of a great idea. I do not give an opinion on the long-disputed question between the territorial aggrandisement of a nation and the material well-being of the individuals who compose it. France may elect to follow one or other of these principles, but not both; for there, as in other countries, "il faut qu'une porte soit ouverte ou fermée." I have pointed out above the importance in Central Africa of one Abrahamic policy. There is another which seems an essential preliminary to France taking her full share in opening up that continent. She must be fruitful and multiply.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1891#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND GERMANY IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The recent visit of M. Herbette, the French Ambassador at Berlin, to Paris, is connected with the negotiations impending between the two Governments as to the delimitation of their spheres in West Central Africa. For some time past the Germans have been growing dissatisfied on account of the claims made by French travellers to have established relations with the country that lies at the back of the Cameroons, and the return of M. Maistre has brought matters to a head. If the relations of two countries in this district are not to become hopelessly embittered, it is well that some working agreement should be come to, though this will probably be no easy task. When Lieut. Mizon, after his failure to reach Lake Chad from the Benue, turned southwards and crossed the stretch of country between Yola and the Valley of the Sangha, the Germans were inclined to treat very lightly the treaties which he brought back with him. Then followed M. de Brazza's exploration from the Sangha towards Yola—an expedition which gave rise to a good deal of bad blood between the explorers at the time, since Lieut. Mizon's friends alleged that M. de Brazza had pledged his word not to poach on the Lieutenant's preserves, and so frightened the Sultan of Adamawa by an advance from the south. Between them, however, Mizon or de Brazza have drawn a line from the present north-eastern limit of the German boundary at Yola to the French colony of the Congo, and have cut off the Germans from the road to Lake Chad. Maistre has drawn another line behind the Mizon line, and, if these adventurous Frenchmen can make their treaties good, the Germans are cut off from any further expansion towards the interior, and the only Europeans left to dispute the ownership of the regions around Lake Chad will be the French and the British. It is the more desirable that an international arrangement should be come to, as Lieut. Mizon is again in the neighbourhood of Yola on a mission which is as much political as commercial.", 'last_edit_date': '1893-07-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_07_1893#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REPORTED FIGHTING IN THE CONGO.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**REPORTED FIGHTING IN THE CONGO.**

**LISBON, April 16.**—A report is current here that an encounter has taken place between Frenchmen and natives at Ponta Negra, in the Congo territory, in which the latter were the victors.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1883#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The British Protectorate over the West African Oil Rivers', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It seems that the present strained relations between Spain and Germany in respect to the attempt by the latter to take over possession of the Caroline Islands is giving Liverpool African merchants the hint to look at the present condition of the oil rivers in West Africa, which England recently formally took under her protection. The Cameroons river was annexed by Germany because there was no resident actual representative there of the English Government, although the river itself had been regarded on all sides for years past as a British protectorate. At the present moment, it appears, there is no English consul or vice-consul in the West African oil rivers in the vicinity of Bonny, although no fewer than three vice-consuls, and at least one consul, were appointed some six or eight months ago. The consul has been out, as also have been the three vice-consuls, but just now there is not, it is said, even one vice-consul in the river. One of the officials, Consul Blair, recently died after enduring great hardships and exposure whilst on an official visit up the Benin river, and the others, it appears, have been invalided home. The places now present the unusual aspect of being British protectorates without a single British official near them.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND BELGIUM IN AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Uneasiness has lately been felt in Paris lest the troops of France and Belgium, who are in close quarters in West Africa, may drag those States into hot water. These two Powers have been at loggerheads for the last eight years about the interpretation of the Convention of 1885, which determined the boundaries of the Congo Free State. The French contend that under that Convention the whole of the River Licona N'Kundja belongs to France. When it was found that that river was identical with the Oubanghi, King Leopold tried to step out of his agreement. In the following year there was a compromise. Belgium was to hold the left bank and France the right up to the 4th parallel, and beyond that France was to hold the two banks. But fresh disputes arose. The Berlin Conference had admitted the French right of pre-emption to buy the Congo State. King Leopold has now to face a deficit of about £400,000; and so hit upon the device of bequeathing his African territory to Belgium and borrowing of her the money he urgently needs, and what he has spent. M. Ribot disputed the power of King Leopold to thus rid himself of the Congo burden; and the French Minister to Belgium was directed to insist on seeing the Royal testament disposing of the Congo or obtaining a denial of its reported existence. This was as far back as 1890, and during the four years that have passed the settlement of this matter has been postponed from various causes; but things seem now again to be critical. It is clear that the King cannot long go on making pecuniary sacrifices, and that the time is coming when he will either have to evade his agreement, or ask France to purchase the Congo. The French contention is that King Leopold's tenure of the Congo is entirely personal, and thus, as its sovereign, he stands apart from Belgium. He can, therefore, no more bequeath it in return for a financial grant to his European State than to any other Power. But, as his Congo sovereignty is personal, Belgium cannot be made answerable should the King slip from the convention of 1885 and the agreement of 1887.", 'last_edit_date': '1894-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1894#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: The residents of Tamatave were skeptical of French threats but feared that French rule could lead to violence and instability, prompting some to consider relocating to the interior.
result: The claim that the residents of Tamatave were skeptical of French threats and feared that French rule could lead to violence and instability, prompting some to consider relocating to the interior, is supported by observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The General History of Africa describes an Anglo-French naval attack on Tamatave in 1845, which was repulsed by the Malagasy, leading to heightened suspicions and fears of foreign influence. This incident, along with subsequent French demands and military actions, contributed to a sense of instability and threat of violence, reflecting the residents' skepticism and fear. However, the textbook does not explicitly mention relocation as a response to these fears. In contrast, The African Times articles detail the arrival of the French warship Vaudreuil, which caused great excitement and alarm among the native population, indicating skepticism and concern about French intentions. The articles further describe the inhabitants' determination to desert the town and migrate to the interior in the event of a French attack, highlighting their fear of potential violence and instability under French rule. While the articles do not explicitly state skepticism of French threats, the reactions suggest a wariness of French actions. Together, these sources illustrate the residents' apprehension and potential plans to relocate due to fears of French aggression, with the textbook emphasizing skepticism and fear of violence, and the articles highlighting the consideration of relocation.

This incident, along with subsequent French demands and military actions, contributed to a sense of instability and threat of violence. The text also mentions the broader context of French colonial ambitions and the imposition of a protectorate, which likely exacerbated fears of instability. However, the textbook does not explicitly mention residents considering relocation to the interior as a response to these fears. This absence of information about relocation is a notable difference between the claim and the textbook content. Overall, while the textbook supports the notion of skepticism and fear of violence, it does not provide evidence of relocation as a direct response.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that align with the claim regarding the residents of Tamatave's skepticism and fears about French rule. Additionally, the articles describe the inhabitants' determination to desert the town and migrate to the interior in the event of a French attack, highlighting their fear of potential violence and instability under French rule. This aligns with the claim that some residents considered relocating to the interior. However, the articles do not explicitly state that the residents were skeptical of French threats, but the described reactions suggest a wariness of French actions. Overall, the articles support the claim by illustrating the residents' apprehension and potential plans to relocate due to fears of French aggression.
