[{'id': 529, 'article_title': 'Captain Burton and the late Captain Speke Re the Nile Basin', 'full_section_title': 'Captain Burton and the late Captain Speke Re the Nile Basin', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_01_1865', 'content': 'There has been some controversy between Captain Burton and the Standard reviewer. In a letter just published, the latter writes: "Captain Burton says the river Bann flows into and out of Lough Neagh. He is welcome to a discovery which I had already conceded, as far as the names are concerned. But a name is not everything. There is more than one Regent-street in London. If Captain Burton will take the trouble to look at a map of Ireland—the only one I have at hand is Lewis's Atlas of the Counties—he will find that into Lough Neagh there flow the Main, a small 'burn' rising to the south of the town of Antrim, the Six-mile Water, a small stream running into Sandy Bay, another rising near Lurgan, then the Upper Bann, and next the Blackwater, the Ballinderry, and the Moyola. Which of these, I should like to know, would Captain Burton choose for the source of the Lower Bann. Perhaps he will say the longest, perhaps the largest. In neither case, then, will the source be the Upper Bann. What remains but that Lough Neagh is a reservoir for the waters of a large number of mountain streams, and that it overflows into the Lower Bann, and is the real source of that river, in just the same sense that Speke named the Victoria Nyanza as the source of the Nile. Speke never supposed, as I said in my notice of 'The Nile Basin,' that the Victoria Nyanza was a self-creating piece of water. All he meant was—as I understood him—that there was no great river falling into the lake, and that it was the product of a number of small, unknown streams, none of which could be said to be the source of the Nile, any more than any one of the mountain streams running into Lough Neagh can be said to be the source of the Lower Bann.

"Captain Burton says, 'it is curious to find a critic,' &c. No doubt it is very curious that any critic should have the temerity to differ with Captain Burton. It was my lot, however, to disagree on a small point with Captain Speke, and it is now my misfortune to differ on a greater question with his opponent. That opponent is so uniformly courteous to those holding different views—teste his insulting personal allusion to Colonel Rigby, in 'The Nile Basin'—that I ought to feel humbled when I consider how I have dared to disagree with him. The 'Spekeian White Nile' may, indeed, share the fate of the 'Brucian Blue Nile,' but I may be allowed to think it will not be by the Burtonian and M'Queenian arguments that this consummation will be secured. When somebody goes out and brings us facts, to set against Speke's facts, then the name of Speke may go down into the oblivion which Captain Burton desires for it. Meanwhile, even at the close of 1865, there will probably be some people in England who will still have the audacity to think that Captain Speke was a greater geographer than Captain Burton.'}, {'id': 4513, 'article_title': 'MR. H. M. STANLEY AND M. DE BRAZZA.', 'full_section_title': 'MR. H. M. STANLEY AND M. DE BRAZZA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_11_1882', 'content': 'A contemporary had the following paragraph: "M. de Brazza is the French, as Mr. H. M. Stanley is the Belgic lion just now. The former was honoured by the National Union of Commerce and Industry last night in Paris. He is seeking the aid of the French Government in opening up the country on the Congo to commerce, and boasts that he has been the first to plant the French flag in an unexplored country, extending over 6,250 miles from Gaboon to the Portuguese possessions. He alone is powerless to defend the work he has commenced, but he hopes the Government and the great political and financial powers will come to his aid in the undertaking to which he has devoted his life. It goes ill with commerce when it has to rest on bayonets."'}, {'id': 4513, 'article_title': 'MR. H. M. STANLEY AND M. DE BRAZZA.', 'full_section_title': 'MR. H. M. STANLEY AND M. DE BRAZZA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_11_1882', 'content': "M. de Brazza's claims are clearly set forth and (it seems to us) refuted by Mr. Stanley in his speech at the Paris dinner mentioned in another column. Mr. Stanley said that he met with M. de Brazza in 1880 on the Congo, about forty miles from the lower station of the International Association, in a hopeless and poorly-clad condition, with a small following of men. Their appearance was not likely to have made a very great impression on the natives whom he might have met in his wanderings. When de Brazza started out he received 50,000 francs from the French branch of the International Association, 40,000 francs from the Secretary General of the Association at Brussels, and 10,000 francs from the French Ministry of Marine, making 100,000 francs in all. His wanderings measured about 1,080 geographical miles, out of which only 160 miles was new ground; yet his expenses averaged a little more than 74s. per mile. Compared with Livingstone, who journeyed 4,000 miles at a cost of 14s. 6d. per mile, and with Burton and Speke, who marched 1,800 miles at a cost of 29s. a mile, M. de Brazza had no reason to complain that his poverty-stricken appearance was due to the miserably small sum he had received. It was not to be supposed that King Makoko, of the Batiko, north of the Congo, had been so stricken with the genial manner of the great traveller and with admiration for the tri-colour as to strip himself of nine miles of his territory, with its villages and their inhabitants, and to give them to him for the establishment of a French station, in return for nothing more tangible than a promised protection of which King Makoko stood in no need. A few words unintelligible to the King, written on a slip of paper, by de Brazza, composed the deed of this strange transaction, and the surprise of the King could well be imagined if at some future period de Brazza succeeded in inducing his Government to recognise and put the official seal upon his acts. As it was, instead of the spirit of peace and goodwill breathed in this document, Stanley and his companions discovered the spirit of mischief abroad. De Brazza admitted to Stanley that he had been sent out by the same Society, and that the object of their labours was the same; yet after having constructed the Station of Franceville near the confluence of the Pass with the Ogowebay by means of International funds, he claimed it to be French territory. King Makoko had never ceded any territory to de Brazza, nor had ever given him the right to call any portion of the Batiko territory his own. He simply gave him permission to build houses that he might trade. Brazzaville had no existence in fact, and confronting its intended site was Leopoldville, the fourth station of the International Association, for which a substantial ground-rent was paid."}, {'id': 4519, 'article_title': 'MR. H. M. STANLEY AND THE RIVER CONGO.', 'full_section_title': 'MR. H. M. STANLEY AND THE RIVER CONGO.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1882#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_11_1882', 'content': 'Although we have already in type some account given by Mr. Stanley of his operations in opening a practicable land route past the Congo Cataracts to Stanley Pool, yet with our belief in the vast importance of the object achieved, as regards the future progress of civilization and Christianity in Central Africa, we feel it our duty to give the speech of Mr. Stanley at a banquet offered to him by the Stanley Club in Paris. The _modus operandi_, the motives and aims are herein clearly set forth; and we think they ought to go down to posterity in our columns. Mr. Stanley, who was listened to with deep attention and loudly cheered, is reported to have said (in substance) "that he always called the Expedition by another name than that of the African International Association, because at the time he set out in 1879 the funds of the Association were insufficient to meet the heavy expenses likely to be incurred. Funds were solicited by the King of the Belgians, and the new subscribers formed themselves into a body called "Le Comité d'Etudes du Haut Congo." There were about twenty-five gentlemen connected with the enterprise, representing Belgium, Holland, France, and England. Civilising stations were to be established, and capital was furnished to be laid out by the community of whites in such a manner as would most benefit the native inhabitants. The Comité did not seek to be lords of the soil nor rulers of any portions of the land. The first station founded was at Vivi, though not before a substantial consideration had been agreed to be paid monthly to the five chiefs who ruled the districts. This station served as the base of operations. There began the great work of road making. By December, 1880, Isangila, fifty-two miles from Vivi, was reached, and the second station established. Between Isangila and Manyanza, the third station, the distance was seventy-four miles by river, but the stores and implements of the expedition had to be brought by a route two thousand two hundred and twenty-four miles in length. Before arriving at this station, in May, 1881, the severe strain put upon Mr. Stanley told upon his system, and brought him to the verge of death. On his recovery in the early part of July he started for Stanley Pool, along the north bank, being quite ignorant of what de Brazza had done there. After a march of several days Mr. Stanley was met by two negro sailors from the Gaboon, each carrying a French flag. After polite greetings were exchanged he was presented with two papers, one of which was called the Treaty, and the other an order to show hospitality to any white man who might enter the territory supposed by de Brazza to have been given him by Makoko. At Stanley Pool arrangements were made for another station, and by the 1st of February, 1882, a large edifice, ninety-seven feet in length, twenty-four wide, and divided into rooms for the European officers of the station, was completed. The fifth station was made by the beginning of April, and goods sufficient for two years' consumption of the men at the station were stored away. Three hundred and thirty miles from Stanley Pool a lake was discovered, which proved after circumnavigation to be about seventy miles in breadth. On returning from this last excursion, Mr. Stanley was again stricken down with fever, and was reluctantly compelled to abandon the enterprise. He had, however, accomplished more than he had promised, and his success was greater than he had anticipated. He had encountered no hostility, and had every reason to hope that the stations so happily planted in Africa would more than meet the anticipation of all those who were concerned in the enterprise.'}, {'id': 4539, 'article_title': 'ITALY AND AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'ITALY AND AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': '12-06-1883', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1883#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_01_1883', 'content': '## THE CONGO COUNTRIES.

Public attention has of late been frequently called to the subject of the Congo Valley in connection with the much-to-be-regretted antagonism between Mr. Stanley and M. Savorgnan de Brazza as to the occupation of the shores of Stanley Pool. M. de Brazza reached the Upper Congo by the Ogowe route before Mr. Stanley did so, making his way past the cataracts of the Lower Congo. The latter was seeking to open a permanent road, while the other merely made his way through without doing anything of the kind. M. de Brazza claims that the Ogowe route is the easier and the better of the two. As far as we can judge from careful comparison, there is, however, little to choose, either as to time or facility, between the two routes. In virtue of a treaty made with one of the native chiefs, M. de Brazza claims to have annexed three-fourths of the territory around Stanley Pool, and the French Government have ratified the treaty. As he went out, not as a political agent of France, but as a member of the Belgian International Association with which Mr. Stanley is also connected, the latter naturally feels that he ought not to have turned his journey to political account for one particular nation.

Without entering into the rights of this question, we would ask the friends of our Mission to join in praying that this difference between the two leading explorers of the district may not be permitted to cause war and bloodshed on the Congo, or in any way to hinder the progress of the Gospel. Our own Government standing so completely aloof as it does from all interference in the matter, we for our part would be glad to see any good government established in the district which would protect the natives from the oppression of traders, put down tribal wars, and open up the country to commerce and civilization; but that strife or rivalry between white men should lead the poor ignorant natives into fresh dissensions would indeed be deplorable.'}, {'id': 4539, 'article_title': 'ITALY AND AFRICA', 'full_section_title': 'ITALY AND AFRICA', 'last_edit_date': '12-06-1883', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1883#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_01_1883', 'content': '### DE BRAZZA'S EXPEDITION.

**PARIS, Dec. 19.**—The *Telegraphe* announces that the Government will shortly ask for a vote of 800,000 fr. for the expenses of M. de Brazza's mission to Central Africa. M. de Brazza will, it is said, sail almost immediately, accompanied by about ten persons. M. de Brazza was present yesterday at the annual banquet of the Geographical Society of France, at which M. Ferdinand de Lesseps presided. In the course of the evening M. Duveyrier handed a flag to M. de Brazza in the name of the Society. M. de Brazza, in reply, said: "This flag will be in my future explorations a symbol of peace, liberty, and commerce. It will signify protection to the weak, and will ensure respect for all."

**Dec. 13.**—The *Telegraphe* says: "The departure of M. de Brazza appears to be delayed by administrative difficulties raised by the Minister of Marine, who wants to establish the stations on a regular technical footing. The misfortune of this situation is that it favours Mr. Stanley, who has been in the field since November 12."

**Dec. 26.**—It is now stated that the sum to be allowed to M. de Brazza for his expedition will be 1,800,000 fr., or 72,000l. A son of M. de Rochefort has been granted permission to accompany M. de Brazza to Africa.

**Dec. 27.**—The Government has introduced a Bill in the Chamber of Deputies for a credit of 1,275,000 francs on account of M. de Brazza's mission to West Africa. The report of the Committee on the above grant for M. de Brazza's mission states that that gentleman considers it possible to accomplish the exploration of the Upper Congo within a period of two years. M. de Brazza's object is to maintain and secure the position already achieved, by founding eight chief stations, connected with one another by twelve minor stations, which will form a double and uninterrupted route from the Gaboon towards Brazzaville by way of Ogone and Alima, and from the sea by way of Quilimon and Valle Niavi. In order to mark the pacific character of M. de Brazza's mission, it has been decided that it shall be carried out under the patronage of the Ministries for Foreign Affairs and Public Instruction. Towards the 1,275,000 fr.—the total estimated cost of the mission—the Ministry of Marine will only contribute 230,000 fr., a sum which represents the cost of transport.'}, {'id': 4541, 'article_title': 'De Brazza’s Expedition', 'full_section_title': 'De Brazza’s Expedition', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1883#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_01_1883', 'content': 'XPEDITION.

The misfortune of this situation is that it favours Mr. Stanley, who has been in the field since November 12."
