The report of the Committee on the above grant for M. de Brazza's mission states that that gentleman considers it possible to accomplish the exploration of the Upper Congo within a period of two years. M. de Brazza's object is to maintain and secure the position already achieved, by founding eight chief stations, connected with one another by twelve minor stations, which will form a double and uninterrupted route from the Gaboon towards Brazzaville by way of Ogone and Alima, and from the sea by way of Quilimon and Valle Niavi. In order to mark the pacific character of M. de Brazza's mission, it has been decided that it shall be carried out under the patronage of the Ministries for Foreign Affairs and Public Instruction. Towards the 1,275,000 fr.—the total estimated cost of the mission—the Ministry of Marine will only contribute 230,000 fr., a sum which represents the cost of transport.'}, {'id': 4591, 'article_title': 'THE CONGO AND THE ASSOCIATION INTER-NATIONALE.', 'full_section_title': 'THE CONGO AND THE ASSOCIATION INTER-NATIONALE.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_04_1883#article-11', 'issue_date': '02_04_1883', 'content': 'A correspondent writes to us from Brussels: "The departure of M. de Brazza with his Expedition to the Congo, has, if possible, increased the great interest which is always felt here in all that pertains to the exploration and civilization of Central Africa. The latest correspondence received in Brussels from the Congo is dated from the middle of December. Mr. Stanley had already arrived on the coast, and had gone up the river as far as Vivi, the first of the stations founded by the Association Internationale Africaine. His party had been strengthened by 223 natives of Zanzibar, who had just arrived, under the guidance of the Belgian Captain de Cambier, the successful founder, in 1879, of Karema, the first station and habitation of white men on the great Lake Tanganyika. The negroes of the West Coast are so slothful and untrustworthy that Mr. Stanley, who made his first great journey across the continent with an escort of Zanzibaris, has ever since relied upon the assistance of these people in all his more arduous labours, and several hundreds of them have, at great expense, been transported to the Congo by the Association Internationale. At Vivi, the letters state that great preparations were being made for the construction of a railway between the station and the landing stage on the river. The difficulties of transport in this country, where there are no four-footed beasts of burden, are simply enormous. To secure a healthy locality, the station of Vivi was established on an eminence, at some little distance, about three-quarters of a mile from the river; and as it is the great depot for the stores and material of the Expedition, it is proposed to connect it with the river by a small portable tramway on De Cauville's system. The following stations have now been successfully founded—viz., Vivi, Isanghila, Manyanga, Lutété, Stanley Pool, Ibaka Nkotou, and Bolobo. The latter, which is some 700 miles from the mouth of the Congo, has only just been founded, and was reached by the steamer En Avant from Stanley Pool. Four small steamers have been sent out to the Congo, and of these three were already afloat last December, whilst the fourth was in the process of being transported from Manyanga to Leopoldsville, each separate section being necessarily carried on the heads of human bearers. The successful launching of these steamers on the open water above the great falls marks the accomplishment of the first part of the arduous task undertaken by the Association Internationale in their desire to open up the great river to the advance of civilization. The development of the stations which have been founded is naturally a work of time, but already they are becoming centres of civilization, and are exercising a strong and healthy influence on the natives in their neighbourhood. At Vivi, horned cattle, which were unknown in Central Africa, have been successfully introduced, and the great luxury of a supply of fresh milk has been secured to the station. At Leopoldsville special attention has been paid to agriculture, and fairly successful endeavours have been made to introduce the more useful of the European vegetables. Potatoes proved a failure, but cabbages, carrots, and lettuces thrive well, and are a great luxury to the staff of the Expedition, and to the missionaries, who are working under their protection and with their assistance. Mr. Comber, the head of the English Baptist Mission, who had been seriously ill, had, according to the latest accounts, quite recovered his health, and the reports also state that there was no sickness among the members of Mr. Stanley's large staff. So far, in spite of the enormous difficulties which have been encountered, there has been steady progress, and a few months ago even little anxiety was felt on the Congo as to the ultimate complete success of the great enterprise. The news which Mr. Stanley brought from Europe of M. de Brazza's ambitious schemes, and of the apparent probability of the recognition by the British Government of the Portuguese claims, had, however, caused some disquietude. With regard to M. de Brazza, the Expedition consider that the competition with him was of the nature of a race for securing by arrangement with the native chiefs the right of way and the most favourable sites for the necessary stations. In this race M. de Brazza is already distanced. At Bolobo the Association have reached a fertile and populous country far beyond the limits of M. de Brazza's former journey, and, with their men and material already concentrated, they feel confident of being able to advance too rapidly to be overtaken by the French Expedition. Unless M. de Brazza resorts to actual violence, his rivalry is no longer dangerous. The Portuguese pretensions are considered more serious, and if the British Government does not make stringent conditions to ensure free right of way and free trade, as also the security of property which has been purchased from the native chiefs, the labours of the Association Internationale may yet prove abortive, and both Mr. Stanley's expedition and the English missionaries will have to quit the country."'}, {'id': 4606, 'article_title': 'The West Coast of Africa', 'full_section_title': 'The West Coast of Africa', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1883#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_05_1883', 'content': '**THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.**

**THE CONGO.**

**BONNY, March 15 (via Liverpool, per ss. Corisco).**—From information received here, it appears that from Ambriz to Gaboon the whole of the native places are in a most excited state. Mr. Cohen, the English Consul at Loanda, visited Kinsembo in Her Majesty's ship Swallow to inquire into some outrages on English trading factories. The "palaver" resulted in the King of Kinsembo being fined one "custom," or a quarterly tribute paid him by the traders. Ambriz, when the steamer Corisco left, was almost entirely deserted, the merchants and traders making a wholesale exodus. There were but three European trading houses there at latest accounts. Ambriz is under the Portuguese Government, and the Portuguese merchants themselves had all left. It was said that the Portuguese authorities were levying fresh duties and taxes, which made it impossible to do business. It was expected that the merchants would settle at the adjacent northern territories, which at present are neutral.

A Portuguese war vessel was permanently stationed at Banana Creek, the entrance of the Congo, whilst a British war vessel was at Boma, further up the river. The United States Consul at Loanda had gone up the Congo with the object, it was said, of seeing how far American interests were affected by the action of the Portuguese. The American Consul was acting on instructions received from his Government, and his destination was said to be Stanley Pool. From Ambriz to Landana, and from Landana to Gaboon, the greatest excitement prevailed amongst the natives. It was stated that the Portuguese had intended to annex the former territory, whilst the French were to place their officials in possession of all the district from Gaboon down to Landana, the head-quarters being at the last-named place. At each place the chiefs and natives had intimated their firm determination to resist to the utmost any attempt made to take illegal possession of their country. It was therefore feared that if any action of the kind were attempted by the French and Portuguese, the bloodshed would be terrible. The French missionaries had already extended their operations as far as Landana. The arrival of Count Brazza at Gaboon was being anxiously looked for, as the natives were of opinion that he would take aggressive action on behalf of the French.'}, {'id': 4634, 'article_title': 'Lord Mayo on the French Congo Expedition', 'full_section_title': 'Lord Mayo on the French Congo Expedition', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1883#article-12', 'issue_date': '01_06_1883', 'content': 'To those interested in the Congo question and the opening up of that important river for the purpose of trade with the interior of Africa, a telegram saying that hostilities are likely to ensue between De Brazza and Stanley, must rather have startled them. We know that the French gunboat Sagittaire is now in the Congo, and that it is without question that she has been sent to support De Brazza's expedition that started from Bordeaux in March last.

It is difficult to decide what Stanley can do against such a Power as France. There is no doubt now that the Government of that country intend upholding their intrepid explorer, but it is to be greatly deplored in the interests of civilization and commerce that two such Powers should clash, especially when the commerce of the Congo is only in its infancy. If real hostilities ensue the trade that now exists in the river will be seriously affected, and the natives seeing the all-powerful white men fighting against each other will not know who to trust. No doubt many natives are engaged already on both sides to carry out their bloodthirsty intentions.

England, a passive spectator of such a conflict, will, from a trade point of view, be the largest sufferer, and I might humbly suggest that a couple of gunboats in the river would have a very pacifying effect on "les braves Belges" and "la belle France," represented by M. de Brazza and the Sagittaire. It is a great pity now that the world of commerce, who have been made aware of the importance of the trade of the Congo, should be obliged to look on and see trade brought to a standstill, because of the animosity shown to each other by two of the most hardy explorers that this century has seen. If the French Government are really in earnest the Belgian International Association have little prospects for the future and it must remain to this country, as is, indeed, usually the case, to preserve order in the interests of commerce and free trade.'}, {'id': 4686, 'article_title': 'Universal Disturbance', 'full_section_title': 'Universal Disturbance', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1883#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_10_1883', 'content': '

"The world at large presents nowhere a scene of perfect calm. A desperate war is ravaging the richest region of South America. The South Seas are perturbed with anxieties and desires concerning New Guinea and the New Hebrides. Asia has its Tonquin question in the south, and throngs of other questions in the west and north. Europe is overridden with armies and with difficulties, civil, religious, and international. But any who love to fish in troubled waters may be recommended to turn their thoughts to Africa in preference to all. Africa riots in questions of every sorts and to suit every taste. Spain has its eyes upon new possessions in Morocco. France, besides its latest preoccupation with Madagascar, remains busy with Tunis, and has not made up its mind about Tripoli. A British army holds half of Egypt, and a religious war engages the rest. Abyssinia is so habituated to anarchy that itself and its neighbours are scarcely conscious of agitations which are as violent as ever. On the West Coast every few months the British public hears that it has been warring with negro tribes and desolating their homes in the interests of civilization and commerce. A new element of curiosity and excitement may at any moment be now anticipated from the contiguity of Mr. Stanley and M. de Brazza. Mr. Stanley, it is announced, has been instructed by the Association which commissions him to be as friendly towards M. de Brazza as is compatible with the defence of its territory against trespassers and a protest against annexation. Mr. Stanley's acquaintances will know how he is likely to interpret those liberal instructions. It will be surprising if an iron will like his and a fiery ambition like M. de Brazza's find the Congo or an entire continent sufficiently spacious to contain both. In North Africa and in the central west various white races share the duty of preserving the country from stagnating in peace. In the south the European ingredient is less multifarious. It is not at all less proficient in the art of setting itself and its native neighbours by the ears. The Cape Government enjoys a profuse choice of subjects for solicitude and controversy. Basutoland has not ceased to be a care because the colony has determined to wash its hands of the glory and cost of its custody. All its chiefs are proposing to fight, and they are too close to the colonial borders for Cape colonists to look on with composure at the conflict. The Pondos are as restless as the Basutos, with the additional vexation that when they are not fighting one another they are lifting the cattle of white farmers across the frontier. In the interior a multitude of critics are inclined to scrutinize suspiciously the new policy towards the Basutos. The Transvaal has its hands still full of contentions with Caffres within and without. It wants British money, and it wants to curtail the little British influence the Convention allowed. On the southeast coast, Natal, according to its custom, is equally uneasy and unable to decide on the precise form the remedy for its grievances should take. Hardly a section of African soil, north and south, and east and west, is without its vexations and feuds, in which Europe is obliged to interest itself, and of which the telegraph is compelled to attempt to chronicle the shadowy stages. A predominant sentiment of Englishmen at home, as they read these fragments of obscure African news, must be a desire either to know more or nothing, to be able to intervene with effect or not at all. On the Congo it is pleasant to feel that Mr. Stanley may be left to himself. He is not an English subject; and his enterprise, however sincere the sympathy of Englishmen with its objects, is not an English enterprise. Yet even on the Congo England has considerable mercantile interests at stake, and owns corresponding rights which it cannot surrender or suffer to be trampled on. Higher up, on the Gold Coast, its powers are larger, and it exerts them more amply. There would be a satisfaction in knowing the principles on which the periodical shelling of negro villages for offences against English trade proceeds, and whether the Colonial Office have a policy in relation to such matters, and what it is. On the Gold Coast there is nobody to interfere with England, and English supremacy, it may be suspected, is used at times somewhat too vigorously. In Egypt it might be wished on behalf of Egypt itself that it were used more masterfully than at present. Europe regards England as responsible for the health of Egypt; and England hesitates to assume the prerogatives which that responsibility implies. South African embarrassments permit an easier remedy, with a diminution instead of an increase of the burdens of empire. England often finds imperial responsibilities heavy without being free to abdicate them.'}, {'id': 4711, 'article_title': 'THE CONGO', 'full_section_title': 'THE CONGO', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1883#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_11_1883', 'content': 'have ever since his return given him their assistance in the heartiest and most friendly manner. The King still looks favourably on his enterprise, and thanks to the careful avoidance of political intriguing by the expedition, all complications have been avoided. Twelve stations extending from the coast along the Quillo, or Kivilu, to Stanley Pool, and thence doubling back along the Congo to Manyanga(?) and Vivi have been established, and two whites left in charge at each station. A magnificent country has thus been opened up to commerce, and the ground so entirely cut from under the feet of poor long-suffering M. de Brazza that his journey to Africa will, I am informed, have been a mere promenade militaire, harmless enough, except to such of his followers as may have their lives affected by the climate, but with no practical results whatever, and not even the compensation of cheap glory. "Up to the present," says Lieutenant Van de Velde, "he has done nothing. He can and will do nothing, at all events in the direction of Stanley Pool, however long he may remain in Africa.

When Lieutenant Van de Velde left the Congo, M. de Brazza, accompanied by twelve whites, was at the lonely and depressing spot which has been dignified by the name of Franceville. He was meditating an advance to Stanley Pool, but intended only to make a short halt there, and push on as rapidly as he could into the interior. There would not appear to be the remotest danger of a collision, unless in the way of osculation, between the fellow-labourers in the African field. The wind has been fairly taken out of M. de Brazza's sails by the prompt action of his "dear enemy." All he can do will not, according to Lieutenant Van de Velde, undo the work of Stanley, and already he has found it convenient to avail himself in a slight measure of Stanley's assistance. Quite recently, wishing to dispatch an officer (a M. Dolizi or Delizy, I believe) to Stanley Pool, he chose Stanley's route for the journey, and the officer started with Père Augouard, via Vivi, under Stanley's auspices. Several missionary stations founded at Stanley Pool are said by Lieutenant Van de Velde to be prospering, and the King seems to regard them with favour. Among them are the Baptist Mission, placed under the personal protection of Mr. Stanley, the Livingstone Mission, the Mission of the Pères du Saint Esprit de Gabon, and that of Cardinal Lavigerie.

Stanley is still very anxious to have the assistance of a few American officers. "The Congo climate," said Lieutenant Van de Velde to me, "is not nearly so bad as it has been painted. It is only dangerous to those who neglect proper precautions. I did so, and, as you see, I am going home invalided. Stanley never neglects them, and in consequence has not been ill once since he landed."'}, {'id': 4714, 'article_title': 'THE DE BRAZZA EXPEDITION TO THE CONGO', 'full_section_title': 'THE DE BRAZZA EXPEDITION TO THE CONGO', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1883#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_11_1883', 'content': "The *Temps* (October 26) states that M. Dutreuil de Rhins, who accompanied M. Savorgnan de Brazza to the Gaboon, has returned to France. He left M. de Brazza on July 7, and re-descended the river Ogoné, on his way to the coast. He reports that two posts had been established—upon the coast at Loango and upon the river Quillon; at which latter point a rival post has been established by Captain Elliott, a member of Mr. Stanley's expedition. Four other posts had been established along the river Ogoné, and treaties had been signed with the natives in the neighbourhood, by which they undertook to supply the number of boatmen required for service on the river, and also to furnish an escort for the expedition. M. de Brazza intended to establish a fifth post in the country of the Adumas, and so complete a chain of posts from Franceville to the seacoast—a distance of about 500 miles—with a depôt of provisions and men at each of them. Dr. Ballay, M. Jacques de Brazza, a brother of the chief of the expedition, and Sergeant Malarinne had started on an expedition to the country of King Makoko. M. de Brazza himself was about to start to rejoin them after he had taken a number of canoes up the river to Franceville. M. Dutreuil, on his way back to Europe, made a halt at the mouth of the Niger, and he says that he saw 250 Houssas, all armed with repeating rifles, being sent off to join Mr. Stanley; and he adds that Mr. Stanley has under his command 200 whites and 1,600 blacks, while M. de Brazza can dispose of only 86 whites, including the 25 men on board the Olumo, who never go ashore, and 350 blacks. Moreover, as M. de Brazza is obliged to leave two whites and a few blacks at each station he creates, his force is gradually getting smaller."}, {'id': 4736, 'article_title': 'THE RIVER CONGO', 'full_section_title': 'THE RIVER CONGO', 'last_edit_date': '11-03-1883', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1883#article-4', 'issue_date': '01_12_1883', 'content': 'The Portuguese steamer, San Thome, which has arrived here from the West Coast of Africa, brings advices confirming the occupation by the Portuguese of Chi Loango, to the north of latitude 5 deg. 12 min. as far as the River Luisa Loango, and stating that it was effected with the object of more clearly defining by a fluvial boundary the limit of the territories claimed by Portugal. The Luisa Loango flows ten miles south of the French station of Pontanegra. There is no confirmation of the news recently brought by the British and African Company’s steamer Corisco that the French naval commander had sanctioned the occupation of the coast line between the Gaboon and the Congo by M. de Brazza. Intelligence received here from Loanda, dated Oct. 17, says it was reported there that a Portuguese expedition would be despatched to ascertain the best route to the Upper Congo, avoiding the cataracts and rapids in the river. It was supposed that the route would traverse the interior of the province of Angola, near the region of the Quango river.

**Official Gazette** of Angola, on Oct. 11, published a circular from the Governor addressed to the foreign consuls at that place, informing them of the occupation of Chi Loango, and the establishment of Portuguese authority at Kacongo and Massabi. The circular added that to the south of latitude 5 deg. 12 min. the *status quo* would be strictly maintained pending the decision of the Portuguese Government.

**Paris, Nov. 21.**

Intelligence received here from Banana, dated October 18, states that M. de Brazza had arrived at Stanley Pool, after encountering numerous difficulties, alleged to have been placed in his way by Mr. Stanley. It was believed that a conflict would occur between M. de Brazza and Makoko’s successor, who was devoted to Mr. Stanley. The French missionaries had arrived at Stanley Pool. Sir Frederick Goldsmid was at Vivi, and was preparing to return to Europe by the next mail.

**Brussels, Nov. 23.**

It is positively denied here that the African Association desires to conclude an arrangement with England, whereby it would be disembarrassed of its rights of sovereignty on the Congo, and that Baker Pasha is to succeed Mr. Stanley.

We understand that Mr. Stanley is on the point of returning to Europe, owing to certain difficulties which have arisen between himself and the African Association Committee. It seems that Mr. Stanley intends to defend himself in person against the accusations brought against him of indiscretion and impatience in his dealing with the natives.'}, {'id': 4781, 'article_title': 'SOUTH-WEST AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'SOUTH-WEST AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1884#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_02_1884', 'content': "The African Steamship Company's royal mail steamer Benguela, Captain Charles Brown, arrived in the Mersey on Tuesday, January 22, with mails and passengers from South-west Africa. Amongst the passengers by the Benguela were Mr. E. Delmar Morgan and Dr. Leslie, who came from the Congo. Both these gentlemen went out about the middle of last year with Sir Frederick Goldsmid, who, unfortunately, had to return to England rather suddenly through being attacked with fever. Dr. Leslie and Mr. Morgan embarked on board the Benguela on December 17, up to which time no advice had been received from Mr. Stanley for several months. The explorer was, however, at Stanley Falls, which are some 1,850 miles up the river. Mr. Morgan and Dr. Leslie did not go further than Stanley Pool, which is about 350 miles from the mouth of the Congo. A number of Houssa troops had been sent up to Stanley, whilst others had accompanied him during his journey. These troops are being recruited on the West Coast by Captain Lonsdale, and are not, as has been stated, for the purpose of fighting De Brazza, but to strengthen Stanley's hands in case of attack by the tribes in the region he is now penetrating. It is stated that in this district slavery is very largely carried on, and the Arabs may possibly interfere with Mr. Stanley, as one of the objects of his society is the suppression of the slave-trade. Captain Lonsdale was experiencing some difficulty in obtaining Houssas, as, owing to some disturbance with neighbouring tribes, they have, it is believed, gone out to fight them. The members of the Stanley staff were said to be pretty well. Mr. Phillips, one of Captain Grant Elliot's party, died of apoplexy. De Brazza was reported to be far up the Congo at latest account."}, {'id': 4912, 'article_title': 'THE FRENCH IN MADAGASCAR', 'full_section_title': 'THE FRENCH IN MADAGASCAR', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1884#article-12', 'issue_date': '01_09_1884', 'content': "M. DE BRAZZA.—A French journal, L'Eclaireur, published at Perpignan, has lately contained a series of communications on De Brazza from a former member of his staff. These communications abound with the most extraordinary statements with reference to Mr. Stanley's rival. If one-tenth of these statements are true, and the writer is most precise as to dates and persons and references, then it would be difficult even for a foreigner to regard De Brazza with anything but indignation and contempt. The journal is, we must say, violently Radical and anti-clerical, and regards De Brazza as the creature of the Jesuits and the Monarchists. These statements have only been published within the last few days; it remains to be seen whether De Brazza and his friends will take any action with reference to them.

DEATH OF MRS. J. D. JONES, OF BATHURST.—It is with much regret we learn of the decease of this esteemed lady, which took place on July 14. On the following day her remains were taken from her residence in Bedford-place into Dobson-street Chapel, previous to interment in the cemetery."}, {'id': 4931, 'article_title': 'STANLEY AND DE BRAZZA.', 'full_section_title': 'STANLEY AND DE BRAZZA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1884#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_10_1884', 'content': 'It must be well known to the great majority of our readers that these two great travellers do not work harmoniously. There is a good deal of rivalry—it may be jealousy—between them; and it goes without further remark that the French Press takes up the cudgels for its countryman, and speaks of Mr. Stanley in no very pleasant tone. To such an extent has this been the case lately, that Mr. Stanley has addressed a letter to the Paris office of the *New York Herald*, in which he discusses the dishonest treatment he receives from the French Press, and points out that there is absolutely no ground for the allegations which are so persistently made against him, of treating M. de Brazza with "brutal insults" and "savage provocation." The letter is too long for reproduction here, but we cannot refrain from quoting the last paragraph, which contains some wholesome advice to M. de Brazza especially, and to those busybodies in general who are so fond of finding fault with the successful work of others:—

"With all good-will to M. de Brazza, I tender him my advice to attend to his own duties, and to deserve credit when he returns to Africa, from his country, his friends, and associates. He has a vast territory, which will task his health and his best energies. Let him rest assured that no agent of the Association will interfere with him. We have no ill-will towards him or his work; on the contrary, we wish him the fullest success. Let me call his attention to the tons of stores and machinery that are rotting and spoiling at the mouth of the Ogowe. Let him think of his disturbed route between the Ogowe and Brazzaville; let him perfect his communication between the sea and his stations at Gauchu and the mouth of the Liketi. Meanwhile, let him work as he may for the prosperity of the new territory; the Association will not permit their agents to annoy him, or to throw the slightest obstacle in his path.'}, {'id': 4967, 'article_title': 'The West African Conference', 'full_section_title': 'The West African Conference', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1884#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_12_1884', 'content': "On the 29th, the Committee had a further sitting, lasting for more than four hours, which resulted in the elaboration of the draft declaration.

It is believed that the chief difficulty and danger now lies outside the strict programme of the Conference, whose success chiefly depends on the settlement of the territorial difference between France and the International Association—in other words, the rival claims of Stanley and De Brazza to the whole of the banks of Stanley Pool. At present opinion is in favour of Mr. Stanley's claims, so far at least as the eastern shores of the Lake are concerned, his rights being based on treaties older than those concluded by M. de Brazza. It is very desirable that the Powers assembled in Conference should pronounce some decision on this point, in order to avert serious dangers to Congo commerce. If they do not, the Association is too weak to oppose France, which Power, despite all pretensions to freedom on the Congo, could easily divert trade to the Ogowe, which is excluded from the freedom of the Congo basin. How seriously France regards this question is evident from Baron Lambremont's report that France reserves the recognition of the extension of freedom of trade on the West Coast of Africa to Sette Cama until after the settlement of the territorial differences, although the majority of the other Powers wished to immediately advance the limit to Sette Cama. On this point, as on others, Portugal sided with France. This co-operation between France and Portugal, although checked in its efforts to restrict so far as possible the Congo basin, was again active in the sitting of the Committee mentioned just above, especially during the discussion on the duties useful for meeting expenses necessary to commerce. France and Portugal advocated duties on imports; but England, Belgium, America, and Germany resolutely opposed this, and finally unanimity was attained by a mutual agreement that imports should be completely exempt from customs for a period of about twenty years, when a new decision will be come to, if—Well, twenty years is a long time, where Africa is concerned especially. Meanwhile, moderate dues will be permitted on exports only. At this meeting Mr. Stanley made an interesting statement regarding the religious condition of the Congo territory, and the progress of civilization there since the opening of the river.

*[The Conference was still sitting when we went to press. The conclusion we are, therefore, obliged to hold over to our next issue.]"}, {'id': 6184, 'article_title': 'THE FRENCH IN CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'full_section_title': 'THE FRENCH IN CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_01_1892#article-5', 'issue_date': '04_01_1892', 'content': '*The Eclair* recently published a despatch from its correspondent at Brazzaville, French Congo, announcing that M. de Brazza, the former explorer, and now Governor of the colony, is making preparations for an expedition in the direction of Lake Tchad. *The Eclair* says: "It appears that M. de Brazza has been proceeding with these preparations ever since he was informed of the projects of M. Crampel, whose failure he foresaw on account of the inadequate manner in which his expedition was equipped. For the last two years he has been working in silence, and hopes to reap all the glory of the enterprise for himself. Hence the nature of his preparations, and the opposition he offered to M. Crampel's plan. By various means M. de Brazza has managed to collect enormous quantities of food supplies, medicines, arms, and ammunition on the banks of the Sangha and the Oubanghi. He possesses rails, heavy guns, and portable boats, and he has recruited detachments of 150, 200, and 250 laplots (a sort of native militia of Senegal), whom he has brought by different routes to Brazzaville, where a small army of 1,200 men is now concentrated ready to march on Lake Tchad. Of this number, 600 Senegalese are armed with modern breechloaders. The contingent also contains sixty Europeans. The expedition is provisioned for two years.

In reference to this announcement, the following official note was issued by the French Colonial Office: "A morning paper publishes a series of details respecting M. de Brazza's project of exploration on the Congo which exaggerate the importance of that undertaking. In order to reduce these statements to their proper proportions, it is enough to state that M. de Brazza is now on the march towards the upper reaches of the Sangha, where he will continue the work of exploration commenced by M. Fourcault. His bodyguard consists of only twenty riflemen; but, although he may find it necessary to employ other riflemen and porters, his force will certainly not exceed 200 men. It may also be stated that this fresh expedition is not of a nature to require more extensive provisioning than those of former years.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**CENTRAL AFRICA.**

**THE STATION AT STANLEY POOL.**—The actual point at issue between the Belgian and French rivals who are at work upon Stanley Pool is described in some detail, and with much perspicuity, in a despatch of Mr. A. Cohen to the Foreign Office. Putting out of consideration for the moment any possible political schemes in contemplation by the latter Power, and making the rather daring assumption that nothing more is intended than a mere commercial enterprise, the competition narrows itself down to this: whether the access to the upper river and the interior of the continent shall be obtained by means of the station at the north side of the Pool or by that at the south. Only about eighteen miles of water separate these two settlements; but the difference between them is perhaps as great as between Dover and Calais. "Brazzaville," on the north side, is a place of later establishment, and more remote than the Belgian station, from the recognized route up the Congo river. But then M. de Brazza and his pugnacious following have a means of access to their town through the Gaboon territory, by way of the Egouaii; and if these adventurers organize a regular colony, under military protection, at the Pool, it is supposed by many people that they will divert thither the bulk of the trade to that part of Africa, for the Egouaii has a continuous navigation, uninterrupted by cataracts or falls, which so much detract from the value of the Lower Congo as a trade route. On the other hand, Mr. Stanley, on the part of the Belgian settlers, is attempting to open up new routes along the Killoo and Kacongo rivers, so that he may also have a double means of access to the interior.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1884#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Scramble for Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We need only mention the islands of Fernando Po, Principe, and St. Thomé, as belonging to Portugal. From the Cameroons for 200 miles the coast is occupied by the Banaka tribe, with the native town Batonga, bombarded in March, 1880. This brings us to Corisco Bay, with the small Corisco Island occupied by Spain, to which country, moreover, Stieler's recent map gives a strip of coast to the north of the bay. Here we enter upon the region where France has been so busy in recent years. Under the auspices of De Brazza and other explorers, the French have been not only opening up the interior and tracing out river trade-routes, but been among great stretches of territory as they went. How far their power extends in the interior it would be difficult to say, but by a sweep up the Ogové and down the Alima, they have at least a line of territory ending at Stanley Pool, on the Congo. Between the French territory and the mouth of the Congo, some 350 miles, the coast at present is chiefly occupied by petty native kingdoms, which will doubtless soon be absorbed, probably by France. Along this coast there are several small settlements belonging to various Powers; at Setti Camma are some British factories; at the mouth of the Kevilu are both Dutch and English factories; at Punta Negra is the station recently occupied by the French; at Chinchoxo is a Dutch factory; and just south of the last-named is Landana, which, with the adjoining territory, was placed under Portuguese authority by treaty with the native chiefs in December last. The International Association have established stations at the mouth of the Ruillu that are connected by a regular series with the interior.
[Oct. 1, 1884.]

Upper Congo, while the French have a station at the mouth of the Congo on its northern shore. Up the Congo estuary are factories of various nations, while at Vivi the domain of the International Association begins. But at present the Congo mouth and the coast on each side is debatable if not neutral territory. This is certainly the great prize of all the coast, and no one nation will be allowed to possess it without much protest from the others. It is doubtful, however, if all the four nations interested will be likely to restrain themselves; in the general scramble that has begun we may hear any day of the annexation by some one Power of all the Congo coast.", 'last_edit_date': '1884-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1884#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.635, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Universal Disturbance', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"The world at large presents nowhere a scene of perfect calm. A desperate war is ravaging the richest region of South America. The South Seas are perturbed with anxieties and desires concerning New Guinea and the New Hebrides. Asia has its Tonquin question in the south, and throngs of other questions in the west and north. Europe is overridden with armies and with difficulties, civil, religious, and international. But any who love to fish in troubled waters may be recommended to turn their thoughts to Africa in preference to all. Africa riots in questions of every sorts and to suit every taste. Spain has its eyes upon new possessions in Morocco. France, besides its latest preoccupation with Madagascar, remains busy with Tunis, and has not made up its mind about Tripoli. A British army holds half of Egypt, and a religious war engages the rest. Abyssinia is so habituated to anarchy that itself and its neighbours are scarcely conscious of agitations which are as violent as ever. On the West Coast every few months the British public hears that it has been warring with negro tribes and desolating their homes in the interests of civilization and commerce. A new element of curiosity and excitement may at any moment be now anticipated from the contiguity of Mr. Stanley and M. de Brazza. Mr. Stanley, it is announced, has been instructed by the Association which commissions him to be as friendly towards M. de Brazza as is compatible with the defence of its territory against trespassers and a protest against annexation. Mr. Stanley's acquaintances will know how he is likely to interpret those liberal instructions. It will be surprising if an iron will like his and a fiery ambition like M. de Brazza's find the Congo or an entire continent sufficiently spacious to contain both. In North Africa and in the central west various white races share the duty of preserving the country from stagnating in peace. In the south the European ingredient is less multifarious. It is not at all less proficient in the art of setting itself and its native neighbours by the ears. The Cape Government enjoys a profuse choice of subjects for solicitude and controversy. Basutoland has not ceased to be a care because the colony has determined to wash its hands of the glory and cost of its custody. All its chiefs are proposing to fight, and they are too close to the colonial borders for Cape colonists to look on with composure at the conflict. The Pondos are as restless as the Basutos, with the additional vexation that when they are not fighting one another they are lifting the cattle of white farmers across the frontier. In the interior a multitude of critics are inclined to scrutinize suspiciously the new policy towards the Basutos. The Transvaal has its hands still full of contentions with Caffres within and without. It wants British money, and it wants to curtail the little British influence the Convention allowed. On the southeast coast, Natal, according to its custom, is equally uneasy and unable to decide on the precise form the remedy for its grievances should take. Hardly a section of African soil, north and south, and east and west, is without its vexations and feuds, in which Europe is obliged to interest itself, and of which the telegraph is compelled to attempt to chronicle the shadowy stages. A predominant sentiment of Englishmen at home, as they read these fragments of obscure African news, must be a desire either to know more or nothing, to be able to intervene with effect or not at all. On the Congo it is pleasant to feel that Mr. Stanley may be left to himself. He is not an English subject; and his enterprise, however sincere the sympathy of Englishmen with its objects, is not an English enterprise. Yet even on the Congo England has considerable mercantile interests at stake, and owns corresponding rights which it cannot surrender or suffer to be trampled on. Higher up, on the Gold Coast, its powers are larger, and it exerts them more amply. There would be a satisfaction in knowing the principles on which the periodical shelling of negro villages for offences against English trade proceeds, and whether the Colonial Office have a policy in relation to such matters, and what it is. On the Gold Coast there is nobody to interfere with England, and English supremacy, it may be suspected, is used at times somewhat too vigorously. In Egypt it might be wished on behalf of Egypt itself that it were used more masterfully than at present. Europe regards England as responsible for the health of Egypt; and England hesitates to assume the prerogatives which that responsibility implies. South African embarrassments permit an easier remedy, with a diminution instead of an increase of the burdens of empire. England often finds imperial responsibilities heavy without being free to abdicate them.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1883#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICAN EXPLORATION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'If the reports concerning Mr. Stanley's work on the Congo and the prospects of trade with the interior of Central Africa, as a result of the enterprise of the King of the Belgians, have latterly not been very encouraging, there is some reason to believe that Mr. Stanley's rival, M. de Brazza, and his companions are not proving more successful than the agents of the African International Association. This at least may be inferred from an account of the experiences of Henri Rochefort, junior, the eldest son of the editor of the Intransigeant. Young Rochefort (who is only twenty-two years of age), after twelve months' military experience under the French flag in Algeria, obtained permission at the beginning of the current year to accompany the De Brazza Expedition. Of the forty other members of the expedition who left France, only ten are still with their leader; two are dead, and the rest are scattered over the country, entirely broken down in health. Rochefort was attacked with fever as soon as he reached the Congo, and has never since been quite free from it. M. de Brazza appointed him the head of the station at Loango, leaving seventeen Senegalese riflemen under his charge. At first all went well; but the Portuguese are said to have excited the negroes against the mission, and in the end Rochefort and his party had to sustain "a terrible attack." Victory remained with the French commander, but the lives of five of his men were sacrificed. The only other special achievement by Rochefort, apparently, was the rescue of thirty of the wives and as many of the slaves of a defunct native chief. These unfortunates had been condemned to undergo the trial by poison which is one of the rites practised on the death of a native, and which invariably results fatally. Rochefort and his men charged the tribe with the bayonet, but, strange to say, the intended victims, and particularly the women, were absolutely furious with their rescuers. Referring to the hardships endured by the expedition, the Figaro says, the truth is that De Brazza left home without money. The Franco-Italian explorer, it appears, laughs at obstacles, and is so absorbed with "the spirit of conquest" that he thinks neither of meat, drink, nor clothing. The fact that young Rochefort has returned in a state of extreme prostration, coupled with the ominous rumours concerning De Brazza himself which have lately obtained currency, suggests that the narrative from which we have been quoting is not an over-drawn picture of the experiences of the expedition as a whole. The mania for colonial empire which induced the French Chambers to recognize the absurd De Brazza-Makoko treaty seems likely, in this instance at least, to result in a fiasco.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1884#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Two events of the past month are likely to have a lasting influence upon the future of Africa. Perhaps the most important of these is the convention or agreement between Great Britain and Germany, whereby the "sphere of influence" of these two Powers has been clearly defined in regard to territory which has been for a long time the subject of diplomatic dispute, and might have become the occasion of trouble even more serious still. This is a matter the importance of which it is almost impossible to over-estimate.

So long as any Power makes a claim which is considered to be inconsistent with the rights, or fancied rights, of another, not only is there sure to be a considerable amount of friction in the relations of those two Powers, but such a state of things is necessarily very prejudicial to the country concerned, especially when it is only just being opened out to the influences of civilisation. It is for this, among other reasons, that the agreement between Great Britain and Germany will be welcomed by all who are interested in the advance of Africa. With regard to the details of this arrangement, we find that England admits the claim of Germany to...', 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1890#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.627, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Scramble for Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Under this particularly apt and suggestive heading, the _Times_ published a few days ago an eminently opportune and important article. In view of the extreme interest attaching at the present moment to the colonising and annexation movements now animating the African continent from end to end, we venture to reproduce the chief points sketched by our contemporary, despite their length feeling assured that it is only by a full and clear comprehension of the facts as they exist that this country can be aroused to a sense of the dangers that threaten our valuable and promising possessions in this part of the world. A further excuse for this lengthy quotation might, if necessary, be found in the fact that the spirit, if not the letter, of the article in question has underlaid many of the warnings that have been uttered in these columns during the last few months.

Since Germany has joined in the game, there promises (says the _Times_) to be something like a scramble among the three great European nations for the possession of at least the West Coast of Africa. Within the last year annexations and "protections" have been announced with such bewildering rapidity, that we hardly know where we are; no map-maker can keep pace with the swift doings of consuls, naval officers, and "explorers." It may, therefore, be useful to take a running survey of the West Coast of Africa, and see how much of it has been eaten up by the various European Powers engaged in the game, what parts still remain unappropriated, and what is the commercial value of the various annexations.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1884#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Having glanced at African exploration during the past 400 years, the lecturer proceeded to inquire what had been the net outcome of direct and indirect efforts and sacrifices and intercourse between the European and the African. He knew that the impression they had acquired from various sources was that the beneficent results were enormous; but he had been enabled to see for himself the nature of those results and to draw his own conclusions, and he appeared before them to put a pin into the beautiful iridescent bubble which they had blown for themselves with the materials supplied by the ignorant, the interested, the colour-blind, and the hopelessly biassed. Taking a bird's-eye view of the whole situation in time and space, so that each factor might assume its proper relative position and proportion, he unhesitatingly affirmed in the plainest language that so far their intercourse with African races, instead of being a blessing, had been little better than an unmitigated curse to them. These were strong statements, they would say, and required confirmation. If true, what could possibly have caused this frightful miscarriage of the noblest aspirations of a Christian people? The answer was simply the nature of their commerce with Africa in the past and present. To the slave and gin trades, and that in gunpowder and guns, must he ascribed the frightful evils they had brought upon the negro race, beside which the good they had tried to achieve was hardly discernible.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.658, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ITALY AND AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "## ITALY AND AFRICA.

**ROME, Dec. 6.**—The *Gazetta d'Italia*, in a leader on the Queen's Speech, says that it possesses, despite its simple unostentatious form, great political importance. Its simplicity reveals England's fixed purpose of competing with France in Africa, the ostensible object of this rivalry being the extension of trade, its real aim the establishment of an immense African Empire which may one day rival that of India. At the same time, says this journal, Turkey is in a state of anarchy, and signs are visible of the impending destruction of the Ottoman power in Europe. The *Gazetta* asks what Italy will do in view of these complications to guarantee herself from danger and assure herself a future worthy of her past.", 'last_edit_date': '1883-12-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1883#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.659, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN "MIDDLEMAN" AND OTHER HINDRANCES TO TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'After the 1870 war the French, then more intent on healing their wounds at home than on extending their colonies, were desirous of exchanging the Gaboon for the Gambia. Any one who has seen the two places must wonder why we did not accept their offer. The French were then desirous of consolidating their possessions, and for long after our refusal to treat for the exchange the work of exploration by De Brazza starved.

This exploration has led to the addition to the colony of the Gaboon of the countries between it and the Congo, which may soon offer an important field for trade, and probably contain a trade route to the equatorial and northern portion of the Congo, which will compete with that of Mr. Stanley. Our commercial relations with France since the abrogation of the Cobden Treaty have been such that we have been unable to safeguard the interests of our merchants in French possessions beyond the seas, but perhaps nowhere except in the Gaboon have English ships been forced to haul down the English ensign and hoist the tricolour before being allowed to trade in certain territorial waters! The French in the Gaboon have acted on a principle of exclusion, and though a portion of the territory is bound by the Free-trade rules, we may feel certain that the English merchant, though he may legally stand on an equal footing with the French trader, will find that his position is very different, and that many obstacles are put in the way of his competing on equal terms with his rivals. The Congo is now the scene of one of the greatest experiments that has ever been tried in international law. The establishment of trade and the opening of communications cannot be brought about in a few months, and if some of the utopian descriptions we have heard of the thousands and millions of yards of calico which the teeming multitudes of Central Africa will require are to be taken as the basis of calculation in estimating the future trade of these districts, those who accept will be doomed to disappointment.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND ENGLAND ON THE NIGER.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'I must preface this article by two definitions. For want of a better concise name I shall use the vague term "Central Africa" to describe the more or less malarious portion of that continent lying between (say) the eighteenth parallels of north and south latitude, exclusive of the maritime regions within twenty or thirty miles of the seaboard, which can look to European fleets for protection of life and property. Central Africa, thus defined, is about thirty times the area of France, and fifty times that of the United Kingdom, and probably contains about one-twelfth of the population of the globe. In the second place, and for the same reason, I use the word "England" for "Great Britain and Ireland," and "Englishmen" for the inhabitants of this country. "Britain" and "Britons" are, unfortunately, considered pedantic in prose.

The Anglo-German and Anglo-Portuguese agreements of 1890 have induced a colonial movement in France which, in this age of electricity, may be described as a strong secondary current. Competent authorities tell us that this agitation is no longer confined to colonial enthusiasts, but has penetrated into the mass of the nation; and a number of expeditions have lately been despatched from widely separated points of the African coast to extend French rights into the heart of the continent. The inadequate recognition in England of this movement may perhaps be attributed to a well-founded belief on the part of "Our own Correspondents" that the British public has lately had a surfeit of the Dark Continent.

It may seem illogical that the demarcation by other countries of spheres of influence in East and South Africa should affect the estimates which France had previously formed of the value of the regions bordering on her possessions in the north and west of the Continent; but it is not in France alone that the fever of annexation proves contagious. To this cause, principally, may be attributed the popularity of propositions for the immediate occupation of vast areas of Central Africa. Two minor causes have contributed to this movement. The first has been the downfall of the Boulangists, who had opposed colonial adventures; partly, no doubt, from a belief in the necessity of concentrating the forces of France at home, and, perhaps, partly from a desire to oppose any policy which had been adopted by their bête noire. Now M. Ferry, having recognised the hegemony of Germany in Europe, had, during his tenure of power, sought to direct the energies of France to compensations abroad. The reaction against Boulangism has
**19**', 'last_edit_date': '1891-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1891#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Voyage of the Raleigh', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There is a lesson to be learnt from this case, and what has lately happened to the German East African Company in Zanzibar. In both cases the Arab traders were the instigators, though in the latter case they seem to have had matters simplified for them by the action of the German East African and Imperial authorities. If it be true that the German ships have occasionally been guilty of promiscuously shelling the coast, "simply to overawe the natives," we can hardly wonder at the influence obtained by these Arab traders. In the ordinary way there is not much reason for this alliance between the natives and the Arabs—as the intercourse of the latter is generally confined to kidnapping and enslaving the former. But the presence of a common enemy is sure to drive them into alliance together. And let us remember the native mind does not grasp the difference between one European power and another. It is not in the interests of the Arab to enlighten them—on the contrary, it is clearly to his advantage to persuade them that all Europeans are bent upon their destruction. The Arab influence in East Africa is already immense. The chief obstacle to its further development lies in the hostility of the native tribes, who have trusted Europeans in preference, because they found that these have been just and considerate; but according to latest accounts, the Germans seem bent upon changing all this, and forcing the natives to make common cause with the Arabs. Their efforts at peaceful colonisation will surely fail in exact proportion to their success in this enterprise.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-03-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_03_1889#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.629, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH MISRULE IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Probably it will be said that this picture is grossly exaggerated—a mere caricature.* But the fact remains that it is an Englishman who speaks, and thereby condemns his own country for the century of misrule under which Sierra Leone groans. Surely the time has come when these matters should receive the attention they so imperatively demand. There are thousands of native Africans who are in all respects the equals of the most cultured Europeans; and the average West African is not deficient in those qualities the need of which would prevent his governing himself; but subject to the shocking influences which are all around, is it to be wondered at that he sinks to a lower level than his entirely uncivilised neighbour in the far interior?', 'last_edit_date': '1891-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1891#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.631, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'REVIEW.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'As we have often exposed European misconduct in these countries, we may be allowed to quote F.R.G.S. on the same subject: "There are about 100 Europeans in the land; amongst these there are many excellent fellows, but—it is an unpleasant confession to make—the others appear to me inferior to the Africans, native as well as mulatto. The possibility of such a thing had never yet reached my brain. At last, in colloquy with an old friend upon the Coast, the idea started up, and after due discussion, we adopted it. I speak of morals. In intellect the black race is palpably superior, and it is fast advancing in the path of civilization."—Vol. II., p. 73. As the author's almost hatred of Africans is everywhere apparent, this, which would, no doubt, have been "worn-out declamation" from us, may possibly be considered worthy of credit.

The F.R.G.S. carries about with him everywhere "a consul," as closely attached to and as inseparable from him as were the Siamese twins to and from each other, so that we may be excused if we fail at times to distinguish between them. We thank them or him for the testimony "that the land of West Africa might be rendered not more unhealthy than the East or the West Indies," but we do not at all agree with him that even now "it is deadly—a Golgotha—a Jehannum"—except to those who conspire against themselves to make it so to them. The changes proposed with a most admirable aplomb, here, there, and everywhere, are few, if any, of them new to us, and our readers will recognise many that have been indicated in our pages. We must refer them to the work itself, which they will find in many parts very amusing. The following antipodes of our author describes a person such as we have not unfrequently met with in our own peregrinations: "At Accra we left our Spaniard. He was a gentleman fond of his bed and also of his Madeiran wicker-work armchair. He read a little; but when excited, which was rare, he would declaim loudly against the practice of 'lecture,' as worthless touching the main enjoyments of human life—eating, drinking, visiting friends, and attending the theatre. According to him, the summum bonum of human life was to lie upon his back smoking cigarettes and looking at the moon or at all the stars. He once, but only once, gathered energy to sermon me upon the subject of over curiosity. I had remarked that the thermometer stood unusually high. 'To me,' quoth Don, 'it is hot when I am hot; it is cold when my body feels cold. What do I want to know more?'"—Vol. II.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1863#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.637, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Tensions between indigenous populations and the Liberian government were exacerbated by disputes over land claims, export regulations, and the integration of foreign traders.
result: The tensions between indigenous populations and the Liberian government were significantly exacerbated by disputes over land claims, export regulations, and the integration of foreign traders, as detailed in both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The General History of Africa highlights the cleavage between the Americo-Liberians and indigenous Africans, noting the Americo-Liberians' tight political control and restriction of political participation for educated indigenous Africans. This control extended to trade, where the imposition of trade restrictions and levies favored Americo-Liberian merchants, alienating both foreign merchants and indigenous African chiefs, leading to armed resistance from groups like the Vai, Kru, and Grebo. The annexation of Liberian territories by European powers further strained relations, as indigenous groups were discontent with Liberia's trade policies and lack of effective occupation. Similarly, The African Times articles emphasize conflicts over land ownership, with tribes like the Grebo and Settra Kroo rejecting Liberian sovereignty and asserting their ancestral land rights. The imposition of export regulations, requiring produce to be exported through designated ports, led to resistance from native populations, as evidenced by troubles on the Liberian seacoast. The integration of foreign traders also fueled tensions, with hostility towards Sierra Leone merchants and challenges faced by foreigners in conducting business in Liberia. Together, these sources illustrate the complex interplay of land disputes, regulatory impositions, and foreign trade dynamics in exacerbating tensions between the Liberian government and indigenous populations.
gha: The General History of Africa textbook provides several details that support the claim that tensions between indigenous populations and the Liberian government were exacerbated by disputes over land claims, export regulations, and the integration of foreign traders. The text highlights the cleavage between the Americo-Liberians and indigenous Africans, noting that the Americo-Liberians maintained tight political control and restricted the political participation of educated indigenous Africans. The imposition of trade restrictions and levies by the Liberian government, which favored Americo-Liberian merchants, alienated both foreign merchants and indigenous African chiefs, leading to armed resistance from groups like the Vai, Kru, and Grebo. Additionally, the text discusses the annexation of Liberian territories by European powers, such as Britain and France, which further strained relations as indigenous groups were discontent with Liberia's trade policies and lack of effective occupation. The integration of foreign traders and the imposition of export regulations are evident in the government's attempts to control trade through designated ports and the subsequent resistance from both indigenous populations and foreign merchants. These details align with the claim, illustrating how land disputes, export regulations, and foreign trader integration contributed to tensions between the indigenous populations and the Liberian government.
tat: The African Times news articles provide several details that support the claim that tensions between indigenous populations and the Liberian government were exacerbated by disputes over land claims, export regulations, and the integration of foreign traders. The articles highlight conflicts over land ownership, with indigenous tribes like the Grebo and Settra Kroo rejecting Liberian sovereignty and asserting their rights to their ancestral lands, as seen in their resolutions and repudiation of Liberian authority. Additionally, the imposition of export regulations, such as the requirement for all produce to be exported through designated ports, led to resistance from native populations, as mentioned in the troubles with the natives on the Liberian seacoast. The integration of foreign traders also contributed to tensions, with reports of hostility towards Sierra Leone merchants and the challenges faced by foreigners in conducting business in Liberia. These elements collectively illustrate the complex interplay of land disputes, regulatory impositions, and foreign trade dynamics in exacerbating tensions between the Liberian government and indigenous populations.
