Their power was based primarily upon the tribute and plunder which they acquired - especially the herds of cattle and captives, some of which they redistributed to their followers. From an economic perspective, their pre-eminent position closely paralleled that of the surplus-appro› priating aristocracy who governed the neighbouring conquest states and controlled the ivory and slave trade.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.617, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Cross river basin > The Ekpe society and the Bloodmen', 'content': 'The social and political history of Calabar, then, was similar to that of the delta states in the types of external pressures to which the system was subject, but different in the specific internal resolution of the problems. Ekpe, the position of the monarchy, and the Bloodmen, were unique phenomena in the situation at Calabar.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.61, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The countries of the Zambezi basin', 'section_title': 'The impact of the Nguni and Kololo invasions', 'content': "Undi and Lundu. The structure of the Nguni states, and to a lesser degree the Kololo, constituted a substantial departure from earlier political forms. The new polities were smaller in scale, denser in population and appreciably more centralized. Their most distinctive characteristic was the age-regiment, which underpinned the aristocracy's power and facilitated the domination and the incorporation of disparate peoples.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.61, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]
tat_orig:
[{'id': 607, 'article_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst, River Gambia', 'full_section_title': 'A Peep through Bathurst, River Gambia', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-15', 'issue_date': '23_05_1865', 'content': 'The merchants in the Gambia have a season of recreation and a season of work. As soon as the rains commence, very few, if any at all, remain in town. Making their escape from the unhealthy season, most of them are to be found in England and France, and some even in America. The working season commences in November. The merchants, with their families, arriving, make the place gay. A great many vessels are now in port, loading and unloading, and many arrivals and departures. At this time there are a great many festivals, and everyone enjoys himself in right good earnest.

The houses in the Gambia are very substantially built, principally of bricks and stone, containing large and open rooms, and spacious verandahs. The Mandingo huts are the most miserable erections to be seen in any part of the Coast. Low, dark, and of a round shape, with doorways about three feet or less in height, and two in breadth, they are made as if intended that these sons of the Prophet should make their salaam before they even enter their lots. Goats, sheep, and fowls are fellow-inmates in some of these miserable constructions.

Besides the European population, the most influential inhabitants are the free Jollofs, a race of people, whose principal habitation is at Goree and Senegal, and their interiors, and who own most of the principal buildings at Bathurst. Next to these in influence are a few Sierra Leone people; and then comes the Mohammedan population, consisting of Suninkees, Marabouts, and Cereres, the first of whom are the masters of the land.

A promenade has lately been erected by Governor D'Arcy with Teneriffe stone, entirely at his own expense, for the good of the colony. It is called "D'Arcy's Promenade." The idea is very excellent, but the position is most unhappily selected. It is placed in front of the market, where the stench is sufficient to drive away a mere passer-by. The consequence is, that no one

has ever been seen to walk in it. It should be placed abreast the sea, in a spot where ladies could enjoy their evening promenade. I hope this short notice will influence the Governor to remove it from its present unpleasant position to a more convenient spot, or the nuisance which renders it useless.'}, {'id': 701, 'article_title': 'AFRICAN PROSPECTS', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICAN PROSPECTS', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1865#article-20', 'issue_date': '23_09_1865', 'content': "The next tribe we meet with, as inhabitants of portions of land along the river Gambia, are the Núminkars. There are two divisions of these tribes; one subject to the King of Saloom, the other to that of Barrah. The territory of the former is situate on the north bank of the river, through which two rivers run, one called Saloom, and the other Sinie. Those who inhabit the country along the Saloom are Jollofs and Serias. The King of Saloom was at one time so powerful that he owned the land from Saloom to Cower, a distance of about 200 miles. The inhabitants on the Sinie are entirely Serias. The Numinkars, who are subject to the King of Barrah, are about thirty miles north of Betaintee.

The Numinkars are a hard-working set of people; they cultivate a good deal of land, planting principally rice and guinea corn; they are also great fishermen. They carry fish and produce to the upper rivers and exchange them for cotton and corn, or the latter of which they sell in St. Mary's, Bathurst, in exchange for iron bars, tobacco, rum, and the cotton employed for home consumption.

The following are the countries one has to go through up the River Gambia: *Passing from the north bank*, at the mouth of the river, are—1. *Saloom*. This territory extends to the interior behind the towns bordering on the river, from Barrah to as far as Cower. Between Baddibo and Jokadu is Swara Kunda Creek. 2. *Barrah*. Principal town, Essow, formerly Beridin. 3. *Jokadu*. Principal town, Jokadu. 4. *Badibo*. Principal town, India. 5. *Sangalle*. Principal town, Candy Kunda. 6. *Cower*. Principal town, Cower. 7. *Yuaney*. Principal town, Catabar. The interior county is Footah Taurah. 8. *Wollie*. Principal town, Madinna. The country in its interior is Wallor of Jollof.

There are two varieties of Foollahs met with in these parts—viz., the Wandering Foollahs, who are not Marabouts, and the Footah-Tools and Footah-Jollah, who are Marabouts.

Having thus noticed the countries along the right bank of the River Gambia, let us examine those on the left bank. On arriving at the mouth of the river, we have first Combo, occupying an extensive belt of land, whose principal town is Cape St Mary's, or Baccou—which, by its exposure to the bracing influence of the sea, has been made the Bathurst sanitarium. Combo contains three reigning kings, one at Boosumbalum, another at Bericamah, and a third at a town of the same name. The inhabitants are an admixture of Mandingoes and Jollofs. They live principally in farming and palm-wine making, and the women are all but naked."}, {'id': 745, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA CLUBS ORDINANCE.', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA CLUBS ORDINANCE.', 'last_edit_date': '12-04-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1865#article-2', 'issue_date': '23_12_1865', 'content': "Dear Sir,—Your last number contained a memorial addressed to Her Majesty's Secretary of State for the Colonies, and signed by the principal members of the Gambia societies, praying for the abrogation of an ordinance intended to crush the harmless and helpful societies long existing in that colony."}, {'id': 745, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA CLUBS ORDINANCE.', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA CLUBS ORDINANCE.', 'last_edit_date': '12-04-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1865#article-2', 'issue_date': '23_12_1865', 'content': 'The third paragraph of the memorial states, "That these societies have been standing uninterrupted for several years, and have been the means of producing good effects on the conduct of most of their outlawed and troublesome members, &c." The right honourable gentleman and yourself may not fully comprehend the meaning of this important point in the memorial, and be led to inquire what are the good effects which have been produced by those societies. I will explain. Between 1837 and 1841 the sitting magistrates at the Gambia were wearied with one complaint and one plea throughout the rainy seasons, when business is half closed, and no employment can be found for the lower class of workmen, such as labourers, &c. These men must live, and when they could not obtain their living honestly, they procured it by dishonesty, going about stealing from the merchants' stores, &c., and when taken before the magistrates they pleaded not guilty, giving as their poor, groundless reason, "that they were in want, and, having nothing to live upon, as there was no work to do in the rains, and no merchant willing to give them credit, they were obliged to rob." The magistrates then saw the real wants of the people, and consulted a Wesleyan missionary (now in England) to see if he could manage some means of restraining those lawless characters. The rev. gentleman then called on one of his local brethren to see what could be done. They concluded to form a "Workmen's Club" for assisting each other throughout the rains. The local brother mustered the whole of his tribe and explained to them in their own language the shame and disgrace some had brought on themselves, &c. He then showed them the necessity for a Workmen's Club, for assisting each other in time of need. The proposal was unanimously voted; and thus the first Eboe society started in the year 1842. It consisted of both males and females, and up to this day a male member pays 1s., and a female 6d. per month. At the close of every meeting the members were warned to be honest, and informed that should they require any necessary assistance the club will be ready to meet their wants. In the course of two years the practices complained of were totally forgotten. People became honest and respectful, other tribes following their example, until all the various tribes in the Gambia formed themselves into similar societies with similar objects. It succeeded so well that the magistrates and merchants returned their thanks to the rev. gentleman for his kind suggestion to the people. The people are also, to this day, grateful to him and to his local brother, their own countryman, whose son is now in London, sent by his countrymen to study for their further welfare.'}, {'id': 3019, 'article_title': 'The Bathurst Letter, Signed "A Member," Published in Our September Number', 'full_section_title': 'The Bathurst Letter, Signed "A Member," Published in Our September Number', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1876#article-0', 'issue_date': '01_01_1876', 'content': 'Bathurst, River Gambia, Oct. 16, 1875.**'}, {'id': 5276, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA BLUE BOOK.', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA BLUE BOOK.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1885#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_12_1885', 'content': '**Manufactures, Mines, and Fisheries, &c.**—Manufactures are varied and most primitive; the cloths of the country, as specimens of weaving and dyeing, are the most advanced proofs of locally developed skill. An unpretentious but extensive timber industry proceeds in the building of cutters, by means of which, with the aid of canoes, the inland water carrying trade is mainly effected. The tonnage of the Gambia cutter local industry is represented by 2,500. The other woodwork is interesting and curious, composed of agricultural implements, furniture, musical instruments, wharves, &c. Ground nut oil, palm oil, palm kernel oil, castor oil, toolacoona oil, worage oil, porpoise oil, shark liver oil, manatee oil, are locally manufactured in primitive fashion for home use. The Gambia had much notoriety in the past for its woods, which were to be found in European markets; they are still to be had; and convenient water transport by means of the river available, so that a revival of this trade may, perhaps, be hoped for. The celebrated runs, "Borassus Æthiopicum," of the Gambia may find a market in Holland in connexion with house foundation; they would seem to last longer under than out of water. The natives make also rope of the fibres of monkey bread, cane, aloe, "Farrah." The fish is abundant, cheap, and similar to what is found on the Senegal coast, a detailed scientific description of which will be found in the "Faune de la Senegambie," par A. S. Rochbrane. The fishermen are chiefly aliens as regards this settlement, composed of Iebons of Senegal. Net, hook and line, and harpoons from canoes, are used as implements of catch. Mines have not been discovered within the settlement, but their sites are, if not bordered, neared by the Upper Gambia. The gold mines of Bambouk, or Bambarra, near to the source of the Gambia, are of notoriety.'}, {'id': 5794, 'article_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'full_section_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'last_edit_date': '02-04-1889', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'issue_date': '04_02_1889', 'content': 'Beginning on the West, the first British possession we encounter on the coast of Guinea is the small colony of the Gambia, where we have allowed the French to obtain a considerable hold. Not only has the Upper Gambia been recently taken under French protection, but the greater part of commerce at the mouth of the Gambia is French. The official coinage is in French five-franc pieces, and the European language most commonly heard is French. The Gambia is the most readily navigable waterway in the interior—in fact, almost the only navigable waterway for any distance inland which is to be found on the West African coast, west of the Niger Delta. It is, indeed, a waterway leading to the very heart of the French possessions in Senegambia, and had we shown any energy in the past, and a greater patriotism and knowledge prevailed among our West African merchants, we should have considerably extended our rule in these regions, to the palpable benefit of our trade. It was really the cessation of the slave traffic that brought about the downfall of our prosperity in the Gambia, for it does not grow the oil palm; and ground nuts, now its chief article of export, were not sufficiently in vogue during the first quarter of this century to supply the place of slaves as a source of profit; and the Gambia has remained a restricted and not very valuable British possession, our actual rule being confined to a very small area, just at the mouth of the river, and one or two islets in its middle course. The native inhabitants of the Gambia represent several very distinct negro races. There are the fine, handsome Wolof people, some of whom are Mahommedans; the pagan Felups, negroes of rather low development; and various Mandingo tribes; and even Fulbe along the Middle and Upper Gambia.'}]
tat_extra:
[{'document_title': 'Address of the Egbas at Bathurst to their Friends in Abeokuta', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We, the undersigned Egbas by descent, now located at Bathurst Town, St. Mary's River, Gambia, to the Chiefs, our brethren, countrymen, &c., bearing rule at Abeokuta, greeting:—

We cordially and sincerely wish you all grace and peace from God our Father, and his Son Jesus Christ.

Whereas we have been informed, from undoubted and good authorities, that you, our beloved countrymen at Abeokuta, have recently been involved in quarrels with the British Government, and are ready to take up arms against them.

We, therefore, anticipating the dismal calamities, misfortunes, and distress that will inevitably result upon our nation from this quarrel, deem it an indispensable duty of sincere and affectionate brethren seasonably to interfere; and hope, by God's grace, to prevail on you with wholesome advice, in order that a stop might speedily be put to these impending and approaching evils. Which, we earnestly pray and hope, by God's providence, will be dispersed by our advice being taken and acted upon.

We heard that you rose up against the Crodco people, and the white men interfered, and asked you to give up the matter, and be at peace with them, allowing you ten days for meditation on the subject; and that at the expiration of these ten days you still continued obstinate, in consequence of which the white men get very much angry against you. Whether the fact be true as represented to us or not, we cannot tell, as we had no written, but mere verbal information; or whether these ten days allowed you for consideration were permitted to elapse before the white men took the offence, we cannot tell; but if it be so or not, we send this note to inquire of you, expecting to receive an early answer from you. If, unfortunately, it be true, we beg most humbly to interfere; and in the name of God, invoke, supplicate, and beseech you to give up the matter, and make peace with the white men the English people, because they have all this while been protecting you from enemies from every quarter.

We were very glad, indeed, to hear of your welfare and good behaviour in times past; but to hear this last sad news troubles our heart very much, because we are here under the immediate control and government of the English people.

We expect, therefore, to hear from you nothing but peace, ure and lasting. Fare-you-well.

We subscribe ourselves, with all good wishes, ever to be your sincere, affectionate countrymen and brethren in the Gambia.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-05-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.593, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LATEST FROM THE GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Intelligence has been received from Bathurst, River Gambia, of a rising of the natives in the district, who are reported to have destroyed two or three towns and carried off many of the inhabitants. The raids are said to have been made by the warriors of Chief Beram Cissey, who himself headed the marauders. The first descent was made on the town of Jayed, a place about 300 yards from the River Gambia. After plundering the place the invaders set it on fire. As many as could fled from the city, but several fell into the enemy's hands, including five subjects of British Bathurst. The persons taken were led away into captivity. All the establishments of the traders were plundered and much booty obtained. The fugitives fled towards the River Gambia, and many of them were here picked up by a trading cutter. The poor people were almost naked when found on the banks of the river. The town of Toro was also destroyed by Cissey and his followers. It was stated that the interior of the country had been in a disturbed state for some time, war raging incessantly between the rival chiefs until the belligerents had gradually come to the sea-board. Some of the chiefs, it is said, received annuities from the British Government, with which they are stated to have purchased ammunition to carry on the hostilities. It appears that these troubles had arisen in the kingdom of Badaiboo. We hear that on the death of King Maba, his son, Saida Matee, should have succeeded to the throne, but his authority was usurped by his uncle, Mahmoud Derry Bah, the Regent. Civil war ensued, with the result that Saida Matee was defeated. The fugitive Prince after burning and laying waste all his domains in his flight has, it is supposed, gone to seek the aid of Latjore the deposed Monarch of Cayor, who has nevertheless a number of followers, and a severe struggle for supremacy may be expected, the power of Said Matti being crippled but not destroyed. What is most surprising in the flight of Said Matti is the celerity with which he made his retreat out of the kingdom without even a battle to decide his fate. It is supposed, however, that at the most critical moment he was deserted by his most powerful vassals who it is reported went over to the invaders. And it is quite possible that he may make another effort to recover his lost position. Until lately the action of the Administrator of the Gambia (Captain Moloney) was confined to the giving of good advice and to offers of mediation. When one of Saida Matee's stockaded towns were recently captured, the victors not only burnt the place but pillaged the goods of British subjects, and the latter in consequence fled to Bathurst for safety. The Administrator at once left for the seat of war in the hope of being able to obtain reparation, as well as to prevent all danger of hostilities extending to British territory. The Administrator's mission appears to have been completely successful, as in an interview with Mahmoud Derry Bah he succeeded in extracting from that chief a promise that the claims of the plundered traders should be satisfied. A Board, consisting of Mr. Richards, the chief magistrate at Bathurst, Mr. J. R. Maxwell, the Queen's Advocate, and a native merchant, was engaged in investigating these claims, so that compensation might be demanded only for such as were shown to be well founded.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.609, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Policy of Non-Intervention in Western Africa: Its Mischievous Tendency on the Good Government of the Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The political horizon of British Gambia is by no means in a satisfactory state; clouds are gathering from a quarter which ordinary men regard as a menace to the peace of the river. A glance at the past will show us what we may expect in the future, and also how to deal with it.

Mahba, King of Badiboo, formidable alike to all the native kings and to the French and to the English Government, sent last September a menacing despatch (in Arabic) to Colonel D'Arcy, the officer administering the Government of the Gambia, very warlike in its tone, and by subsequent actions violated all existing treaties. He detained all the British traders within the kingdom of Badiboo, with their goods and chattels, not allowing one man to leave the place, and also prevented all ingress into Badiboo, thus putting a stop to the trade of an extensive country, whose yearly quota of ground-nuts and hides adds greatly to the revenue of the colony. What was the *casus belli*?

The ostensible cause of this warlike and menacing attitude was, that a woman with a few children* availed themselves of Mahba's temporary absence from his capital, and made their escape to the British town of Bathurst. He at once sent to Colonel D'Arcy that, unless the woman and children were delivered up, all friendly diplomatic relation must stop, and trade cease, and the ports of Badiboo must, consequently, be considered closed to English merchants.

But the real cause, to all those who have studied the character of these Marabouts, inhabitants of the River Gambia, is to be found in that ambitious, overbearing, and covetous disposition of the Mussulmans, who view with discontent the rich prize they would obtain, could they have an opportunity of making one midnight raid on the rich Babboo Christian merchants at Bathurst. The toleration of this overbearing disposition of the Marabout chieftains in the River Gambia will always lead to serious complications; they must be made to understand that the British Government, although desirous of peace, yet still will never tolerate any nonsense from them.

We have not as yet forgotten the outrageous attack of Mahfal, the Commander-in-Chief of south-eastern Badiboo, on towns in British grounds, which led to the battle of Zoobabocolong; and at present, if reports from traders are correct, the greater part of Mahba's force is threatening Albreda. But the unhappy manner in which that most justifiable war was received by the home authorities, must for ever fetter the hands of all subsequent administrators of the Government of British Gambia.", 'last_edit_date': '1867-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1867#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.607, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Proposed French and English Exchange of West African Settlements', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Irrespective of Imperial considerations and views, and of the questions of West African development and civilization involved in the matter of the proposed exchange of British and French settlements in West Africa, there must necessarily be particular and personal interests that would be affected by such changes of rule and system as are involved in the proposed measure, should it be carried into effect. These particular and personal interests have grown up under British rule in the Gambia, and are the only ones on the West Coast of any importance that would be jeopardized or interfered with by the contemplated transfers. The British free trade policy, which has opened the ports of all our settlements and colonies to foreign commerce, differs so essentially from the French protective system, under which, as at the Senegal, for instance, all possible British competition is prohibited, that the British merchants having establishments on the River Gambia—establishments, some of which were founded more than half a century ago—are very naturally apprehensive that in coming under the restrictive French colonial system, instead of the liberal British one, their interests will be seriously jeopardized; or, in brief, that they would very soon be driven out altogether from the Gambia as a French colony or settlement. We cannot say that these apprehensions are unfounded, and we have therefore not been at all surprised to find that the British merchants having establishments on the Gambia have been holding private meetings in London, during the past month, for mutual counsel and agreement as to the best course for them to pursue for their own protection in this emergency. We sympathize with them, and do not hesitate to say that it would be unjust on the part of Her Majesty’s Government to make the proposed exchange without some stipulation that shall protect their absolute interest. As we are strangers to their counsels, we have not heard what is their estimate of these interests, or what special course of action they may have decided to adopt in defence of them. We have, however, a very decided opinion of our own in the matter, and that opinion we shall unreservedly express. First, then, we think they will be very unwise if they adopt the course of opposition to the Imperial policy in this matter, either on Imperial grounds or on the grounds of any supposed rights that the Native populations in the Gambia may have to a continuance of British rule in their countries. These are questions with which as British merchants they have not any concern. Like all other British subjects, they may express fully and freely their opinions respecting them, but they will not be wise if they do more. Their opposition to the Imperial policy would necessarily have little or no weight, because it could not be separated from, but would infallibly be regarded as influenced by, personal considerations. We helped them in 1869-70 to fight the battle against the transfer of the Gambia to the French, on Imperial grounds, because the transfer, as then proposed, was motived by considerations unworthy of such an empire as that of Great Britain, and certain to bring upon her an enduring disgrace. The motives of Government action are, however, at the present time essentially different. It is no longer a question whether ten or twenty thousand pounds a-year can be saved to the Imperial exchequer by getting rid of the Gambia. That economy was made without getting rid of it. We cannot, therefore, as we stated last month, fight the battle over again on such grounds, because they no longer exist. The considerations that influence us ought also to influence the Gambia merchants on this point. We insist the more on this because we have heard that merchants not connected with the Gambia trade have been active in tendering their co-operation and support to the Gambia merchants in opposing the Government on these Imperial grounds. They have real or fancied interests of their own involved, no doubt, in the projected exchange of settlements; but their interests are not in any respect the interests of the Gambia merchants, who will do wisely to leave them to pull their own chestnuts out of the fire, if they have any that seem likely to be burned there; and decline the proffered aid which, if accepted, will weaken instead of strengthen their position. Their true policy seems to us very clear. It is that they should not oppose the Government views, which are supposed to be now based on Imperial considerations of sufficient weight to justify the Government in entertaining them. Their acquiescence or non-acquiescence will not eventually influence the Government decision. What they have a just right to ask, and should energetically and persistently ask, is that they should not be sacrificed to those Imperial considerations which may justify Her Majesty’s Government in exchanging the Gambia for the relinquishment by the French in favour of Great Britain of their settlements and interests on all other parts of the West Coast of Africa. The Gambia merchants have invested large sums in buildings and other immovable property, in the belief, which they were in every respect justified in entertaining, that the British settlement on the Gambia was a permanent one. The giving up by Great Britain of any settlement it has once formed is an event so extremely rare that there could not be any possible reason why the future cession of the Gambia to some other Power should have been at all contemplated or considered by them. There is not anything therefore in their position at the Gambia to diminish the force and justice of their claim, that in any arrangements made by the British Government with that of the French for the cession of the Gambia to the latter, their interests should be scrupulously guarded and preserved to the fullest extent of their pecuniary value. We have no doubt it is tolerably correct that it would be impossible for them to live and continue their trade at the Gambia as hitherto, when French authorities and laws shall have superseded those under whom and which they have hitherto lived and carried on their commerce. The cession of the Gambia to the French involves therefore their eventual ejection from the settlement. If they remain there striving against the new and adverse circumstances after the cession, and those circumstances act so prejudicially to their interests as they seem to us to be fully justified in believing that they will act, they might be forced into parting with their properties to French merchants at almost any price that the latter might choose to give. They are justified therefore in demanding of Her Majesty’s Government that they shall not be subject to any such contingency, but be so placed under the new rule and laws that, should the prejudicial results which they fear really follow, they may be able at any time to leave the Gambia and receive the full present value of their properties. It is not necessary for us to point out to such practical men as they are how this might be arranged for without any actual loss or burthen to the French Government. It might certainly be so arranged that should the change result adversely to them they shall receive the full present value of their properties; while at the same time they should be left free to realize as much more for these as they might be enabled to obtain. Our belief may', 'last_edit_date': '1875-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1875#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.613, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "DEFEAT AND DEATH OF THE MAHOMETAN CHIEF AND WARRIOR MABA, OR MAHABA.**

We have often had to report in the African Times the successes and excesses of Maba, who has been the scourge of the countries between the Senegal and the Gambia, and thus brought himself occasionally into collision with both the French and the English. In 1861 he was an unimportant chief in the kingdom of Baddiboo, against which the last great war expedition of the British authorities in the Gambia was directed. Maba was a bigoted Mahometan, and watching his opportunity, he in 1861 rebelled against the King of Baddiboo, whom he put to death, raising himself to be supreme ruler of Baddiboo. He then declared a propaganda of Mahometanism, which he endeavoured to force by fire and sword in all the adjacent countries. His last recorded exploit was a successful attack upon some 300 French troops (Europeans), who were all slain except nine, the officer in command putting an end to his own existence.

The last French mail from Senegal brought to Europe the intelligence that this restless and cruel fanatic chief has at last met with the fate he has constantly provoked. He was therein stated to have been taken prisoner in battle by the Joloffe King of Sein, and by him put to death, his head and hands being sent by the Joloffe King to the French Governor of Senegal.

By the mail of the 2nd inst. from Bathurst we have a confirmation of this important news. As we are not of those who believe that the forcible spread of Mahometanism in Africa (and it never spreads in any other way) is desirable, we unfeignedly rejoice that this great warrior-chief, for such he undoubtedly was, exists no more to trouble the Gambia countries. He has interfered very much with the development of the ground-nut cultivation, on which the trade in the Gambia chiefly depends, and many British traders up the river have suffered severely in the troubles he was constantly exciting, and the wars he was as constantly waging; and we hope now to hear of a new era of trading prosperity there which may compensate them for their losses, and promote the spread of civilisation in those important countries. In this case we feel certain the British authorities will again find it necessary to place a small force at M'Carthy's Island, the former British outpost in the interior.", 'last_edit_date': '1867-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1867#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.608, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BATHURST, GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Without any uncertainty, we would state, in contradiction of Mr. Lee's observation, that the people of this settlement have no inclination whatever, and are directly opposed to the opinion, for more reasons than one, that the Gambia should be restored to its former system of separate government.

This novel idea of separation was first expressed by a member of our Legislative Council, who suggested to a member of the Gambia Native Association, about three months ago, a memorial on the subject to the Right Honourable the Principal Secretary of State for the Colonies; but the suggestion was so opposed by the Association in behalf of the general public that nothing more was ventured further upon the subject. It was even suspected that, like a late memorial against the establishment of a Government school in this settlement, some clandestine efforts might be put forth to move the Government to adopt the system of separate government, and the Association has been watchful lest such a circumstance should transpire.

If the Gambia be made a separate Government, it will be indispensable to appoint a Governor-in-Chief and Chief Justice; thus the staff of our Government, which is already proclaimed numerous, will be increased along with its expenditure. It is true that the Gambia is not poor, possessing as it does about £25,000 in the hands of the Crown Agents in London. But although it took Dr. Gouldsbury six years of efficient labours to accumulate this amount, yet it does not appear, from the unnecessary expenses the Government is now undergoing, that the settlement will ever be in position to meet the increased liability which a separation must inevitably entail.

We cannot speak much in favour of Captain Moloney's administration. To us it appears that his advent here was an importation of troubles, losses, and depression of trade. Dr. Gouldsbury's administration was a marked one. It effected so much improvement in the settlements, privately or publicly, that it can never fail to find a high place in the history of the Gambia. Already the cry is heard in Bathurst, it resounds in the interior of the Gambia, "Dr. Gouldsbury is wanted! It is he that should be here at the present crisis." Like Sir Samuel Rowe, it is acknowledged that Dr. Gouldsbury knows how to go about natives, and how to establish peace among them. We are of opinion that, should Dr. Gouldsbury be ordered out here for the space of two years, he will, without much cost to the Government, re-establish peace among the natives, and do all things tending to improve and extend trade; and in case the Home Government should decide upon separating the Gambia from the Government of the West Africa Settlements, we earnestly hope that Dr. Gouldsbury, or some other experienced competent individual, will be appointed to the office of Governor-in-Chief.—Believe me, Mr. Editor, yours sincerely,', 'last_edit_date': '1886-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1886#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.595, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Wars among the Natives of the River Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our informant, to whom we have alluded in our notice of the River Gambia, on our second page, writes in substance as follows, relative to those wars among the natives of the Gambia Districts, to which we have more than once alluded, and which have been generally represented as resulting from a Mohammedan propaganda by fire and sword:—

According to his version, the origin of this disturbance is to be found in the mismanagement of the late British war against the kingdom of Badiboo; and, therefore, that what seems now to occupy almost exclusively the heads, hearts, and hands of the Government, is traceable distinctly to their own acts. He seems to consider that the chief Mahabah is performing a duty which the Government neglected to do, and for doing which it envies the man who is really performing very important public services, and preparing the way for the progressive civilization of the country. That man, Mahabah, he says, is not seeking his own interests only, but that of all British subjects. British merchants have been without any real, efficient protection in the river of late years, and Mahabah has made a vast improvement in this respect during the last 24 months. It is true, he proceeds, that, partly owing to the war, and partly to the famine that prevailed during the rainy season, there has been a great deficiency of produce, "but it is far better to prepare the ground before sowing seed, than to sow it in unprepared soil." The Pagsoos, in this river, are a people that do not work, but who go about plundering those who do work; pillaging the merchants and traders, and committing many other and great enormities. They are, in fact, a lazy, predatory, and degraded people. The late war between the British and Badiboo was caused by such deeds as are above alluded to. The British effected really nothing, but Mahabah has made an entire change. These people, before so troublesome, having been brought by him under subjection, are now learning to depend on their own labour for the means of support; so that British merchants, who previously scarcely dared to commission any traders in that part, have now been able to find employment as traders there for those who have been (so arbitrarily, as he contends) dismissed from the Government service.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-02-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-21', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.617, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'History of Changes in the Gambia Trade', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—It is now a very considerable time since we have written you on matters concerning the Gambia; but as opportunity affords we will enter the lists and aid our friends who have been furnishing you with reports of the state of things which has assumed a most formidable appearance against the native traders, dealers, and other inhabitants of the place.

The time has now arrived, and unity or combination is the cry everywhere in Bathurst among the native inhabitants to give the death struggle against the wicked contrivance of a body of men on matters respecting the re-enactment of an Ordinance that has been repealed, through your valuable assistance, by the wise and good Secretary of State for the Colonies, the Earl of Kimberley.

We have, it is true, for some time past been very careless about the internal development of our interests, and hence thrown aside things of vital importance that demand our every attention, as if we were at ease under our vines and fig-trees.

Having been aroused from our state of despondency, we have made ourselves ready for the fight, and if assistance could be afforded us through your valuable columns, we will do all that lies in our power to put an end to the monster—the slavery under which we are now groaning. During the great question of the Cession of the Gambia, which was set on foot in the year 1875, and while we were extremely glad that Her Majesty's Government has set aside and will never cede a Crown Colony, such as the Gambia, to any foreign power, Mr. Frederic Speer made his appearance on the Gambia, and made himself known as one of the correspondents of one of the leading papers in Great Britain, and as a deputy sent out by a society to inquire into the feelings of the people; at which time a circular was sent round summoning the members of the Gambia Native Association, which sent a deputation to wait on the deputy sent out by that society, which, we were told, took an interest in the welfare of the native inhabitants in particular.", 'last_edit_date': '1881-11-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1881#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.592, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WEST AFRICAN SETTLEMENTS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have formerly opposed, and successfully, any cession of the Gambia by Great Britain, to France. But, if the British policy there is to be such as has been shadowed forth in questions and answers in the committee-room, we are inclined to withdraw our opposition—nay more, to recommend what we most ardently opposed. The testimony to the entire discontinuance of the slave-trade, under any name or pretext, by France, has been general and convincing. On slave-trade suppression grounds there would now consequently be no loss by the substitution of French for British rule in the Gambia. If, therefore, because of economical considerations—because of the poverty of its exchequer, Great Britain declines to exercise such jurisdiction over the river and the natives along its banks, from the sea to M'Carthy's Island, as will as effectually repress violence, robbery, and war, stimulate production and commerce, and aid voluntary efforts for the dissemination of Christianity, we see no justification in her retaining the Gambia, provided the French Government will consent to acquire it on reasonable terms, and under such stipulations for entire freedom of trade, and protection to Christian missions, as we feel convinced the enlightened Emperor of the French would willingly agree to. Possessing both the Senegal and the Gambia, and having already a preponderating influence in the neighbouring rivers south of the latter, and supposed to be in their upper portions in near proximity to it, as the Senegal is to the northward, the French Government, which, fortunately for African civilization, still possesses sufficient pecuniary resources to enable her to expend a few thousands a-year for bringing the over-warring natives under a peaceful restraint, as the only foundation for future enlarged production, commerce, and civilization, might, in a short time, succeed in giving a new aspect to regions whose fertility is beyond dispute, and which possess an adequate population inclined to agricultural pursuits.

For British reasons we should indeed deeply—deeply deplore such a cession of the Gambia to France. To retire from British territory in any part of the world is a serious thing; but if we are to abandon every noble, Christian, and humanitarian, as well as commercial aspiration at the dictum of a miserable economy, our country would only be dishonoured by a longer stay at the Gambia. Better leave it at once, while we have still some rags of reputation remaining from past benefits conferred.

* Burton's "Wanderings in West Africa." Vol. I., p. 255.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.604, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE RIVER GAMBIA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The question of the cession of the important River Gambia to France has again cropped up. From the moment we heard of a new advance of the French in the rivers near Sierra Leone we felt convinced that it would do so. With the exception of the River Niger, the Gambia is the finest waterway from the Atlantic to the interior of Africa; and even were there no other considerations mixed up with the desire of possessing it, *per se*, by the French, it is well calculated to inspire such desire. But there are other considerations, and those of no mean importance. The upper waters of the River Senegal—on which river the French Government has spent very large sums of money—are not very far distant from a portion of the upper waters of the Gambia, which is a far superior river to the Senegal; and it must certainly be a matter of real importance to obtain, by means of possession of the two rivers, not only undisputed commercial and territorial possession of the rich tracts of country lying between the two streams, but a monopoly of access from the Western Ocean to the heart of West-Central Africa, with its reputed rich gold fields—with Timbuctoo, the Soudan, and the Upper Niger. Disposed as the French Government would be to spend money in the Gambia, as they have already done in the Senegal—being without rivals—being able, by possessing both streams, to bring the entire native population under a sufficient degree of subjection to force a reign of peace among them, and to insure the fullest security for traders, the River Gambia would be to the French Government and French commerce a possession of immense value. And further, when viewed in connection with the projected great railway across the Sahara, the acquisition of the River Gambia by the French Government would insure to France, within a very brief period, the absolute sovereignty over the whole of North-west and West-Central Africa. The old Roman dominion in Africa, as held after the subjection of Carthage, would be eclipsed by modern French dominion over the same and still wider regions; while the commercial spoils would be far more solidly gratifying to Paris than was the procession in chains of conquered sovereigns to the citizens of the old and renowned capital of the world. The French have, therefore, very strong and solid reasons for wishing to obtain the River Gambia, to say nothing of the *éclat* so dear to the national heart that would attend such an acquisition obtained without expenditure of either money or blood. We say without money, because for any amount they might be called upon to pay for the transfer of existing establishments they would receive their money's worth. But there are other parties interested in this matter. The people of Sierra Leone, merchants and traders, are not those to whom we would here allude. The cession of the River Gambia to France is desired by them because they want to get rid of the French from their own immediate neighbourhood. We warned them and their Government, sixteen or eighteen years ago, that the encroachments then commencing in the Mellicourie, and other neighbouring rivers, would, ere long, unless some measures were at once taken to prevent it, become a serious thorn in the side of Sierra Leone trade and commerce. The proper measures were not taken, and the result we foretold has been painfully realized. The giving up of the River Gambia to France on the sole condition of the latter withdrawing at once and for ever from what are called the Sierra Leone rivers, is, therefore, a popular idea at Freetown. It is so pleasant a thing to secure great advantages, not by any personal or local self-sacrifice, but by the sacrifice of possessions belonging to others, in which they have themselves really no interest, and on which they have not really any claim whatever. Why should the great River Gambia, an Imperial possession of magnitude and value, be given up to France, and its people be transferred beneath the rule of that Power, for the advantage of Sierra Leone? There cannot be any valid reason for such a thing. The mere withdrawal of the French from the Sierra Leone rivers in order to increase the commerce of Sierra Leone, the gains of its traders, and perhaps the public revenue, could not be any equivalent to the British Government for the cession of so important an Imperial possession as the River Gambia indisputably is; although up to the present time it has not pleased the British Government to adopt the necessary measures for utilizing it for the national benefit. Then, as we have said, there are other parties interested in this matter. We mean the more or less educated natives of Bathurst, St. Mary's, &c., and even of M'Carthy's Island, 300 miles up this noble river. On the first occasion of negotiations between the French and British Governments for the cession of the Gambia to France, the feelings and opinions of those natives against the proposed cession were very strongly expressed. They denied the right of the British Government to give them up to French dominion. Contrasting their position with that of a similar class in the Senegal, they protested against being deprived of the rights and privileges of British subjects. We espoused their cause and fought their battle. The British mercantile houses at the Gambia were also strong in their opposition; and, finally, the whole project fell to the ground. When it was again brought forward, we found that although the opinion and feelings of the people had undergone some change; though there was not the same enthusiasm in protests against the cession, there was still no desire for the withdrawal of the British Government, and the advent of that of France. During the discussions on the subject in the British Parliament, when the great advantages that would surely be obtained by the adoption by the Imperial Government of effective means for developing the acknowledged great resources of the noble river were earnestly set forth, there was something very like a pledge given by the Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies that some such means would be adopted. This pledge, however, has never been redeemed. No greater protection than previously has been given to trade and commerce up the river; but instead thereof, traders have been", 'last_edit_date': '1880-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1880#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.605, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The British Operations in the Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**69**

**FRANCE AND DAHOMEY.**

For generations the existence and independence of the Kingdom of Dahomey has been a standing menace to the peace of West Africa.
